To write and many please is much,
to please not write, is pain:
Than rather write and please the good,
then spend thy time in vain.
HVLOETS Dictionarie, newelye corrected, amended, SET IN ORDER AND ENLARGED,
with many names of Men, Towns, Beasts, Fowls, Fishes, Trees, Shrubbes,
Herbs, Fruits, Places, Instruments etc. And in each place fit Phrases,
gathered out of the best Latin Authors. Also the French thereunto annexed, by
which you may find the Latin or French, of any English word you will.

By John Higgins late student in Oxeforde.

Liber ad Lectorem.
Simplice iampridem qui sum tantum ore loquutus,
Bino contentus reddere verba sono,
Nunc ego triglottos trinis en prodeo linguis
Illustris, mira commoditate nouus.
Higginus claro vos istoc munere douat
Heus iuuenes, grato me accipitote s^^^
LONDINI, In aedibus Thomae Marshij. ANNO. 1572.

The wise will vewe and deem the best,
unwise the worst will mark:
The wise do use reprouinge least,
the foolish ever carke.
Then care the less be thou at rest,
though Momus baule and bark.


COLVMNA GLORIAE VIRTUES
blazon or coat of arms

CLARISSIMO VIRO, AC BONARVM LITERARVM SVMMO PATROno Domino suo, Domino Georgio
Peckham equiti aurato, Ioannis Higgini, de huius operis dedicatione EPISTOLA.
MEMINI ET DVM VIVAM SEMper meminero (Clarissime vir) Platonicum illud: Ortus
nostri primas Dij immortales, secundas patria, tertias parents vendicant.
Illud enim ipsum quoties cogito, (cogito autem saepissime) toties iustissimi
debiti memoria, atque recordatione sic co^moueor: vt (quia soluendo non sum)
incredibilem ex eodem reminiscendo anxietatem, dolorem, atque molestiam
percipiam. Cui quidem aegritudini quo possim expeditius, citiusque mederi,
nullum te^pus intermisi (diligente interim adhibita deliberatione) vel
cogitandi, vel etiam inuestigandi, quid tandem Deo Optim. Max. gratum, quid
patriae commodum, quid summatim parentibus, tibique (quem propter singularem in
omnes literatos beneuolentia^ patris loco colui) non iniucundum exhibere^. Nam
vt de te (patron benignissime) dicam quod sentio, illud tacere non possum, te
post reditu^ tuum e Gallijs, in Academia Oxoniensi aedes magnis sumptibus
extruxisse: doctissimorum hominum familiaritate saepissime vsum esse: linguarum
cognitionem (cuius magno desyderio tenebaris) summis encomijs ornasse: mihi
caeterisque tuis alumnis opem, auxiliumque praebuisse: denique lectiones,
disceptationes, exercitationesque cunctas in scholis publicis ita frequentasse:
vt omnes te virum rarae virtutis, literarum decus, ac bonarum artium amatorem
vere praedicarent. Itaque existimaui si quicquam in lucem laud dignum ederem,
quod a tuo studio non dissentiret. id neque Dijs immortalibus, neque patriae,
neque parentibus, neque vllis studiosis ingratum vel iniucundum fore* Qua de re
maiore cum deliberatione cogitanti, etiamsi multae res sese mihi obtulissent,
in quibus non inutiliter versari poteram: inter reliquas tamen iuuenum
praesertim nobilium erudiendorum cupiditas, caeteras long multumque superabat.
Quorum tyrocinio cum Gra^maticae disciplina diligens and exquisita maxim
necessaria esset, ego me verborum inueniendorum arti alicui and methodo
tradidi. Et quia eorundem vniuersalis tractatio magnam and operam, and
industriam desyderat: Etymologiam vt iuuentuti sine magistro faciliorem, ita ad
prima rudimenta intelligenda magis idoneam, nobis ornandam tractandamque
suscepimus. Qua de re foeliciter perficienda animi omnino dubious, cum diutius
cogitassem, and doctissimorum in hac re cu^ labores, tum etiam lauds
ponderassem, forte fortuna Huloeti imperfectus, sed doctus labor mihi in mentem
veniebat, quem quasi diuinitus datum in manus sumpsi, singula folia legi, atque
relegi, paginas lustraui, lineas notaui, verba consyderaui, syllabas, literas,
apices, atque charecteres dilige^ter perpendi: tandem cum ex aequa censura
cognouissem quid redundaret, and quid de^sset: proxima mihi cura fuit, vt and
ea reijcerem quae superflua videba^tur, and ea adijcere^ quae desyderabantur.
Eum igitur hijsce noctibus hybernis locupletaui, existimans nullum tempus
perire, quod optimis studijs impertiretur: minimeque liberi hominis esse
iacturae adscribere, quod patriae, and amicoru^ vtilitati impenderetur. Sed ne
obtrectatorum canina inuidia impetum in nos faciat, videto (vir singularis)
atque animaduerte scopum nostri laboris. Non alienis vestigijs desidiose
insistere conati sumus, non in aliena^ messem furtiuam falcem immittere: sed
more prouide^tis atque frugi agricolae Huloeti ego sementa ad messem perduxi,
perducta in horreum congessi, and quod ille seminauit, ego vicissim meto. Nam
illum primo Gallice loqui institui, atque ex bilingui triglotton effeci:
secundo nouas voces, idiomata, atque phrases adiunxi: denique, ex paruo magnu^,
ex libello in volumen transformaui. In me tamen ego aequissimos tuos oculos
nimium intentos esse nollem, Huloetum sicut antea intuere, qui non nisi mutata
vest a me ditior factus, atque splendidior in luce^ prodit, laudemque Huloeto,
laborem Higgino attribuito. Deu^ enim testor me nihil aliud spectare, quam
iuuenum omnium emolumentum atque co^modum, haeredis praesertim tui, qui and in
lingua latina and iure nostro Britannico tantu^ profecit, quantu^ in illa
aetate vix expectari potuit. Illud interim no^ nescio nihil tam recta ratione,
sapienterue dictu^ esse, nihil tam been prudenterue factu^, quod quorundam
improborum non incurrat maleuolentiam: qui neque ipsi recte quicquam aut
faciu^t aut facere possunt, and alijs tame^ ne recte faciant, impedimento sunt.
Habuit enim diuinus vates Romanorumque poetarum facile princeps, suos Bauios,
suosque Meuios, habuit etiam sacratissimus Graecorum poetaru^ Homerus suum
Zoilum: Quare quemadmodum hic Alexandru^ bellicossimu^, ille Caesare^
Augustissimu^, co^tra malorum amarissima^ dicacitate^ patronum habuit: sic and
ego quo sim ab obtrectatorum odijs tutus atque securus, ad te bonarum literarum
fautorem, and ad tuum patrocinium co^fugio, tibi tuaeque fidei, me meaque omnia
comittens. Na^ si obtrectatores (quorum omnia sunt plenissima) te protectorem
atque propulsatorem videri^t, aut iniqua^ maledicendi consuetudinem deponent
atque abijcient, aut saltem ita coercebunt, vt tantum clandestine nobis
insidientur: ita eoru^ inuidia aut parua, aut certe nulla erit, seque sui omnes
quam primum poenitebit. Huc etiam and illud accedit, vt tanto ardentius in his
versetur iuue^tus, quanto magis intelliget haec eadem tam pio, tamque generoso
viro placuisse. Sic eodem opere and tu patriae, and ego tibi, patriaeque
debitum officium praestabo, dum patriae nostri studij fructum, tibi vero omnem
obseruantia^ offeramus. Accipias idcirco gratissimo animo, hoc quicquid est
muneris (quod tuo nomini reuerentiae causa dicamus) non tam oblati dignitatem,
qua^ offerentis in te animum atque pietate^ ponderans: quod si pro tua
consuetudine feceris, maiorem mihi scribendi alacritatem, maxima^ tibi nominis
tui gloriam parabis.

Nomini tuo deditissimus Ioannes Higginus.

To the Reader.
AT first I took this work of Master Huloets in hand (gentle Reader) only
to enlarge, and when I had herein passed some paineful time, I perceived it
almost a more easy matter to make new, then to amend: for there were many
such words, as either served not for the matter, or were out of use. Yet since
I had taken so much pains therein, and brought thereto welnighe then a Thousand
words and Phrases, I thought not so to lease my labor and forsake the
enterprise, but once again took pen in hand, and such words as were not
sufficient (by consent of authority) I either displaced, and put far bettter
in their roumes, or if they were doubtful, confirmed by sclender authority, or
else served the place but not so fitlye, I gave them an Asteriske or note in
this manner * and in some places if I had better, and yet thought those would
stand, I gave the same note * and set such words or Phrases as I found
after it. I have also where mine Author wrote the English and not the Latin,
filde those places: so where it was far out of order, and ill to find, there
have I not without great pain brought it in, and put too many names of things,
yea and sometime their natures, cyting the book or Chapter where I red them and
adding thereto the French. And for ye better attayning to the knowledge of
words, I went not to the common Dictionaries only, but also to the Authors
themselves, and used the rein conference with them which wrote particularly of
such things, as ye place required. As in herbs I followed the judgment of
Master Turner, Dodoneus, Pineus, Fuchius, and sometime Plinius: In beasts,
fishes and fowls, Conradus Gesnerus: In instruments of war Vegetius: In
buildinge Vitruuius: generallye Hadrianus Iunius: In names of places Ptolomeus:
In the nature of words Valla and others: In Phrases Thierre out of which I
confess I have taken a great part of this Book, notinge the Phrases with S.
after the French, for that Stephanus was the first Author thereof: and
finallye I wrate not in the whole Book one quyre, without perusinge and
conference of many Authors. Therefore where you find in the Book any of ye
first letters, of the names above, or the like: that same stands for a note
of the Authors name, where I found such Phrase, French, name, or word as is
there placed. And if any shall doubt hereof, let him but confer Huloet and
this together, and peradventure in one letters lookinge over he shall find so
much added, as shall seem more painful to him in account, then I deemed the
labor in doing it. I fought be taken away, be sure it was done, not without
some conference with ye best Authors: the same shall you find observed in the
additions, which thing those that can judge better, and use less
reprehension shall sooner find, then those that use more, with less and weaker
judgment. And though the book needs no explication, sith it is far more
easy, as well for the Phrase, as also for the order then it was before, yet for
the better understanding thereof, observe this followinge. Where you find a
verb without this sign To, before him (which is our English note of the
infinitive mode of al Verbes, (except Passiues) you may add the sign thereto,
as in this Verb Lay, where is Lay blame, Lay to ones charge, Lay in wait,
which are in their places so easy for him to understand that knows a Verb
from a Nowne, that they need no exposition: and signifye, To lay blame, To
lay to ones charge, To lay in wait. Yet have I in many places added this
sign To before them, as in Lead, thus: To lead one to etc. For where I
cannot begin the Phrase with the word wherein it is, and keep the order of
letter still in the first front, there begin I the line with such a Paragraphe,:
As in Lie thus, To tell a lie, To forge a lie, To maintain a lie, To take one
in a lie, To imagine a lie, and likewise in others. And where ever you find
the Paragraphe, that same is all by me added yt follows it. Wherefore gentle
Reader accept my pains, as thou would others should (in like case)
accept thine, which if I perceive, assure thy self (or it be long) to
receive other fruits of my labor that shall profit thee more.

Farewell gentle Reader.
Domini Buggans
carmen ENCOMIASTICON.
SI quis Romanas studeat cognosoere voces,
Gallia quosque sonos, Anglia quosque ferat:
Higgini ingenium fuluo protiosius auro,
Cunctas en vno codice praebet opes.
Prodit and hinc triplici titulo liber iste vocatus
Triglottos, linguis sedulitate tribus.
Hunc decet amplecti studiosos semper alumnos,
Cuius in amplexu docta Minerua cubat.
Hunc decet amplecti pueros, iuuenesque senesque,
Cortice sub cuius munera tanta latent.
Hunc decet amplecti cupidis iunctisque lacerti^
frigida Parnassi quos tulit aura viros.
Discite qui sapitis, ter doctas discite voces
Galli, Britanides, Romulidesque simul.
Higgino et tanti precium praebete laboris,
Aeternas lauds, perpetuumque decus.
Hoc quoque continua pariter prorumpite voce,
Proueniat meritis gloria vera suis.
Henrici Torquati
carmen in laudem Higgini operis.
SI cupis exiguo doctum parare libellum
Aere: puer celeres hac move quaeso pedes.
Trinas quas vno conclusit codice linguas
Solers Higinus: parua moneta dabit.
Parua moneta dabit, quicquid Romana vetustas:
Quicquid et Herculeo venit ab ore, dabit.
Albia quodque tulit, (nomen mutata yetustum)
Hic breuiter codex ingeniosus habet.
Hunc si tu voluas studijs intenta iuuentus,
Tunc feres ex isto commoda magna libro.
Inque tribus semper doctus versabere linguis,
Singula si teneas quae dabit iste liber.
Huloeti succos nanque emendauit acerbos,
Auxit and innumeris vocibus iste librum.
Carmina,
A. W. Oxoniensis.
VT saeuo fortis defendit Mart Camillus,
Impite Senonum terribili patriam:
Vt clarus miseram seruauit Tullius vrbim,
Ornasset tetras cum Catilina faces:
Higginus linguam nobis sic reddidit Anglis,
ac pepulit patriae barbara verba suae.
Hoc duce barbaries pulsa est, nunc Anglia gaudet,
Totaque Castalijs plena rigatur aquis.
Perlegat hunc igitur, Parnassi scandere culmen,
Musarum and seeds quisquis adire velit.
E. B.
Carmen Sapphicum
VIn' leui lector precio libellum,
Atque thesaurum potius parare,
Qui Midae gazas superat, Luculli
Diuitis aurum?
Ac docens te triplice sensa mentis
Eloqui lingua: eximias phrasesque
Qui tibi ignaro Copiae ministrat
Diuite cornu?
Hunc Higgini suscipe, volue, quaere
Sum, compara, lege, verte librum,
Magna nam vobis minimo labor
Commoda reddet.
Thomas Churchyard
Give learning laud, that burns like lamp, in dim and darkest soyles,
Which precious Pearl shall show it self, and craves no forged foyles.
And where does knowledge favor find, but where some virtues budde.
Her fountain runs with gushing streams, and flows like Nilus floudde.
Her foes are froward minded men, whose blindness cannot see,
The blasinge beams and skillful arts, of those that learned be.
We read that Kings gave place and fame, to Poets grave and sage,
Dionisius honored Plato.
And such as could set forth good books, were likte in every age.
A tyrante honorde Plato sure, and with a triumph great,
Vespasianus a covetous king, gave. 1500. crowns yearly, to the master of
every schole.
Did fetch him in, and made the man, to sit near Princes seat.
An other king whose greedye mind, like glutton gapte for goulde,
To make good schools and scholars both, great treasure give he would.
To every master that did teach, lo how a sparinge hand
Did flinge forth fruit, in hope thereby, to frame a learned land.
A king whose conquest claymde renown, for one bare work did yeilde,
More crowns of goulde then in one Camp, are men to fight a field.
Alexander.
The self same Prince laid Homers works, as pillowe for his hedde,
And for companion did he hold, this book about his bed.
Caesar's Com.
The fame that mighty Caesar gave, to learned men is known,
Who in his life at leisure wrote, a volume of his own.
These proves are to be found, in Chelidonius Tigurinus Institution of Princes.
Of Kings and Captains could I show, a swarm which knowledge sought.
Whose works record what virtues rare, may rest in noble thought.
Then think the best you lookers on, of those that takes pains,
Or prease in place and play a part, to show your cunninge veins.
An idle head may soon find fault, but that no glory is
Till better skill, with judgment deep, attempt to mende the miss.
The labrer does deserve his hyer, a writers chief reward
Is that with comlye quiet words, his works ye do regard.
Thus book pass on, through every hand that can thee gentlye use,
The wrangling head, and hateful house, thou freelye may refuse.
Since he meant well that set thee forth, where calmye winds do blow,
Repair and bid thy master seek, in place where he shall go
A patron that does learning love, and hates no gift of grace,
To keep this book from busy brains, that would this work deface.
Which work well wayed the wise will like, and such as learning crave,
From Scholars pen and Printers shop, a schole of rules may have.
For French and Latin as it faules, and as men list to look,
I say no more the work it self, shall serve to praise the book.
FINIS.
A. ANTE A.
A The first of all the letters, and has in our English tongue small
signification, because it is no perfect word, yet it is a note whereby the
substantive is known from ye adjective, as thus, A man, A woman, etc. which
in the latin tongue is without any such note, for the latin substantive is
known by article and termination, Homo, Mulier, etc. neither is the latin
article expressed, but in demo^stration or speaking of, as, hic vir, this man.
And in the latin speech. A. is a preposition (serving to the ablative case) of
diverse significations. As in these phrases of speaking. Ouercommed by Scipio. A
Scipione victus, Vaincu par Scipio. or thus, vapulauit a praeceptore, he was
beaten by his master, Il a este batu du maistre, ou par le maistre. It is the
same that with, As to begin his souper with drink, A potu coenam incipere.
Commencer son souper par boire. Also, since, or from, As from, or since the
beginning, A principio, Ab initio, Des le commencement, de puis le
co^mencement. From his childhoode, or since he was a little one, A prima
adolescentia, Ab ineunte adolescentia, Ab adolesce^tia, Ab adolesce^tulo, Ab
ineunte aetate, Ab initio aetatis, A primis cunabilis, A prima aetate, Ab
incunabilis, A pueritia, Ab infantibus, Ab infa^tia prima, Ab iuue^ta, A
paruulo, A puero, A pueris, A tenero, A teneris, A paruis, A puero paruulo, A
pusillo puero, A teneris vnguiculis, Des, ou de puis l'enfance. And A, is as
much as after, After dinner. A prandio, Apres disner. After supper, A coena,
Apres souper. The second after the king, A rege secundus, Le second apres le
roy. This letter A. was the letter of safegarde amongste the Romans, as with
us it is used that those which are saved by their book, have a letter (though
not the same) burned in their hand, A note of ye princes mercy (in hope of
repentance) and mark whereby they are known if they itterate the offense. An
other thing is to be noted, that as often as, A. comes before a word that
begins with a consonant, it is simple as in the example before, but if the
word followyng begin with a vowel it must be compounde with N. As an age, an
army, and not a age, a army, and so is it in the latin tongue, for we join B.
thereunto, and diverse other letters, both in apposition, and in composition, on
consideration of the letters followyng, for we say A principio, because P. is
a consonant, and ab initio, for that I. is a vowell. A. also by him self was
written for Augustus. Aulus. and for diverse other proper names of noble men.
And A. is the first of all the vowelles. A. A. A. Is the primative speech, or
natural voice of a Baby, or crying of an Infant, Lallatio. onis, and Lallo.
as, ang. to speak like a Baby. The Greeks approaching more near the English,
then the Latin, say Babazin, which (made a lattin word) is Babare. The opinion
of some is: it to be the lulling, singing, or babbling of the Nowrice: when she
tendreth to the child her breaste or dugge, or when she will have him to
sleep. Verbum fictitium, vel de sono tractum. But Pers. Satyr. 3. has
Lallare, to suck.

Et similis regum pueris pappare minutum
Poscis, and iratus mammae lallare recusas.
And like the princely infantes thou desire little pappe,
And angry leauste to lall her dugge that lulles thee in her lap.
Aad a river in Brabant, Fluuius Brabantiae, Fleuue ou riuiere. etc. Aar, a
river in Valesia, Fluuius Valesiae. Fleuue ou riuiere. etc. Aaron, vel Aharon
the son of Amram: and brother to Moses, signifying the mountain of
fortitude, or strong hill. He was the first bishop of the Jews. Aaron, id est
mons vel montanus. Vne montaigne.
A. ANTE B.
ABach, the name of a City in Bauaria, Ciuitas Bauariae, La Bourgeosie de
Bauiere. Abacuck, a name of one of the Prophets, it signifies embracing,
Amplexatio, onis, Embrassement. He prophesied and lamented the taking of
Jerusalem by Nabugodonosor. This Habacuck, ( as he was carrying meat and
drink to his harvest men) was taken up therewith, and carried into Babylon by
an Angel of the Lord, into a dongeon where Daniell the Prophet, was put to
be devoured by Lions, and was carried home again the same day, as in the last
end, of the last chapter of Daniels prophecy may be seen. Abacuc the Caspian
and Hyrcan Sea. Mare Caspium and Hyrcanum, La mer d'Abacuc ou Abacuth. Abandon,
to leave, or forsake, Desero, is, ui, ere. Abandonner. Abandoned, left, or
forsaken, Desertus, ta, tum. Abandonne. Abandoner, leauer, or forsaker,
Desertor, toris, Qui delaisse and abandonne. Abandoning, leaving or forsaking,
Desertio, defectio, destitutio, Abandonnement. Abase, put down, or to humble
one, Deprimo, demitto, humilio, deijcio, Abbaisser. Abasede or put down.
Deiectus, demissus, depressus, Abbaisse. Abasement or depressio^ of the voice,
Submissio vocis, Abbaissement de voix. Abandon chastity. Pudicitiam
prostituere. Abandon one to all sorrow, as to let him to be possed with all
heaviness and care. Frenos dolori remittere. S'abandonner a toute tristesse.
Abashe, or make abashed. (^) Consterno, as, naui, nare, natum. Obstupefacio,
cis, facere, factum. Stupefacio, cis. Espouanter, estonner. Abashed.
Consternatus, a, um. Demissus, a, um. Deterritus, a, um. Obstupidus, a, um.
Stupefactus, a, um. Stupidus, a, um. Verecundus, a, um. Espouante. Abashed
nothing at all. Frontosus, a, um. Eshonte. Abashed to be. Brupeo, ere.
Obstupeo, es. Obstupesco, scis. Stupefio, fis. Stupeo, ere. Stupesco, scis.
Estre tout estonne, espouante. Abashme^t. Consternatio, onis. Verecundia, ae.
Honte. Abate. Demo, is, psi. Diminuo, is. Hostio, iui. Leuo as, Oster de
quelque chose, regner. Abate courage. Animos comprimere, vel retardare,
Demittere animum. Procello, is, culi. Abbaisser son courage and Appaiser. Abate
pride. Supercillium ponere. Idem. Abate the sum total. Dimittere de summa.
Rabbattre de la sum. Abating. Diminutio, onis. Appetissement. Abbot, Abba,
Coenobiarcha, Hetaeriarcha, Antistes, Abbas, Abbatis. Abbe. Abbot eats, or
banqueteth with his couente. Hetoeriarcha epulatur cum sodalibus. L'Abbe mange
en convent. Abbotesse or Abbess, she that has the governance of a religious
house. Antistes, vel Antistita, Abbatissa. Abbess. Abbaye or religious house
of monks and friars, Antistitium, Coenobiarchia, Hetaeriarchia, Abbatia.
Abbaye. Abbot, which signifies (at Thassirians) father. Abbas, atis. Abbe. A.
B. C. a book for children, called Abcedarium, rij. Alphabetum, ti. Et
Abcedarius. Vel abecedarius, angl. he that makes a book of the order of, A. B.
C. vide Alphabete. Abdenago, a man also named Azarias, interpreted the servant
of brightness. Seruus claritatis. look Azarias. Abdias, a prophets name,
interpreted the servant of our lord. Seruus domini. Abdicate or put away.
Abdico, cas, caui, care. Abastardir. Abdicate, or put away his son. Abdicare
filium. Iecter son fills horse de la maison. Abdicate, Abolishe, or put down a
law. Abdicare legem, Abrogare legem. Abolir la loy. Abdicate, for refuse.
Abdicare pro respuere. Refuser. Abdication, as when the father does wyllingly
exclude the son from his enheritaunce. Abdicatio, onis. Abastardisement.
Renoncement. Abel, the second son of Adam, and brother to Cain. the first
martyr that ever was, he was slain by his brother, as Gene. 4. witnesses.
Abominable. Abhominabilis, le. Detestabilis, le. Obscoenus, a, ura.
Teterrimus. a. um. Detestable. Abhominably. Tetre. Detestablement. onis.
Abomination. Abomination. Oscis, propudium, ij. Abhominatio Abhomined.
Fastiditus, a, um. Abhomine, deteste. Abhor. Abominor. aris. Aspernor, aris.
Auersor, aris, Detestor, aris. Execro, cras. Execror, raris. Fastidio, dis.
Inhorreo, es. Inhorresco, scis. Nauseo, as. Vatesco, scis. Detester, Auoir en
horror en abomination, Abominer. Abhorred. Abominatus, a, um. Aspernatus, a,
um. Aduersatus, a, um. Detestatus, a, um. Execratus, a, um. Fastiditus, a, um.
Abomine, Deteste. Abhorring. Detestatio, onis. Nausea, ae. Abominatio, onis.

A. ANTE. C.
ACan, a name in the Bible, signifieng tribulation. Tribulatio, onis.
Troublement. Acanthium, An herb or bushe callid (by master Turner) Ote
thistell, or Cotto^ thistell, of other Gum thistell. Acanthion, sieve
acanthium, Acanthij. Neut. genesis Herb semblable a vne autre nommee bedegar.
Acca Laurentia, the wife of Faustulus, a shepeherde, which for that she was a
notable harlot, was named Lupa, for her rapacitie and evil life, and so are al
harlottes named Lupae, wolves and the brothell house or stews, Lupanar, is,
vel Lupanarium. Un bordeau. This Acca nourished and kept Remus and Romulus,
being cast out to be devoured on the banks of Tyber, which after were the
buylders of Rome, of this comes that fable that Remus and Romulus, were
nourished by a Wolf, for this cause and to her honor, were the feasts in
Rome instituted, which they called Laurentinalia. Accenting or true pronou^cing
or reading. Acce^tus, tus, tui. apud Graecos prosodia dicta, a Latinis tenor,
and tonus, quos veteres nunc Moderamenta, nunc voculationes appellarint. Inde
sunt tres. Acutus, grauis, and circumflexus. De hiisce vide Priscianum, and
Tortellium. Prosodia, ae. idem. Accent, elevation ou abaissement de la voix.

against the Thebanes, with great slaughter of his soldiers, and no victory.
Adrastus also was son of Percosius (a man of excellent knowledge in the
science of divination) and had to brother Amphius. This Percosius being a very
friend to the Troyanes, and perceiving the unfortunate end of his sons
eminente: if they went to war, he persuaded them not to go, but they (neither
obeying his commandment, nor believing his council) went, and were both
slain. Of one of these comes that proverb, Adrastia Nemisis, vel Adrasti
Nemisis. Ill luck of Adrastus. It may be prouerbially englished, pride will
have a fall. Adrianus, an Emperor so called, in English Adrian. Advance.

Respondeo, es. Respondre. Agamemnon, son to Atreus, and king of Mycene, was
captain general in the siege of Troy, and after (his return from thence)
was slain by Aegisthus through the council of his wife Clytemnestra: and she
(with her aduoutrer Aegisthus) was rewarded for murder and adultrie by her own
son Orestes, who reue^ging the death of his father Agamemnon, slew them
both. Agonae a noble woman, which slew her son Penthea, for his
lasciuiousnes. A notable example of a Panime Lady, for her virtuous act,
which willed rather the death of her natural son, then his vicious life.
Other affirm that Agaue ( whom our Author names Agonae) was very vicious
and cruel: and her son Pe^theus was a man given to all abstinencie, in so
much that he would not go to that filthy feast of Bacchus, (which was kept in
the night, with all furiousness, vice and abomination) neither would have
suffered the women to go: for which cause in the night, when they were drunk:
they tore him in pieces. Wherefore I could not well allow the former history
were not the meaning so modeste. Agaue, es. f. g. Agar, handmayde to Sara, on
whom Abraham begat Ismael, and is interpreted. Aduena. Estrangier. Agaricke,

A. ANTE. H.
AH, an interiection, or sudden voice uttered, whereby some hasty motion is
signified. as in laughter. Ter. Ah ah ah, perij defessa iam misera sum te
ridendo. Ah, ah, I die poor weary wenche In laughing the to scorn. Or in
rebukyng, or correcting him self, as Vergil. Ah Corydon Corydon quae te
dementia cepit. Alas why Corydon in love, What madness has thee caught. In
pytie, or taking compassion: As Vergil. Hic inter densas corylos modo namque
gemellos spem gregis: Ah silice in nuda connixa reliquit. For here but late
twen haselles thick, two twins she eande at ones: My hope of herd, allasse
she left on naked flinty stones. Ah ah, an interiection of sighing as we use:
oughe, oghe. Quand on sospire. Ah, an interiection when we be angry with some
body, and blame him as in Terent. Ah tantamne rem tam negligenter agere? Alas
does he so great a thing with negligence devise? Ahazias, called also Ochosias,
the nynthe king of Judah, reigned one year, and was slain for Idolatie.
Aherna, a city of Hetruuia, Plin. Ahias, the name of a prophet, in the third
book of the kings, and.xi. chapter. Ahinas, a hye priest in Judea the year
before Christ. 986.
A. ANTE. I.
Ajax, was the name of two of the most worthy warriors amongst the
Gretians, of which the one was surnamed Telamonius, next to Achilles in
fortitude, he fought with Hector for the victory, and had obtained it: had not
night ended the combat, for which cause he returned with a sword given him
by Hector, and he likewise gave Hector a sword gyrdle, which gifts (as the
end declared) were both their destructions. For Achilles drew the body of
Hector with that gyrdle round about the walls of Troy at a horses tail, and
after slew him in the sight of his father Priamus. And Ajax when Achilles was
slain, striuinge with Ulysses for his armoure, and being overcome by the
eloquence of his adversary, fell mad and slew brute beasts, thinking them
to be Ulysses and Atridas, but when he came to him self again, and perceived
how he was deluded, and failed in his purpose, being stricken with great
doloure and grief, he slew him self in a desert place: with that same sword
which Hector gave him. There was an other Ajax ( surnamed Oileus) king of
Locris, swyft of foot, cunninge in throwyng the darte, and showed many
examples of fortitude at the siege of Troy, but when it was destroyed, he
deflowrid the virgyn Cassandra in the temple of Minerua, wherefore the goddess
being moved to wrath, fyerid and drowned him and his ships with lightning, as
he was sailing into Crete after the Troyane wars were ended. Ajax, cis. m. g.

Albion, the ancient name of this I Will, which conteyneth England and
Scotland. Some say Olbion, the doubt whereof I refer to the
Historiographers, etc. Alcoron, Mahumettes book. Alcoranum, ni. A book of
most shameful, detestable, blasphemous and horrible lies, the Turks laws
and ceremonies, made by Mahumete. Alcyon, birds which do bread in the mids
of winter, when the seas be most troublous. Alcedines, number. Alcyones, number. A
small bird which makes her nest upon the sands of the sea, and then it is a
token and a sign of fair wether. Un petit oiseau qui fait son nid sur l' eau
de la mer, and lors est sign de beau temps, etc. S. Alder tree. Alnus, ni.

Then first the floudes began to bear, the holowed Alder trees.
Aldermen of a city. Senatores, Patres, Viri seniores, vel ab aetate, vel a
curae similitudine. Les senateurs ou conseilliers. Alecoste, cost, or
costemarie, an herb named in latin. Menta Romana, Menta Saracenica, vel Sali^a
Romana. Ale, or beer. Ceruisia, ae. Zythum. De la biere. Ale new, or new ale
in the corns. Mustum, ti. Alehouse, or an Inn, a house where each geste may
have vitayles and lodging for money. Caupona, Diuersorium, Stabulun^, Taberna,
Diuersoria, Pandochaeum, Domus viatoribus mercede patens. Hostelerie, logis.
Aleknight, a tippler, a tospote, a quaffer, a quasser, a renspitcher, a

She that loves to make a mess at the alehouse. Yurongne, buueur, compaignon a
boire and a yurongner, compotrix. Compaigne a boire and a yurongner. Alehouse,
or tavern, where riote is exercised and maintained. Popina, ae. and Popinalis,

Aley to walk in. Ambulacrum, cri. Deambulatorium* rij. Hypoethra, ae.
Topiarium, rij. Pourmenoir. Aley maker. Topiarius, rij. Iardinier. Aley making,
or that faculty or occupation. Topiaria. Alexander the great, was son of
Philip king of Macedony. And scoller to Aristotell, prince of Philosophers. A
man of great wit, learning, and fortitude, for at the age of twenty years he
took on him the conqueste of all the world, with an army prepared by his
father, which was of 32000. footmen, and.4500. horsemen, having no captain
under the age of.60. years, that not in flight, but in fight, they should
put the hope of victory, and so with valiant courage did set upon the whole
world, and had always the victory, for in the first year he was saluted
Emperor of Greece. He passed over into Asia, at Granicus, overcame the
Persia^s, took Sardis, and Halicarnassus, subduing all the lands unto Phrigia,
and obtaining all the regions as far as Cilicia. He wanne Egypt, and buylt
Alexandria, he took Babylon, subdued Hyrcania, he obtained Paropamissa, builded
an other Alexandria upon the mountain Caucasus, he caused Mophis ye king of
India, to submit him self to him, and subdued ye Cosseans. And when he had
reigned.12. years, to the great peril of his soldiers and destruction of
many nations, in vanquishyng the East part of the world (and unvanquished) He
supposed in his mind he had also overcome all the Weste, through which being
blown up with pride, he caused him self to be named king of all lands, and
lord of the whole world, and sent forth his navy into the East Ocea^, to
search if there were any other world to conquer, but retourning home, in his
greatest glory, at Babylon abiding for the Ambassadors of all countries, he
was poisoned by his own men, for cruelty, dronkenesse, and tyranny.

been three kinds, the one Catinae, which is boiled or sodden. The other
Scissile, or Plume, which is naturally stony: and yet may be altered with a
struck. The third Zucharinu^, made with alume relented, rosewater, and the
white of eggs like a sugar lofe, the which harlottes and strumpettes do
commonly use to painte their faces and visages with, to deceive men: But God
grant they deceive not them selves. It is named in French. Alun. Alysson, an
herb also called Healebyte, because it heals the biting of mad dogs, and
it is thought to be wholesome to hang about the house against inchaunting. And
bound about in a lynnen cloth, it drives away the diseases of cattle: some
think that only by sight thereof, the biting of a mad dog is cured.

AMabilitie or love. Amabilitas, tatis, f. g. Amor, Amiablete. Amadoca, a
city of Sarmatia in Europe. Amalchium, the north part of the Ocean sea.
Amalthea, was nource of Jupiter, and daughter of Melissus King of Crete, she
and her sister Melissa, nourished Jupiter with Goats milk and honey. Amalech,
a name (in the Bible) of a king of Syria, which slew many of the children of
Israel as they returned out of Egipte, and may be interpreted a licking or
striking people. Populus lambens. Read Exodus. 17. Deuteronomy. 25. Number. 14. 1. Re.
14. Of the Amalachites and of their king, his life and his death. Amaranus, was
father to Moses. Amorous, or full of love. Amabundus, a, um. Fort amoureux.
Amorous letters. Amatorie scripta epistola. Epistre escripte d' un style
amoureux. Amorously. Blande, Amice, Placide. Amoureusement. Amassed, or abashed.
Attonitus, a, um. Obstupidus, a, um. Estonne. Amassed to be. Obstupeo, es.
Obstupesco, scis. Stupeo es. Stupesco, scis. Torpeo, es. Estre toute estonne.
Amassed, or astonished to make. Obstupefacio, cis. Stupefacio, cis. Conturbo, as.
Horrifico, cas. Obtundo, dis. Estonner. Amasedly. Attonite. A l'esbahi. Amasis,
a king of Egypt, whose tomb was one of the pyramides, a curias and
unspeakable costly peace of work, built high in form of a steple, and so
small vpwardes that it was almost impossible to think it could be so wroughte
by any invention of man. In the botome of these were the sepulchers of kings.
This Amasis made a ^awe that all his subjects should yearly give an account
of their living, by what trade and gaynes they maintained their estate, which
who so did not, was put to death: and Solon brought thence this law to the
Athenians. Amazones, women of Scithia, which killed al their male children,
and did cut of their right pappes, because they ne would be hindered of the
casting of their darts, or Iauellins. Vnde Amazonicus, a, um, and Amazonius,
aum. Perteining to the nature of Amazones.

Ambassade or office of an Ambassador. Legatio, onis. L'office d' ambassade.
Which was not sent in this ambassade that he is in, by his countremen. Qui
hanc ipsam legationem, quam habet non accepit a suis ciuibus. Le quel n'a pas
este enuoye en ambassade par ses citoyens.

Ambassitor, oris. Legatus, ti. Pater patratus, tus. Ambassadeur, legate.

d'honeur ou de gloire. Whose ambition is to manifest. Ambitionis manifestus

Ambitious, or importunate request, suit or labor. Ambitio, co^tentio and

cis. Amender, corriger, ou emender. Amend a falte. Talum reponere. Amender.

Amiable, fair, pleasant, beautiful, dlectable, eligante to the eye,

Amiable to sight, or pleasant to behold. Venustum ad aspectum. Beau a veoir.
Amiable countenance, or speech. Venustas, it is. Amabilitas, tatis. Amiablete.

Co^suetudo, Necessitudo. Amity. Amity and firm friendship. Firma amicitia.
Amity qui ne vary point. Amity, is necessary among good men. Amicitia inter
bonos, vel bonis necessaria est. Amity est necessaire parmi gents de bien.
Amity variable. Desultoria amicitia. hoc est, identidem euarians, Inconstans,
Non constans. Amity variable. Amity and pure love is not cold. No^
refrixitamor. L'amitie n' est point refroidie. Amity, and true faithful
frendshippe, goes through all nations. Serpit per omnium vitam amicitia.
L'amitie sespand enter toutes gens. Amity great, or faithful, firm, sure and
constant friendship. Coniu^ctio, onis. Grande amity. Amity ancient, durable
or of long time. Magna vetustas and consuetudo. Ancienne amity. Amities
feigned, faynte, coulered, couerte, and (as we say) from the tethe forward.
Fucosae amicitiae. Amitiez fainctes and couuertes. Amities of great show and
no prouffe. Amicitiae ambitiosae. Amity de trop grande monstre and appearance
sans effect. The bands of amity being kept. Saluo iure amicitiae. Sauf le
droict d'amitie.

Amomum, is a small bushe, about the quantity of a man's hand, like a cluster
of grapes foulden into him self like sticks of wode one within an other,
after the manner of a net, and it has a sweet savor, it is named in latin,
Amomu^, rosa Hierosolymitana, seu beatae Mariae, sieve Hierichuntis, it grows
in Assyria, as it seems by this verse of Verg. -- Assyrium vulgo nascetur
Amomum.
Amomum sweet th'Assyrian shroube shall spring in every place.
Among, or amongst. Inter. Parmi. Amongst his cups, or as he was a
tippling, bibbing, bowling, swilling or drinking. Inter vina, inter pocula. En
beuuant. Amongst which we are. In queis sumus. Enter lesquels nous sommes.
Amongst good men. In bonis. Intre les gens de bien. Amongst princes, rulers
or great men. In principibus vel inter principes. Enter les plus grans.
Amongst whom, or amongst which. In queis vel in quibus. Intre lesquels.
Amongst our selves let us play, or let us play alone by our selves together.
Inter nos ludamus. Iouons enter nous. Among, all.(?) Commune, Medium, Vulgo.
Par tout. Amongst good men. In bonis. A gents de bien. (^) And note that this
phrase among may be referred to few, or one. etc. And also that amongst may be
referred to the more or greater part.

Amoue, or put of. Amoueo, es. Apello, lis, ulsum. vide plus. Put away and
remove. Ample, large, abundant, wide, great, etc. Amplus, ampla, amplum.
Adiectiuum. Ample, large, and de grande enstendue, de touts costez. Amplefie,
to enlarge, to augment, to make better, to extolle and magnify. Amplifico,
cas, caui, care. Amplier, fair ample, eslargir and aggrandi^, amplifier.
Amplify and to increase. Augere, Ampliare. Amplier, Amplifier. Amplify and
increase the greatness of ones honor. Amplitudinem ac gloriam alicuius
amplificare. Augmenter and accroistre. Amplify, and to increase ones
substance and honor. Amplificare and ornare aliquem Luy donner accroissement
en bien and honneur. Amplify, or inhaunce the price. Pretium amplificare.
Encherir, mettre enchere. Amplify, augmente or increase his goods. Rem
familiarem amplificare. Augmenter son bien. Amplificate, or increase the common
wealth. Amplificare rempublicam. Accroister le bien public. Amplified, or
augmented. Amplificatus, ta, tum. Parti. Auctus, ta, tum. Ampliatus, ta, tum.
Amply and augmente. Amplifier, or one that does enlarge. Auctor, Amplificator,
toris, Ampliateur and augmentateur. Amplification, or the augmenting, or
increasing of any thing. Amplificatio, onis. Accretio, tionis. Accrementum, ti.
Ampliation. Ampully, largly, nobly, with great magnificence. Amplifice,
aduerbium. Magnifiquement.
A. ANTE. N.
ANa, a river in Spain, that divides Granato from Portugale. Fluuius
Hispaniae. Anabaptists, a sort of heretics of late time in Germany, about
the year of our Lord God. 1524. and the.xv. year of king Henry the eight.
Anabaptistae, arum. Which signify rebaptisoures. Anacharsis was a
Philosopher: which said that laws were made like cobwebbes, for the small
flies were tied, but great flies brake away. This man did also inuente the
potters wheale. Ananias, interpreted the cloud or divination of the Lord, it
was the name of one of the three Hebrew children that were put into a furnace of
fire, at the commandment of Nabugodonosor, and were delivered by the mighty
power of God. Of this read the third of Daniel. An other Ananias is spoken of
in the fifthe of the Acts of the Apostles, which dissembled with God, and was
at the Apostel saint Peter his words stricken dead, and so was his wife Saphira
for the same offense. Also there was one of this name (who was endued with
great virtue) a disciple of our Savior Christ, which restored Saint Paul to
his sight by the commandment of God, and Christened him, as in the ninth of
the Acts. It was also the name of a bishop, that sat in judgment when
Saint Paul was examined, and bade them that stood by, stryke him on the mouth,
because he spoke the word of God. Acts. 23. Ananias, ae. nomen viri.
Anaxagoras, a famous Philosopher of noble blood, which leaving his patrimony
to his kynsfolke, gave him self only to the study of phylosophie: in so much
that he was utterly negligente of worldly affairs, and private businesses.
Being asked of one if he had no care of his country, he answered, truly I
have great care of my country, and therewith pointed upward to the heavens.
Anaxagoras, ae, nome^ philosophi clarissimi. Anotomie, or cutting up of bodies
(to se the parts within) thereby to know, and deem, the causes of
infirmities, or other passions pertayninge to each part. Anatomia, ae, vel
Anatome, es. Incision, Anatomy. Anatomiste, or one that is scilfull in cutting
up an Anatomy. Anatomicus, Anatomiae peritus. Anatomiste, Anatomique,
Anatomien. Anaxarchus a Philosopher, being contused or stamped in a mort^r with
Iron pestles: spoke in the time of his tormente to Nicrocreon his officers
these words. Beat on, Beat Anaxarchus wyndbagge. For Anaxarchus you beat
not. Anaximander a Philosopher, who first invented the Nauticall, or shipmans
compass which shipmen do use. And made first the Sphere. Anchises, father to
Aeneas. Anchor. Anchora, ae. Ancre a retenir les nauires. Vnde Anchorarius, a,
um. ang. Pertaining to an Ancker. and Anchoralis, le. Qui sert a l'ancre.

Ancklebone. Malleolus, li. Le plus bas de la iambe. Anckle of the leg.
Talus, li. Talon. And. Ac, Et, que, Con. cop. Et. And to tell you the truth,
you are to to hard, I can not praise or commend it. Et quod dicendum nunc
si^t,
Tu quoque perparce nimium, non laudo.
Pour dire la verire etc.
And that you now angry, think with your self. Et quod nunc tute tecum iratus
cogitas etc. Quant a ce que etc. And I fear not. Ac non vereor. Et sin'ay pas
paour. And first of all. Ac primum. Et tout primierement. And behold, see. Ac
vide. Et mais voy. And do you see? Atque vides? Le vois tu pas? And in deed I
confess, it has happened by right as I deserved. Atque id confiteor iure
obtigisse. Et certes a bon droict, il est bien employe qu' ainsi me soit
aduenu. And I speak not of that. Atque id omitto etc. Or ne dis ie rien de ce.
And in deed why go not I in? Atque adeo autem cur non egomet introeo? Mais, ou
and mais voirement que n'entre ie? And lo yonder he is. Atque eccum. Mais le
voyla luymesme. And in very deed that is it, or you have hit the nail on the
head. Atque aedepol, ea res est. Et ie vous iure, ou c' est cela sans point de
fault. And also, and that is more, and further, and again. Atque etiam. Et
aussi. And so. Atque ita. Et ainsi. And so not long after. Neque ita multo
post. Non pas fort long temps apres. And therefore. Itaque. Parquoy, par ainsi.
Andiron, or Brandiron. Andela, ae. Andena, ae. Heperpyrgium, ij. Alaria,
Sustentaculum ferreum. Andrewe, one of the.xii. Apostles, brother to Peter.
Andreas, ae. Androgini, which been people of both kinds, both man and woman.
Qui est masle and femelle. Andromache, Hectors wife. Andromede, the wife of
Perses a valiant man. Andwarpe, a town in Braband. Antuacutum, ti. Antuerpia.
Anduile, or stithe. Incus, cudis. Un enclume. Anduile worker. Incudo, onis.
Angew a contry in France. Andagauia, ae. Angiers. And the people there been
called Andes.

Angelica, it is the name of an herb, whereof are two kinds, the one is
called imperial or Angelica, and the other is called Lungworte. Angelica, cae.
Angelique. Angle, or corner of any thing. Angulus, li. Angle. Whereof comes

Anguishe of the body or mind. Angor, goris. Angoisse. Any. Quidam, sing.

Is there any man in the world, so very a wretch as I? An quisquam gentium
est aeque miseratque ego? Ya il homme au monde aussi miserable etc.

etc.

If you prove that I have made any lie, kill me, Si quicquam mentitum inuenies,
occidito. Que in aye menti d' aucunne chose, etc.

Any thing. Quicquam, Quidpiam, Quelque chose. Any time. Vnquam. Quelque fois,

Quidpiam. Anna, an Hebrewe word, which signifies gracious, giving, piteful,
or resting: of this name have been many noble women. Ania, a Roman woman,
which after the death of her husband, said to such as counsaylled her to
mary again, these words. If I shall hap to have as good as I have had, I
will not be in fear to lose him. If I shall have an ill husband, what shall I
need after a good man to have a shrewe. Annexe together. Vnio, is. Vide plus,

Qui se sait chascun an. Annoye, or hurt. Noceo, es. Offendo, dis. Nuire.

It nothing at all annoyeth me. Nihil me laedit. Il ne me nuist en rien.

Actutum. Another. Alius. a, ud. Alter, ra, rum. Un autre. I report me to the
judgment of others, let other judge, I refer it to others arbitrament.
Aliorum sit iudicium. Ie m'en rapporte au judgment des autres.

One of us asks of another, or we one of us ask another. Alius alium
percontamur. Nous demandons l'vna l'autre.

Living one after one sort, and an other, after another. Alius alio more
viuentes. Viuants l' un d' vne sort, l'autre d'vne autre.

One subtle device, bringes out an other, or when thieves fall out, true men
come by their goods. Fallacia alia aliam trudit. Vne finesse affine l'autre.

One encouraging an other. Alius alium hortati. Les vns enhortoyent les autres.

One worse then an other. Alius alio nequior. Les vns pire que les autres.

He cast one from an other. Aliud alio dissipauit. Ila tout iecte, les vns ca,
les autres la.

One after one sort, an other after an other. Alius alio modo. L'vne en vne
maniere, l'autre en autre.

That is an other matter. Alia res est. C'est autre chose.

Another. Alius quisque. Un chascun. Another I, As my friend is my self, or an
other even as my self. Alter ego. Vnsecond moymesme. Un semblable a moy. To
live after an other manner or sort. Alieno more viuere. A la mode ou a la
guise d' autruy.

Another man's words or talk. Aliena oration. La parolle d' un autre. Another
man's matter. Aliena res. Chose d' autruy. Another time. Alias, Adu. temp. Un
autre temps. Another way or wise. Aliorsum. Autre lieu. Answer to agree, to
accord, to consent, to be like, equal or even, to appear or answer, when
one is calde to resemble like or be over right against. Respondeo, des, di,
sum, dear. Respondre. Answer to that I ask thee. Responde quod rogo. Respons
a ce que ie te demand. Answer one according to the constitutions of the law.
De iure respondere. Donner conseil and resolution des difficultez de droicta
ceulx qui vienent consulter. Answer, or give council, to all that come for
matters in the law. Ius civil public respondere. Consulter and donner
conseil a touts venants sur les poincts de droict. Answer, or purge him self
of crimes laid to his charge. Respondere criminibus. Se purger d' aucun cas
qu'on nous met a sus. Answer, and appear when they are called. Ad nomina
respondere. Comparoir au iour de la monstre. Answer nothing, neither appear
and answer. Non respondere. Fair default, ne comparoir point. Answer, and
pay his creditour at the time and day appointed. Ad tempus respondere, vel ad
diem, debtor dicitur. Cic. Payer ou satisfaire au iour nomme. Vide plus
Equal. Answer. Oraculum, li. Responsio, onis. Responsus, us. Folium, vt
Sibillae folium. Response. Answer, which is colorable, or feyned.
Obtendiculum, li. Un problem. Answer defensorie, to a rebuke. Apologia, ae.
Defensio, onis. Excusatio, onis. Apologismus, mi. Apology. Answer greatly
made. Antismos, antismus. * Answers of Idols or spirits. Sorts. Les oracles

as. Responsito. Subeo, is. Subijcio, cis. Suspicio, is. * Respondre. Answer an
a^^^n, or plaint. Dicere causam, Restipulor, aris. Restipuler. Ante, or
pismier. Formica, ae. Et formicula, ae. Dimi. angl. A little pismier. Fourmi.
Antes, that heap and gather graynes of corn. Frugilegae formicae. Qui
recueillent and amassent les grains de ble. That parteineth to Antes or

Antes pace. Gradus formicinus. Pas de fourmi. That is full of Antes, emetes,
or pismyers. Formicosus, sa, sum. Plein de fourmis.

Antems, whose author was Ionasius, archebyshop of Antiochia. Anno Christi.
109. Antiphonae, aru^. Anticlea, the name of Ulysses mother. Anticlea, eae.
Anticlus, one of the Greeks, which were enclosed in the horse, whereby Troy
was betrayed. Anticlus, cli. Anticyra, an Isle in Asia, where the herb
Eleborus grows, which purges Melancholy. Whereof this proverb grew,
spoken to a melancholic person. Nauiga ad Anticyras. Go sail to Anticyra. As
much as to say, pourge your Melancholy.

Antidicomaritae, a sect of heretics, whose author was Heluidius, which
affirmed that Mary had certain children by Joseph. Anno. 406. Antiochia. a
city in Siria. Antipodes, are those people which inhabit the other part of
the earth right against and under us. As Macrobius and Pliny witness. And yet
S. Augustine in the.9. chapter of his.16. book De ciuitate dei. And Lactantius
in the.24. chapter of his third book of Divine institutions, affirm such
fables to be fained and untrue, and to these does Lucretius agree in these
verses. Lib. i. Illi cum videant solemn, nos sydera noctis
cernere, and alternis nobiscum tempora caeli
Diuidere, and noctes pariles agitare diebus:
Sed vanus stolidis haec omnia parturit error.
When they do see the Sun, we may perceive the stars of night,
And even with us in course they have the heavenly times aright.
Eke equal nights with those do pass, when here the days be bright:
But error vain brought al these things, to blind the foolish sight.
Antipus, Antipodis vel Antipodos etc. Antipodes, Antipodum. Qui cheminent a
l'opposite de nous, leurs plant^s coutre les plants de noliz^ieds. Antiquiti^
Anteritas, it is. Antiquitas, tatis. Anciennete.
A. ANTE. P.

number of the soldiers apayred, worn, ab^ted, or diminished by scirmishes.

Amoindri, amenuise. Apayring, or rather abating. Attenuatio, onis. Diminution.

separate, a sunder. Also namely, specially. Seorsum, Seorsus, Seperatim,
Separate, Seperatius, Seperatissime. A part, a l'escart, separeement* en
particulier. I give you all hearty thanks, and namely, chiefly or specially to

Principalenunt.

I am of an other opinion then you are. Seorsum a tesenrio. Ie suis d' autre
opinion que tu n'es.

Aparteyne. Pertineo, es. Specto, as. Attineo, es. Appartenir. Apparteyneth, or
it belongs. Pertinet, impersonale. Il appartient. This malice or evil,
pertayneth rather to men, then to women. Magis haec malitia pertinet ad viros
quam ad mulieres. C'est plus par la malice des hommes* que des femmes.

Who is to be suspected of this naughty fact, or the suspicion hereof may
appertain to him. Ad que^ suspitio maleficij pertineat. Sur qui chet le
souspecon, qui est souspeconne de ceste meschancete.

Apertayneth, or it belongs to the matter. Pertinet ad rem. Cela appartient a
l'affaire, est pertinent a l'affaire. Apartayneth, or it belongs to the
common wealth. Pe^tinet ad Rempub. Cela appartient a la republiqne, concern
l'utilite public. Apartaineth, it belongs, touches, avails, is
convenient or besemeth. Pertinet, Attinet impersonale. Il appartient. What
avails it us to know. Quid attinet nos scire. Qu'auons nous a fair de le
scauoir.

Apartayneth not, or it is not needful to speak of the agreement or accord.
Nihil attinet de assensione omnino loqui. Il n'est point de besoing. Ape.

A. ANTE R.
ARabia is a great part of Asia, between Judea and Egypt: and it is divided
into three parts, whereof the first is called happy, the second stony, and
the third deserte. Arabia pars Asiae, inter Iudaeam and Aegiptum, est autem
triplex, vna foelix, altera petraea, tertia, deserta. Arabie, est un grand pais
d'Asie le maieur situe enter Iudee and Egypt. Ceste Arabie est deuisee en trois
parties, dond la premiere est dicte heureuse, la second pierreuse, and la
tierce deserte. Arabian, one that dwells in Arabia. Arabs, Arabis. Arabe, ou
qui est d'Arabie. Et Arabicus, ca, cu^. Of Arabia. Arachne, the name of a
woman, which first invented spinning of lynnen, and making of nets, which
as the Poets feign, was (for co^tending with Pallas) transformed into a
spider. Ouidius. 6. Met. Aracynthus, a mountain in Boetia in Greece, also in
Athens, in Arcadie or Acarnanie, As Verg. Canto, quae solitus, si qua^do
arme^ta vocabat.
Amphion Dircaeus in Actaeo Aracyntho.
If ever he his heard did call,
So use I for to sing:
As erste on Aracynthus side
Did Amphion Thaeban king.
Aram, yerbum Hebraicum. Abraham his brother. Arbiter, or friendly equal Judge
among friends, on one that in cases of controversy will deal uprightly, or is
thought to be such a one as will do for the contentation of both parties as
far as equity and right requires. Disceptator domesticus, Arbiter ex
co^promisso, Co^promissarius. Sequester. Arbitre esleu par les parties, and
amiable compositeur. To take an Arbiter or Judge in any controversy. Sumere
Iudicem de re aliqua, Arbitrum capere, sieve adhibere. Prendre un Arbitre.

Submit him self, or his cause, to Arbiters or to judgment. Arbitrium
defer, Far iudicem, Causam arbitris permittere, non recusare. Offrir que le
process se vuide par arbitres.

Two Arbiters are so chosen, that if the case so require, they may adioyne,
take or choose the third to them. Arbitri, duo ita lecti, vt si ita res tulerit,
tertium sibi cooptent. Deux arbitres accordez auec puissance d'en prendre un
tiers, S'il y eschet.

l'Arbitre. Arbiter or Judge, in mean matters, or in things of no great value.

Arbitrarius, ia, ium. Chose qui est subject a l'arbitrage de l'Arbitre.

Amener raisons and conjectures pour prouuer quelque chose. Argument or reason.
Argumentum, ti. Hypothesis. Argument, raison. Argument of a commody, tragedy,
or such like. Embolium, lii. Argument. Argument to the contrary of an
objection, called a refutation or replication. Refutatio, nis. Confutation.
Argument, full of deceit and subtlety. Stropha, Strophae. Finesse, ou subtle
moyen, ruze. Argument, which on every side taunteth him to whom it is
objected. Dilemma, it is, vel per quosdam authors Dylema, it is. a Dya Graece, duo
latin, and lema, Vorago, quasi duplex Vorago. Est enim quaedam argumentatio a
quibusdam dicta complexio: que vndique co^plectitur and vorat aduersarium, and
dicitur etiam cornutus Syllogismus. Argument of cauilation, a cauile, a
sophistical argument, or a sophisime. Sophisma, it is. n. g. Argument
cauillatoire. Arguments colored, arguments that are painted with fine talk,
and have only the apparau^ce of truth, arguments of deceit. Argumenta
fucata, inani specie tantum veritatis fallentia. Argumens coulourez. Argument
or theme purposed, to be disputed of. Thema, it is. Le theme l'argument.
Arguments which can not be resolved. Ceratinae. Vne maniere d'argument
sophistique. Arise. Surgo, is, rexi. Se lever. Arise together. Consurgo, is.
Quand plusieurs se lieue^t. Arise up. Exurgo, is. Se lever. Vide Rise.
Aristarchus, a gramarian of Alexandria, instructour to Ptholomeus son, called
Philometor. Aristolochia, Hartewort, or Birthworte, an herb of two or three
kinds, in latin it is named Aristolochia rotunda, Aristolochia longa, vel
Aristolochia clematitis. Sarrasine. Stephanus says, there are four sorts
hereof, and calls it in latin Malum terrae, and Aristolochia. And in French
he names it, Aristolochie. Aristotiles or Aristotle, an excellent philosopher,
son of Nichomachus a physician, borne in Stagira in Greece, was scholar to
Plato.xx. years continually, he was low of stature, crookebacked, ill shapen,
and stut^id, and yet was his wit so sharp, study great, and knowledge so
profounde (in ye works of nature) that he excelled al which wrote before him,
and is had in praise with all philosophers, which wrote since his time, he
taught Alexander the great. His followers were called Peripatetici,
Aristotiles, lis. m. g. Arithmeticke, or the art to number and cast
accomptes. Arithmetica, cae. Arithmetice, ces. Numeralis scientia. L'art de
nombrer and de compter. Arm. Brachium, ii. Vlna, ae. Le bras. Arm hoole.
Acella, ae. Asella, and. Axilla, ae. L'aisselle. Arm of a tree or vine.

sacred peace of his contry with the rage of cruel war, or to bear armor
with the enemy against his own country. Arma contra patriam far, Accipere,
Induere, Capere, vel portare. S'armer a l'encontre de son pais. Armyd, and to
tarry for the battle. In armis stare and morari. Se tenir tous armez. Armyd
in complete harness, men that are armed from top to toe. Milites cataphracti.
Gens de guerre armez de toutes pieces, ou de pied en cap. Army marching
forward. Agmen, enis. Exercitus ambulans iterque faciens. Armee qui march.

mill hommes de pied.

Armies more obeysante or obediente. Exercitus parentiores. Armies plus
obeissantes. Army of the Romans. Res Romana. L'armee des Romans. He is at
the camp, or amongst the army, or in the army. Est apud exercitum. Il est
en l'armee.

Army when it marches or goes forward. Agmen, enis. Vne armee quand elle
march. Army, or a band of men vncomplete or not furnished. Mutilatus
exercitus. Vne armee qui n'est pas fournie de gens. Army disordred, spread

facere, Contrahere exercitum, Conficere exercitum. Assembler vne armee, lever
ou dresser vne armee.

To the which verse this answer was made.
Foetidus es nebulo, charta est plus co^moda culo.
Arssmerte, or culerage, is a very hot herb, and has the name of this,
because that if you rub it between your hands, and then touch any bare
place therewith, it will burn and smerte grievously, it grows in diches and
moist places, it is good to kill flees, it is named in latin, Persicaria.
Curaige. Arsnicke herb. Arsenicum, ci. Arsenic. Art. Ars, it is. Art. Look

and Grammaticae, ces. L'art qui enseigne de bien escrire and parler. Article.

que, tant que. Vide May and can. As much as may be, or in all haste or speed.

well. Cum, Et, Tam, Vt, Vtpote, Vtputa. Autant, tant. Vide Well. As who says.
Quasi, Scilicet, Videlicet. Comme si. Asa, a name which signifies as much, as
a healer of sicknesses, or a Phisitio^. It was also the name of one of the
kings of Judah, which honored God and destroyed Idols: he was the fifth king,
and reigned. 41. years before the birthe of our redemer. 973. years. Asa, ae.
m. g. Asce^d or go up. Asce^do, is. Sca^do, is. Subeo, is. Mo^ter. Ascend or

nous veoir ainsi habillees comme nous sommes.

I am ashamed of him, Poenitet me hominis. IN ay honte de l'homme.

Art not thou ashamed of these things? Non te haec pudent? N'as tu point de
honte de ceci?

He which is nothing ashamed. Longissime a pudore remotus, Inuerecundus,
Impudens. Qui n'ha aucune honte.

cis. Cendre. Asia, the third part of the world, divided from Europa by the
sea, called Bosphorus Thracius, and the great river of Tanais, and it is
separated from Affricke by the famous river Nylus, and it is supposed to be as
great as both Europa and Affricke. Asia minor, is a part of this Asia. Asia is
also a mere, fenne, or marishe, nere to the river Caystrus, but when it
signifies the Region above named, the first syllable is short, and when it is
a marishe, it is long. Asia, ae. f. g. Ask, or require. Apologo, as. Exigo,

Separement. Vide Separate. Aspasia, a woman so called, queen to Pericles,

A. ANTE. T.
AT. Penes, Per, vt per noctem, Propter, Sub, vt, Sub aduentum, vel sub
aduentu. At any time. Vnquam. Quelque temps. Atalanta, the name of a maiden
(daughter to Iasias, a prince of Arcadie) which came with diverse noble men of
Greece into Etolia, to slay a great boar, that destroyed the country, and
she amongst all the rest, first wounded the boar, which afterward was
slain by Meleager, son of the king of Etolia, who loved Atalanta, and took
her to his wife. An other Atalanta was the daughter of Caeneus, king of th'ile
Scyrus, she contendid always in renning with them that wowed her. And when she
had vanquished, and put many to death therefore (for that was the reward, if
they could not outrunne her) at the last a young man called Hippomenes
(whilst they were running) threw three apples of gold (at sundry times)
from him, which she staying to take up, was ouercomme. Atalanta, ae. f. g. At
a point. Ad vnguem. Parfaict. At the beginning. Primo, Primum, Principio, Ad
carceres, Ad initium. A prime face. At adventure. Forte, Fortuito. D'aduenture.
At hand. Numerato, Praesto, Pro^pte, Prope. Present. At hand, or ready to be.
Praestolor, aris. Appetit vespera, Instat, quoties est verbum neutral.
Attendre. At leisure. Per otium, Vacuo animo. Tout aloisir. At the last. Ad
extremum, Ad posterum, Imposteru^, Tandem, Tumdemum. A la parfin. At the least

tout le moins. At length, or a long time and space. Tractim. Tout d'vne tire.
At length. Prolixe, Promine^ter, Promise, Tandem. A la par fin. At the most.
Ad summum, Summum. Tout au plus. At no time. Nequando. Que quelque fois, ou
quelque temps. At once, or one time. Semel. Vne fois, tout a vng coup. At that
price, or for so much. Tantidem. Tout autant. At this present. Ad presens,
Inpresentiarum. Pour le present. At that time. Tum, Tunc, Tunc temporis. Lors,
alors, adonc. At or with. Apud. And sometime, apud signifies in. Vt apud
Orcum, in hell. In whose company, Apud quem, sometime out, as Apud se no^ est.
He is out of his mind, sometime by, as Apud focu^, by the fire, sometime
among, Vt apud omnes. etc. sometime with, as apud amicos. etc. Aupres, ches,
auec, deuant, en, enuers. Athalia, was the daughter of the cursed queen
Iesabel, and mother unto king Achab. Athalia. ae. f. g. Athanasius, a bishop of
Alexandria, the year of our Lord.348. He was a man of excellent great
learning and virtue, he confuted the errors of the Arrians in the council of
Nycene (with strong arguments) and therefore was persecuted very much by
them, for they stirred welnyghe all the world against him. After that he
suffered great tribulation for the truth of Christ his religion, and died in
the year of our redemption.379. Athanasius, ij. m. g. Athens, a famous city
in Greece, and a nourice of all good learning, and virtuous exercise. Athenae,
arum. in plurali. f. g. Athenodorus, a philosopher, which gave Octauian the
Emperor this lesson, when he departed from him: Noble prince, when you are
angry, neither say nor do any thing until you have perused the four and
twenty Greek letters, and remember the order of their places where they
stand, that the passion of choler (by withdrawing your mind) may languishe
and vanishe away. Athenodorus, ri, m. g. Of his mind was Cato in that verse
against rash or hasty judgment. Impedit ira animum, ne possit cernere verum.
Anger lettes the mind so that,
It cannot see the truth.
Atlas, the name of a king, there were three of that name, one was king of
Italy, and father of Electra, an other of Arcadia, father of Maia, the third
was king of Mauritania, called the greatest, the brother of Prometheus, who as
the Greeks suppose, did first find out the course of the stars by an
excellent imagination, the Poets feign that he sustained heaven on his
shoulders. It is also the name of a mountain in Mauritania. Atlas, lantis. m.
g. Atreus, was he that first found out the Eclipse of the Sun, he dyed
about the year before Christ. 1258. Atreus. i. m. g. Atonement or truce.
Foedus, eris. Pactio, onis. Transactio, onis. Vnitas, it is. Induciae, arum.
Appoinctement and traictie de paix. Atonemente to make. Componere lites,
Transigere rixas. Appaiser. Attache. Apprehendo, is. Rapere in Ius. Quod and
trahere and vocare dicitur. Le contraindre de venir en Justice. S. Attached
with process. Raptus ad iudicem. Attached with sickness. Implicitus morbo.
Estre enterprins de malady. Attachement. Clarigatio, Manum iniectio. Mettre la
main sur aucu^, le pre^dre au corpse, l'arrester en sa person Attaindre.
Proscriptio, onis. Proscripturio, is. To conspire in cases. etc. * Attainted.
Captus, a, um. Prins. Attalus, a king in Asia the less, marvelous rich, of
whom all magnificke and stately things are called Attalica, Attalus, li. m.
g. To one Attalus Martial, the Poet wrate this Epigramme. Declamas belle,
causas agis Attale belle.
Historias bellas, carmina bella facis.
Componis belle mimos, epigrammata belle
Bellus Grammaticus, bellus es astrologus,
Et belle cantas, and saltas Attale belle.
Bellus es art lyrae, bellus es art pilae.
Nil been cum facias, facis attamen omnia belle
Vis dicam qui sis? magnus es Ardelio.
Friend Attalus thou declamste well,
Thou pleadest causes well.
The histories do pass thou makste,
Thy verses do excel.
Thou make merry poemes, and
Thy Epigrammes are fine:
In Grammar, and the course of stars,
Thy knowledge is divine.
Both well thou singest Attalus,
And dauncest light withal:
Thy art does pass to play on harp,
Or toss the tennisse balle.
When naught thou doste is well, yet all
Thou do thou think right.
Will thou I tell what one thou art?
Ardelio, Thraso like.

Augmente. Augmenting, or augmentacion, or increasing, or enhauncing. Augmentum,
ti. Et Magmentum, ti. Apud veteres, Magnum augme^tum. Ang. A great increase.
Cumulatio, onis. Augmentation. Augustinus, the famous doctor in Chistes* borne
in Afrike, in a town caled Gathensis, was of such excellent wit, that in his
chyldhode he learned all the seven liberal sciences without an instructor: he
was wonderfully learned, specially in the doctrine of Plato, whereby he was the
rather induced to embrace the Christian faith. He favored the errors of the
Manichees: but by the continual prayer of his good mother Monica, and the
persuasion of saint Ambrose, he was at last converted to the true faith, so
that they both (replenished with the holy ghost) did singe together the Psalm
Te deum, aunswering mutually the one to the other. Afterward in prayer,
writing, and preaching, he so much profited, that he was had in great
reverence of all men, and wrote more books than ever did any in the church of
the latins. He lived. 76. years, and was bishop forty years, and died in
the year of our lord, 437. Augustinus, ni. m. g. Augustus the second
Emperor of Rome, son of Octauius a Senator, and nephewe to Julius Caesar (
whom he succeeded) this man was wise, courteous, liberal, and of much
moderation and clemency. In the four and twenty year of this Emperors
reign, was our Savior Christ borne, when that Augustus had confirmed a
general peace in all the world. Augustus, ti, m. g. August month. Augustus,
ti. Sebastus, ti. Sextilis. Le mois appele a oust. Auinion, a city in

A. ANTE. Y.
Look in A. ante I. for in our English tongue there is small diuerstrie
between these two letters in sound, and they are commonly written one for
the other.
A. ANTE. Z.
AZarias, a name in the Bible, and it signifies Auxilium domini, the help of
the Lord, of this name were diverse, one mentioned in the fourth book of the
kings. 14. and. 15. chapter. An other was a Prophet, as. 1. Paral. 15. chap.
An other was one of the three children, that praised God in the hot burning
furnace of fire, and not hurt, but saved by the Angel of God, as in Daniel.
3. Azarias, ae. m. g.
B. ANTE. A.
B A letter among the mutes, boroweth his sound of the letter E. The Greecians
do call B. Vita the which has his nature meanly between P. and Ph. And
that which they write with P. and Ph. is traduced in the Latin in B. And
again contrariwyse, what in Greek is written with Ph. in the Latin is
converted in B. And this is done Ob literarum affinitatem. In compositions B.
is tra^suerted into these letters. C. F. G. P. V. And that. Differentiae vel
Euphoniae caussa. Babylon, a great city in Chaldie, and signifies confusion,
or translation, where was a tower builded by Nemroth, in height. 5174. pases.
Afterward being enlarged by Semiramis, it contained in compass. 60. miles.
The wales were in heighte 300. foot, in thickenesse. 75. foot, and had a
hundredth brazen gates, through the middle of this city ran the famous river
Euphrates. Babylon, Babylonis. f. g. Baby, or little child. Paruulus, li.
Puellus, li. Petit enfant. Baby, or puppet for children. Pupa, ae. Pupus, pi.
Vne poupee. Babion, or monkaye beast. Caebus, by. Cercopithecus, Sphinx. Vng
marmot. Vnde Mart. Callidus enixas eludere Simius hastas,
Si mihi cauda foret, Cercopithecus eram.
I crafty Ape deceive, the darts are cast at me,
and if I had a tail, a Monckey should I be.

Bastard, or two handed sword. Spatha, ae. Vne espe^. Bastard hand, letter,
or writing. Litera adulterina. Vne lettre bastard. Bastardly, as not after the
right sort begotten. Spurius, a, um. Qui est ne d'vne femme public. Bathe,
the name of a town in Somerset shere here in England. It has the name
because of the bathes that are therein, which are of great virtue to soften
the senewes, to scour the skin, to cure the morphewe whit, and black, for
lepre, scabbes, scurfes, old sores and botches, for humors fallen into the
joints, for a hardened milte or the cake in the left side, for a hardened
liver, or mother, for all kinds of palseyes, for the Sciatica, and for all
kinds of itches. Bathonia, ae. f. g. Aquae calidae. Bath. Lauacrum, cri. Bain.

B. ANTE E.
BE. Sum, es, fui. Eras. dat Este pro estote. Be you. Sum, I am. Ie suis. Es,
Thou art. Tu es. Est, He is. Il est. Esse, To be. Estre. Be esteemed. Pondus
habere. Estre estime. Be esteemed as a God. Deorum numero esse alicui. Estre
estime and repute un dieu. Be nothing esteemed, to be out of credit.
Authoritate egere, Non optime audiri, Opinione laborare, Nihil dignitati, atque
opinioni alicuius tribuere. N'estre pas bien estime., N'auoir pas bon credit.
Be in high authority with the king. Esse magno apud regem Estre fort esteem
du roy. Be in honor, favor, or estimation. Esse in aliquo numero atque
honor, Estimatione florere, Obtinere admirationem, Summam opinionem obtinere,
Haberi magnae authoritatis, Esse maximo pretio, vel in maximo pretio. Estre
fort estime. Be absent, away, distaunt, or far of. Absum, es, fui. Estre
absent. Be before. Praesum, es, fui. Estre deuant. Be at commandment, or one
of his. Contribuere se alicui. Dedo, is. Se mettre, render and donner a aucu^.
Be it done away or God forbid. Absit. Be astonnied. Torpere, Stupere,
Stupescere, Stupefieri. Estre tout estonne. Be in a place, or be at a place. In
aliquo loco adesse. Estre in quelque lieu. Be in some thing. Inesse. Estre in
quelque chose. Be it as thou will, or you will. Esto, Sane vt vis. Age porro.
Soit ainsi. Be ofen in one place. Versor, aris. Hanter, estre souuent en vng
lieu. Beak, byll, or nebbe of a foul. Rostru^, tri. Vng bec. Et Rostellum,
li. Angl. A little beak or byll. diminit. Vng petit bec. Beaken or beacon, to
set on fire when enemies do arrive. Specula, lae. Beffroy ou eschauguette.
Belly. Abdomen. Alueus, Aluus, Epigastrium. Venture, tris. Vter, teri. Vterus,
ri. Ventre. Aluus, Is properly of any thing that has no life. Le ventre ou
sont les boyaux. Ventriculus. diminit. de venture, ac. Vterculus. diminit. de
Vterus. Ang. A little or small belly. Petit ventre. Belly ache. Hysterralgia,
Tormen, inis. Tormina, u^. p. n. Maladif du ventre. Et Aluinus, a, um. Angl.
Diseased with belly ache, or freating in the belly. Maladif du ventre. Belly
hard. Dura aluus. Un ventre dur. Belly laxatiue or lewse. Aluus cita. Un
ventre lasche and desuoye. Belly lewse that has the Flux. Liquidus venture. Le
flux de ventre. Belly great, he that has a big belly. Ventriosus, Ventrosus.
Qui ha grand ventre, ventru. Belly cries, or my belly cries with wind.
Crepitat mihi venture, Mihi intestina murmurant. Le ventre me bruit. Belly to
ease, or to ease the body. Aluum soluere, Elicere aluum, Aluum ciere, Soluere
ventrem, and ventris onus, Aluum mouere. Lascher le ventre. Stinte or stay the
belly. Aluum sistere, Continere, Firmare, Inhibere, Contrahere. Reserrere le
ventre.

B. ANTE I.

B. ANTE. R.

pas de pouoir tant fair.

Be it spoken without ostentation or brag of my self, or I speak it not to
vaunte of my self. Sit hoc a me sine Iactantiae suspitione dictum.

gros poil and piquant. Brittayne the most noble I Will, containing England and
Scotland, the true original of the name, (for that is called Albion) as yet
is not known. I leave to treat much hereof, for that I am not able to speak
otherwise then is already spoken of antique historiographers. Therefore who
that desires more, let them resort to the ancient Chronicles and histories.
Britannia, ae. Per geminum. N. Quae and a Poetis dicta alter orbis, Insula est
in Oceano septentrionali, modo Anglia adpellata, olimque a Britone rege
Britannia nominata, cum prius Albion diceretur ab albis rupibus primum
patentibus vt fingitur. Haec porrigitur in longitudine Octinge^tis mill
passibus, in qua colit gens clara, inhospita, and bellicosa, Ibi etiam Lo^dinum
Metropole oppidum celeberimum situatur, negotiatorum, licitatorumque
copiosissimu^. Est Vnita sibi Hibernia paulo minor cum. 40. Insulis quae
Orchades nuncupantur modice terminatis. Apud Britannos longiss. dies in
septenas horas mensuratur in aestate, quando etiam sunt totae noctes
perlucidae. Haec traduxi tum in gratiam, tum in laudem Britanniae nostrae. Inde
plura videris in dictione. England. Brittle, brickle, or brokle. Fragilis, le.

Friar germain. Brother by the mothers side, and not by the fathers. Frater
vterinus, Diuerisis patribus editus, vno tamen ex vtero. Qui est d' vne mesme
mere. Brothers borne both at once, Twins. Fratres gemini, Gemini, Gemelli
fratres. Freres gemeaux. Brother to my great graundfather. Propatruus, i. Grand
oncle. S. Dicitur etiam quasi pater proaui. Brotherhoode, or brotherly love.

brother. Fraternus, a, um. Vt fraternus amor. Fraternel. P. Brotherly.

one man, called brothern in law. Congeneres. Brothern, otherwise called sworn
brethren. Conuoti, orum. Soriantes, tum. Conuoti dicebantur ijsdem votis
obligati. Ca. Brothers childrens called cousins. Consanguinei. Fratres
patrueles. Deux cousins germains filz de deux freres. S. Brothers son. Frater
patruelis. De cousin germain. S. Brothers wife. Fratria, ae. Fratris vxor. La
femme de mon friar. H. Brotherslaughter, as where one brother kills another.
Fratricidium. Browe. Supercilium, Palpebra, ae. Le sourcil. S. Browe space, or
space between the brows. Glabella, lae. f. g. Look forehead. Brows broad

together. Contexo, is. Testre ensemble. Broadered. Contextus, a, um. Tissu.

besongne a l' esguille. S. Brought again. Redactus, a, um. Apporte. Brought

Brought forth into the world. Natus, a, um. Nixus, a, um. Ne: qui est ne. P.
Brought to. Actus, a, u^. Ductus, ta, tum. Mean, duict. S. Brought to account,
or reckening. Referri in acceptum, Ad co^putationem duci. Look Count. Brought

naught. Ad nihilum redigi. Estre mis ou reduict a neant, Estre annichile.
