brought. Hem quo redactus sum. En quel estat suis ie venu*

Brought up like a cockney. Delicatus, a, um. Look Cockneye. Browesse inade
with bread, or fat meat. Adipatum, ti. n. g. Viande grass. S. Browkle,
brikle, or brittle. Fragilis, e. Friabilis, e. Broukelnes, or brikelnes.
Fragilitas. Look britle. Brown color, somewhat dark, called a sad broun.
Subniger, ra, rum. Aucunement noir, Noirastre. S. Brown of color. Fuscus, a,
um. Leucophaeus, a, u^. Rauiscellus, a, u^. Baeticus, a, u^. Nigellus, a, u^.
Subaqueus, a, um. Subaquilus, la, u^. Brunet brun, obscur. S. Brown bread not
ranged. Acerosus panis, Artoptittius, vel Ater panis (Autepyron, * Secu^darius
panis. Look bread. Browse, or meat for beasts in snow time. Vescae, Salicum
fro^des. Tendres and a demi seiches and appestissantes pour les bestes. S.
Bruise. Confringo, is. Detero, ris. Obtero, ris. Subtero, ris. Tero, is, triui.
Batre, briser. S. Bruised. Fressus, a, um. Detritus, ta, tu^. Batu ou broye.
Bruised, or brayed. Intritus, a, um. Idem. Bruit, fame,, noise, or rumor.
Pertinax fama. Rumor, ris. Rumeur. S. Look Fame. Bruyte, or renown. Claritas,
Claritudo, Celebritas. Nobilitas, Fama. Look Renown. Brute of people.
Tumultus, us. Bruit. S. Brute, Savage or wild. Indomitus, a. um. Quion ne
peult donter, vaincre, ne surmonter, indontable. S. Brushe. Peniculus, li.
Peniculum, li. Scopula, lae. Brushe of bristles, made to brushe clothes.
Muscariu^ setaceum, Scopae e setis comparatae ad extergendas vestes. Verge a
nettoyer, vergette. H. Brushe for a paynter, called a pensill. Peniculus,
Penicillus, li. Pinceau. Brutus ( the son of Siluius Posthumus) a captain
of the Troyans in Greece, after the destruction of Troy, a man of excellent
wit and valiant in wars, who after his victory in Greece, for the delivery
of his country men, is said to have sailed into Leogetia, and mynding to seek
some desert country for him and his, he made his peticion to Diana in this
sort. Diua potens nemorum, terror syluestribus apris,
Cui licet anfractus ire per aethereos,
Infernasque domos, terrestria iura resolve:
Et dic quas terras, nos habitare velis.
Dic certam sedem, qua te venerabor in aeuum,
Qua tibi virgineis, templa dicabo choris.
Which I have Englished (though not so well as
I would, yet so nere the sense as is requisite) in this manner followyng.
O Goddess great in woods, that putste
Wild boares in fearful fear,
Which may go all the turning paths
Of every ayrie sphere,
And of infernal houses eke:
Resolve the earthly rightes,
And show what country in to dwell,
Thou giuste me after fightes,
Assign a certain seat, where I
Shall worship the for aye,
And where repleat with virgins, I
Erect thy temples may.
To which peticion, Brutus as he slepte received (by a vision) this answer.
Brute sub occasu solis, trans gallica regna,
Insula in Oceano est, vndique clausa mari,
Insula in Oceano est, habitata gigantibus olim,
Nunc deserta quidem gentibus apta tuis.
Hanc pete, namque tibi seeds erit illa perennis,
Hic fiet natis, altera Troia tuis.
Hic de prole tua reges nascentur, and ipsis
Totius terrae, subditus orbis erit.
Which may be thus Englished.
O Brute far under Phoebus fall,
Beyond of France that ground,
An Island in the Ocean is,
With sea it is compast round,
An Island in the Ocean is,
Where giantes erst did dwell,
And now a desert place that's apt
Will serve thy people well,
To this direct thy race, for there
Shall Be thy seat for aye,
And to thy sons there shall be builte,
An other stately Troy.
Here of thy progeny and stock
Shall mighty kings descend,
And unto them, as subject all
The world shall bow and bend.
After this he awaked, and with great joy took his passage toward Afrike,
then to Hercules pillars, than to Aquitaine, where after diverse conflictes, he
obtained the victory of the Aquitaynes and frenchemen, vitayled his ships and
so departed. And with happy wyndes arrived at Totnesse in Deuonshere, the year
before the birth of our redemer. 1108. And lyking the country well, he named
it Britannia, which before was called Albion. He builded the famous city now
called London, and named it new Troy. He reigned four and twenty years, and
died in the year before the nativity of our savior Christ. 1084. And as some
say was buried at London.

Busied to be. Negotior, aris. Satago, is. Solicitor, aris. Versor, aris.
Negotier. Busily. Actuose, Intent, Obnixe. En faisant bien l'empeche and
embesongne. S. Business Negotium, Negotiatio, Occupatio. Pragma, ae, vel it is.
Res, rei. Occupation, negotiation. S. Business of warfare. Occupatio rei
militaris. Business very troublesome. Molestissima occupatio. Business great
and incredible. Magna atque incredibilis occupatio. Full of business, that
has very much to do, greatly troubled with lettes and affairs. Plenus
negotij. Plein d'affaires qui est fort empesche. Encombre d'affaires. S.

What is the business, or for what matter, are you angry with me. Sed quid
negotij, quamobre^ succenses mihi. Mais pour quoy est ce que tu te courrouces a
moy. S.

An excellent business. Lautum negotium. Cic. Id est egregium Excellent. S.

Not without business, trouble and pain, not easily. Non sine negotio. Non
pas sans peine, Mal aiseement. S.

Without business, pain, labor, travail or toil. Nullo negotio.
Facilement, aiseement. Sans difficulte, sans peine. S.

To put one into trouble and business. Exhibere alicui negotium. Luy fair de
la facherie, le molester, le harceler, luy bailler bien des affairs. S.

Which does well exployte or handell his business. Sui negotij been gerens.
Qui fait bien ses besongnes and affairs. S.

Business and trouble rising. Gliscentibus negotijs. I have had much
business, and have traueyled much in it^ Plurimum in eo negotij habui. I'ay
eu fort affair a cela, and y ay fort trauaille. S.

To be incombred and troubled with grievous affairs and businesses. Molestis
operosisque negotijs implicari. Estre encombre d'affaires. S.

To imploye his diligence and industry to the preferrement of other men's
business. Intendere se alienis negotijs.

I marvelled what business thou had here to do. Mirabar quid hic negotij
habebas. Quel affair tu auois. S.

I have business. Est mihi negotium. I'ay a fair. S.

To offer him self to do others businesses, or to meddle with other men's
matters. Offerre se negotijs alienis. Se presenter and offrir ou ingerer de
fair les affairs d'autruy sans mandement. S.

Pompeie has some business with Caesar. Pompeio cum Caesare est negotium.
Pompee ha quelque affair auec Caesar. S.

I stand here talking as though I had no business to do. Sic verba hic
facio, quasi negotij nihil siet. Comme si ie n'auoy que fair. S.

I had an other business or matter in hand, I thought of an other thing. Non
id mihi negotium fuit. I'auoye bien autre chose a penser. S.

To undertake, do and dispatche, a matter or business. Suscipere,
administrare and conficere negotium. Entreprendre, fair and parfaire. S.

Business which is but small or little. Negotiolum, li. diminut. Cic. Bussarde
or kind of hawk, that has three stones. Buteo, onis. m. genesis Oiseau nomme
buissart. Busshe, or a bremble. Rubus, by. m. genesis Vne ronce. Busshie close, or
place where busshes and brembles grow. Rubetum, ti. Un ronssoy, un lieu pour
plant de ronces. Bushe sithe, a bylle to cut bushes, or a whypsawe. Runcina,
nae. foem. genesis Sarcle. H. Busshy places. Vespices, cum. Coop. Bushe here.
Caesaries, Coma, ae. Perruque. S. A head with a thick bushe of here. Densum
caesarie caput. Gross perruque espesse. S.

A goulden bushe of here. Aurea caesaries.

A fair bushe, or head of here. Decora caesaries. Belle perruque. S.

Bushy, or having a great bushe. Caesariatus, ta, tum. Qui ha de grande
perruque, perruquet. S. Busshe headed, or he that has a good busshe of here
well trymmed behind. Comatus, a, um. Relicinus, a, um. Et Comatulus, A boy
having a propre busshe. Et per metaphoram, arborum, and florum folia
elegantissime dicuntur comae. Coop. Busshel. Modius, ij. bossellus, li.

Two busshell and a half. Culeus. Deux boisseaux and demi.

But. Ast, Atque, Caeterum. Con. Praeterquam, Quin, Sed, Verum, Verumtamen, At.
Mais. S. Sed, est coniuctio aliquando discretiua, quandoque inceptiua. Look
for many letters from us, but do you also send more. Crebras a nobis literas
expecta, ast plures etiam mittito. Mais aussi. S.

But see you? or do you see? Atque vides? Le vois tu pas? But hear thou? or
do thou hear me? Atque audin? Mais ois tu? S. But I speak not of that.
Atque id omitto. Or ne dis ie rien de ce. But a man would say unto me. etc.
Atque aliquis dicat, nihil promoueris. Mais quelqu'vn pourroit dire. etc. But.
Atque vero. Mais. S. But. Atqui, Coniunctio discretiua, significans Sed tamen.
Mais toutessois. But truly, if he touch her with one finger, she will scratche
out his eyes. Atqui si digito illam attigerit vno, oculi illico effodientur.
Certes si. S. Yea but that thing, of all other, or chiefly, separated him from
her. Atqui ea res multo maxim, disiunxit illum ab illa. Ouy, ou voire mais
cela a este cause que, etc. Ou certes cela. etc. S.

But she speaks no word of his exclusion. Caeteru^ de exclusione verbum
nullum. Terent. No man said so but only Cicero. Nemo ita dixit praeterquam
Cicero. Except Cicero, ou fors, ou sinon Cicero. S.

I never go forth so early, nor return home so late, but I see you dig or
delue your ground. Nunquam tam mane egredior, neque tam vesperi domum
reuertor, quin te in fundo conspicer fodere. Qui ie ne te voye au camp. etc.

I doubt not, but that you are of that mind. No^ dubito quin eo sis animo. Ie
ne doubt point, que tu ne sois de tell courage. S.

There is no doubt of this, but that my son will not have a wife. Non dubium
est quin vxore^ nolit filius. Terent.

I cannot choose, but I must needs send to you. Facere non possum quin ad te
mittam. Ie ne me puis garder ou tenir que ie ne te l'enuoye. S.

I cannot choose but cry out. No^ possum quin exclamem.

There is none of us but he has vowed, or made a faithful promise. Nemo
nostrum est quin vota fecerit.

But why are you so sad. Sed quid tu es tristis. But lo I see Pamphilus. Sed
Pamphilum video. Or voy ie Pamphile. S. But hark, stay a while. Hem, sed
mane. Mais, escoute, demeure. S. Yea but. Sed autem. Voire mais. S.

But on the contrary part. Sed contra. Mais au contraire. S. But truly I can
not suffer or endure, but accuse my master. Sed enim nequeo durare quin herum
accusem meum. Certes ou voire mais ie. etc. But truly. Sed enimuero. Certes,
mais certes. S. Not only in doing but also in thinking. Non modo agendo, verum
etiam cogitando. Mais ainsi.

But truly. Verum enimuero. Mais certes, pour certain. But yet. Veruntamen.
Toutesfois. S. But there rests also one scruple or doubt, which troubles
me much. At mihi vnus scrupulus etia^ restat, qui me male habet. Mais. But I
pray you see his impudence. At videte hominis impudentiam. Mais ie vous pry
voyez. etc. But a Gods name what is it. At per deos immortales quid est. Mais
ie vous demand qui est ce. S. But take heed that he pay the whole. At vt omne
reddat. Mais anssi prenes guard qu'il rende tout. S. But truly. At, pro At
vero, At certe. Mais certes. S. But a while agone, or since. Iamdudum, Nuper
Admodum. Il y a fort peu de temps. S. But if. Ni, Nisi, Sin. Mais. S. But if
there be any one amongst many, that passes or excels. Sin aliquis excellit
vnus e multis. Que si aucun se trouue que soit. etc. S. But notwithstanding.
Attamen. Toutesfois, neant moins. But only that. Praeterquam quod. Sinon que.
S. But rather. Quinimo, immo. Mais qui plus est. S. Butte of a land. Iugus,
eris.* Butte or prick to shote at. Meta, ae. Scopus, pi. m. g. Un but a quoy
on tyr, ou on vise. S. Butte, vatte, or great vessel for wine, or other

ae. Terminus, ni. Vne borne, limite, mete. S. Butting or bounding of land.

C. ANTE. A.
C, The third of the letters, a consonant, and has the middle sound in
pronunciation between G. and chapter and whylest you pronounce C, you must needs
touch the inner part of your teethe with your tongue, else can you not
express it so plainly, as the sound of the letter requires, diverse regions,
have sondrie languages, and therefore is the pronunciation of the letters
variable, some viter C, as S, other almost like G, and no maruayle at all, for
in our English tongue it is diverse ways taken, and in sundry sorts sounded,
as the words require. In Latin C, is often changed into G, as Quadringe^ti,
pro Quadrincenti. In S, vt Parco, Parsi. In X, Vt Duco, duxi. And in the notes
of antiquity, C. scribitur pro Comitia, Causa, Causat, Con, Centum, Cum,
Condemno, Condemnatio, etiam C. Cornelius, Caius, etc. And C. stands for a
hundredth. Centum. Cent. S. C C. signifies two hundredth. Ducenti, ae, a.
Ducentum. Deux cents. S. Et sic de reliquis. Cabage, or co^leworts, an herb.
Brassica, cae. f. genesis Officinis Caulis. Des choux. Cabage, or cole cabige.
Brassica capitata. Choux cabus, Pommez, potez. S. Caban, or dark lodging.
Gurgustium, ij. Logette bien estroite. S. Caberne or cabin in a ship. Stega,
Teges. Cabinet. Cable of a ship. Rudens, it is. Funis nauticus. Vne chable. S.
Cable that holds the anchore. Funis anchorarius, Prymnesium, Anchorale,
Retinaculum, Funis qui nauim in alto aut vado sistit. Le chable de l'ancre. H.
Cacke or to go to the stool. Cacare, Excernere, Aluum leuare, inanire,
exinanire, Purgare aluum. Chier. P. Caddowe * choughe, or Jack dawe. Cornix,
Monedula, ae. Look dawe. Caermarden, a town in Wales. Marodunum. Cage, to put
pickers, prowlers, hoores, thieves, and beggars in. Catasta, tae, foe. genesis
Cake. Collyrida, Farreum, Popanum, Strues, Subucula. Un gasteau. S. Cakebread
or fretouse. Artolaganus, ni. m. g. Bignet. S Cake made for brydeales or
church goinges. Summanalia, liae. foe. genesis Coop. Cake made with chese, meal,
and water. Semilissula, Semilixula. sunt haec Sabina vocabula. Cor. Cake made
of meal and licoure, sometime divided in sacrifice. Seciuium, ij. n. genesis
Coop. Cake made of sundry spices, and graynes, offered for sacrifice in old
time. Fertum, ti. n. g. Vne maniere de gasteau qu'on offroit es sacrifices
anciens. S. Cake made like a trendle. Spira, ae. Coop. Cake of wheat. Adorea.
ae. Coop. Cakle like a hen. Glocio, is, ire. Glocido, as. Look Clock.

or general destruction. Calamitas. Calamite, and misere, Chetiuete. S. Full of
calamity or misery. Calamitosus, sa, sum. Plein de calamitez and d' ennuy,
Calamiteux, chetif. S. Vide mysery, wretchedness.

Calculate the course of the stars. Persequi numeris cursus syderum.

accou^ptes. Calculator, calculatoris. m. g. Calculateur. S. Caldron. Lebes,
it is. Cacabus, Caldarium, Ahenum. Chaudron. Cauldron maker. Faber aerarius.
Chaudronnier. S. Calender, or an Almanacke, to know the days of the year
which are holy, which not. Fasti, oru^. Calendarium, ij. Hemerologium, ij.
Calendrier, par lequel on pouoit congnoistre les iours festez and non festez.
Calendes or first day of every month. Calendae, arum. Calendes ou le primier
iour de chascun mois. S. Calendes (or the first day) of January. Iani Calendae.
Le primier iour de Ianuier. S. At the Greek Cale^des, as much as to say Never.
Ad calendas Graecas. Iamais. For the Greeks had no calendas at all.

Calendes of February or after some of March. Intercalares Calendae. Calendes
of March. Foemineae calendae. So called, for that in these they sent presents
to women. La primier iours de Mars, auquel iour la coustome estoit d' enuoyer
des presents aux femmes. S. Calendes of June. Fabariae calendae. Pertaining to
calendes. Calendaris, re. nomen adiectiuum.

Calfe. Vitulus, li. Mosculus, li. Veau. S. Et Vitulinus, a, um. Aug. Of a

mol de la iambe. Calice town. Gessoriacum. Call. Clamo, as. Voco, as. Accerso,
sis. Arcesso, sis. Inclamo, as. Hucher, appeler. Call him in my name, or say
that I bydde him come. Voca illu^ verbis meis. Di luy que ie l'appelle. S.
Call, whoope, or to cry to his company. Vocare, clamore suos. Hucher a haulte
voix. S. Call, or to cry to God. Vocare, clamore deum. Le reclamer,
l'inuoquer. S. To call one by his name. Nomine aliquem vocare. L'appeler par
son nom. S.

Call or to cry to the Gods to help. Deos vocare auxilio. Requerir and
inuoquer ou reclamer dieu a son aid. S. The crow calls for rain. Vocat
pluuium cornix. Elle demand la pluye, ou signify par son cri qu' il pluuera.
S.

Call one to accomptes. Ad calculos aliquem vocare. Requerir qu'il rende conte
des mises and receptes. S. Call one to depose or bear witness. Ad testimoniu^
vocare. Appeler quelqu'vn pour testimoigner. S. To call one to him. Aliquem ad
se accersere. Appeler a soy. S.

To call up, as men do spirits. Arcessere. Appeller les esprits.

So prepare thy self, that if I call, thou may come with a trice. Ita te
para, vt, si inclamaro, aduoles. S.

voix. S.

opem ferant fratri. S.

Call away. Reuoco, as. Auoco, as. Reuoquer rappeler. S To call or raise dead
men. Defunctos reuocare. Resusciter les morts. S.

To call or bring in doubt. In dubium reuocare. Reuoquer en doubt. S.

To call one back again, that is in his journey. Ex itinere reuocare.
Rappeler du chimin, fair retourner.

To call away from sin, or to withdraw or persuade from sins. Auocare a
peccatis. Retirer de mal fair. S.

To call out of the province. Deuocare de prouincia. Rappeler and fair
retourner.

To call to help him. Deuocare ad auxilium. Appeler a son aid. S.

To call the stars out of heaven. Refixa caelo deuocare sydera. Fair
descendre. S.

He cherefully calls his soldiers down from the hill. Laetus a tumulo suos
deuocat. Appelle and fait descendre. S.

call a side before the door. Ante aedes seuocare. Appeler a part. etc.

Care calls or separateth me from study. Cura me seuocat a studio. Call
back. Retracto, as. Coop. To call back, to vnsaye that is spoken, or to
recant. Dicta retractare. Se desdire, se retracter. S.

call back the gift. Reuocare donu^ vel munus, Infecta dona facere. Reuoquer
la donation. S.

Call and to ask for one. Aliquem requirere voce vel sermon. Appeler and
hucher aucun, en le cerchant. S. Call or to name. Cieo, cies, ciui, citum,
ciere. This verb has diverse significations, as to provoke or move, to stir
or raise up, to provoke to anger to vex, to irritate, to call or name. And
this last signification (for that it serves this place) will I only here
touch. Appeler. To call one by his name. Nomen alicuius ciere. Appeler
quelqu'vn par son nom.

To call every one by his name. Nomina singulorum ciere. Les appeler chascun
par leur nom. S.

aid. S.

aid. S. To call one to co^sulte, or to do some other thing. Aduocare ad

quelque chose. S.

To raise the camp. Mouere castra. S.

To fortify the camp. Munire castra. Fortefier. S.

force. S.

Camphyre, the name of a gum. Camphora, vulgo dicta, Aetio medico Caphur,
Hebraeis Copher. Du camphre. S. Can, or may. Possum, potes. Polleo, es. Queo,
is. Valeo, es. Pouuoir. I can not but cry out. Non possum quin exclamem. S.

Every man is not able, or cannot do all things. Non omnia possumus omnes.
Verg.

It cannot come so to pass. Non sic futurum est, Non potest. Il n'est pas
possible. S.

He can by him self. Potest per se. Il peult de soymesme. S.

I will endeavor as much as I can possibly, to do it out of hand, or
shortly. Quam maxim potero, dabo operam vt breue id faciam. Le plus qu'il me
sera possible. S.

I speak it as loud as I can. Quam possum maxima voce dico. S.

May I not know whence thou came, whose thou art, or wherefore thou come?
Possum scire quo profectus, cuius sis, aut quid veneris? Ne pourroy ie scauoir,
etc. S.

See that thou come hither to me, if thou canste possible. Huc face, vt ad me
venias, siquid poteris. S'il to est possible. S.

I do as much as I can maynteine concord. Sic tueor, vt possum, concordiam.
Cic.

Can thou tell me the truth? Potin es mihi verum dicere? Terent. Can thou
not be still? Potin es vt desinas? Ne te scaurois tu deporter? S. He could not
constrayne thee this day to bring her. Nec te quiuit hodie cogere, illam vt
duceres. Il ne to a peu contraindre. S.

I can not write the residue. Non possum reliqua scribere, vel non queo reliqua
scribere. Ie ne puis. S.

I can not tell whether fear of ill, do naturally more prevail with some,
then hope of the good. Nescio an etiam naturaliter apud plurimos plus valeat
malorum timor, quam spes bonoru^. Quin.

It can do little either to increase or diminishe. Et augendae rei, and
minuendae parum valet. Vault peu. S.

Canappy for a bed. Conopeum, i. and Conopium, ij. Vne tente, voile ou
pauillon courtine, Ceil de lict. S. Cancel or deface. Delere literas, Induco,
is. Lituro, as. Cancellare, Oblitero, as. Rescindo, is. Effacer. S. Canceler.
Cancel a decree, judgment, or sentence, once determined. Acta circumducere.

Cares that make a man heavy and sad. Tristes curae. Qui rendent l'homme
triste. I take care for your business as much as I may. Toto animo de tuis
commodis, ornamentisque cogito. Tuam vtilitatem assidue specto. Haeret in animo
meo de tuis commodis assidua cogitatio. Si quid e re tua est, id maxim laboro,

postulent, nunquam non attendo. Omnis mihi de te tuisque commodis cogitatio
est, Tuam vtilitatem meae spectant cogitationes omnes. Meas curas ad tuum

n'ay soing que de toy. S.

Case doubtful. Res dubia, vel Incerta. Uncertain. Case in law, or properly
that ryseth in contention upon the point of the matter, which must be replied
unto, and other confessed, denied, or trauersed. Caussae constitutio, Status,
us. L'estat and condition. S. Case of a nowne. Prosis. Case or the termination
of a nowne. Casus, sus. Cas. Case to put any thing in. Theca. Un estuy de
quelque chose que se soit. S. Case, such as they put pictures in, a case for
an image. Aedicula. L'estuy d'vne image. S. Case to put pinnes in. Acicularium,
Spinularium. Espinglier a mettre les espingles dedans. S. Casement. Transenna.

To cast his cloak on his neck. In collum palliolum conijcere. Plaut.

To cast stones amongst them. In medium conijcere saxa.

To cast darts, or to shoate. Tela co^ijcere. Liu.

Cast, or to bring one in love. Conijcere aliquem in amorem. Le mettre for
auant en amor. To cast one in prison, to lay in the stocks, or gyues.
Conijcere in catenas, In carcere^, In vincula. Emprisonner. Enferrer,
Enchainer. S.

To cast one into mischief and trouble. In malum conijcere aliquem. Le mettre
en grand ennuy. S.

To be cast into a disease. In morbum conijci. Venir ou tomber en malady. S.

To cast or lay the blame upon one. Conijcere causam in aliquem. Mettre le
tort sur aucun.

To cast on, or upon one. Conijcere super. Verg.

To cast up on high. Iacere in sublime. Plin.

I would rather have cast my self into the sea, then. etc. Iecissem me potius
in profundu^, quam. etc. Cic.

Verg.

cornu. Cic.

They cast an odure from the body. Odorem iaciunt de corpore. Rendent odeur.

children do. Talos iacere vel iactare. Iouer au dets.

Cast, or to throw down from the bridge into Tyber. Deijcere de ponte in

Cast his eye, or to look on a thing without regard, or by chance. Adijcere
oculorum imprudentiam aliquo. Iecter sa veue sur quelque chose sans y penser.

Castle set upon an hill. Acropolis. Call. Caster of an account. Psephopecta,

Reticulum, Rete iaculum, Retis genus quod in orbe^ funditur spargiturque. H.
Casting his darte or darting. Tela manu iaciens. Lanceant., dartant. S. Casting
his hands behind him. Reiectis ad tergum manibus. Ayant les mains derriere le
doz. S. Casting or throwyng of an arrowe, darte, or Iauelin. Iaculatio,
Iaculamen, Iaculamentum. Dardement, Iettement. P. Casting out fire. Igniuomus,
a, um. * Casting out water. Vndiuomus, a, um. * Castor and Pollux, two twins,
begotten by Jupiter one Leda under the form of a Swanne, which are called by
the Poets Tyndaridae, and so is Helena their sister likewise named, these as
soon as they came to years, delivered the Sea from Pirates, and for that were
called Gods of the Sea: Afterward they went to Colchos with Jason and other
noble men, to fetch the golden fleece, in which voyage Pollux slew Amycus
king of Bebrycia, which craftily conspired his death, and at their retourning
besieging the cit-Alphidna, (Thesius absent) They took thence their sister
Helena, which he whilst they were at Colchos had stolen, And at ye lenghth
when Castor died, Pollux ( who was immortal and hatched of the same egg
which Helena was) desired his father that he might imparte his state of
immortallitie with his brother Castor, which thing obtained of Jupiter, it is
said that they live and die by turns or course, this fable is meant by the two
twins called Gemini, for ye one rysinge the other sets. there was an other
Castor, a very ancient Physician, of whom read Plin. lib. 20. Cap. 17.
Castor, oris. mas. genesis Catch, or to graspe. Apprehendere, Inuncare,
Harpagare. Accrocher. Hooks catch fish, or fishes are caught or taken with
hooks. Ab hamis capiu^tur pisces. Les haims ou hamessons prennent les
poissons. S.

Catch. Praeripio, is. Reprehendo, is. Prendre ou accrocher. Catch as it were
with an hoke. Inunco, as. Accrocher. Catch gredely or hastily. Capto, as.
Rapto, as. Pre^dre. Catchpole. Satelles, itis. Stator, ris. Acce^sus, si. m. g.
Sergeant. P. Cathedral church. Basilica, Fanu^, Delubrum, Te^plum, i. n. g.
Temple, H. Eglise Cathedralle. Catholic or universal. Catholicus, a, um.
Vniuersalis, le. Vniuersel and general. P. Catholic or perfect Christian.
Orthodoxus, i. m. g. Qui ha bonne opinion and droicte. Cato a name of merit
among the Romans, and after yt, the surname of diverse noble men, of this
name was one excellent man named Cato Censorius, a Censurae dignitate, he came
first to Rome by the instigation of Valerius Flaccus, where (for his singular
virtues) he obtained all degrees of honor without repulse, he was first
Tribune of the Soldiers in Silica. And after being Praetor he subdued
Sardinia, where (though he were aged) he learned the Greek tongue of Enneus.
Lastely he was created Consul with Flaccus, He went into Spain, where
brynging all things well to pass, he gat great renown. he had two sons, of
which the one, under Paulus Aemilius, in his wars against Persius, fought
with great praise and commendation, the other his father yet living, and being
Praetor, was killed, he wrote diverse worthy books of the Law. This Cato
Censorius lived about the year before the birthe of Christ. 182. Another Cato
was called Vticensis, unto whom the above named Cato was great gra^dfather,
whom he followed in seuerite and virtuous discipline, he sometime used to go
abroad barefoote and in a short gown, using only bashefulnesse, at sight of
dishonest or uncomely things: being Tribune of the Soldiers, he was sent into
Macedonie, where with marvelous gravity, prudence, and paynfulnesse, he made
all that were under him, fearce and hardy against their enemies, gentill to
their fellows, fearful to do injury, and prompt to get praises, and he him
self laboring with the^ using apparel, feading and going like them, contrary
to men's expectations (notwithstanding his severity) wanne the hearts of them,
going on foot and talkyng with every man. And further: such was he of
constancy, whom neither flattery could allure, terror of words fear, nor
power provoke, to grant any thing, which seemed to impair the state of the
weal public, wherefore for grief, and sorrow of heart that he had, seeing
the utter destruction of his country eminent, and that it should (by Caesar)
be brought into seruage and thraldom, he slew him self at Vtica. There was
an other named Valerius Cato a Gramarian at Rome, which taught many noble men
in the time of Silla, whose fame is noted in these two verses of Tranquil.
Cato grammaticus latina Siren,
qui solus legit and facit poetas.
Cato that grammarian is
a latin Siren sure,
Which only has the skill to read and poets bring in ure.
Catoure or purueyoure of vitayles. Opsonator, vel trix, Obsonator. Coquus
nundinalis, qui coemptos e macello cibos coquo tradit ad cocturam. Despensier,
qui achette les viandes. Catte Aelurus, Catus, Felis, Murilegus, Muscio, onis
Un chat. S. Et Catinus, vel Felinus, a, um. Ang. Of a catte. D' vne chat.
Cattes here, otherwise called a felon. Furunculus. Un froncle ou clou qui
vient au corpse humain. P. Cattes tail herb, which some call horse tail.
Cauda equina, Equisetum, Salix equina. Queue de cheual, fallot. Cattle. Pecu.
per omn. casu. plural. Pecua, Pecus, dis. et oris. Toute sort de best qni n'
a point de langage ne form human. S. Pecus, dis. Is all small cattle, as
Goats, Sheep. etc. Et Pecus, oris. Is all great cattle as horse. etc. Et
Pecorinus, a, um. An. Of cattle or rother beasts. Et Pecorarius, a, um. Ang.

Full of cattayle, where be many cattayle. Pecorosus, sa, sum. Ou il y a grande
abondance de brebis, and autres bestes abondant en bestail. S.

A caucie or a way paued. Agger solidus. Chemin paue de pieres, Chaucee. S.

To make a cauceye. Iacere aggerem. Fair vne chaussee.

Caudell for a sick man. Iusculum, Sorbillum. Un chaudeau. P. Cave or dungeon.

scoff, or an hafting question. Cauilla, lae, and Cauillum, li. Petite
moquerie, ioyeuse. Cauillation: A merry taunte: A subtle forged tale, A subtle
turning the catte in the pan or wresting of a false thing to some purpose.

Temps calm. Cause. Caussa, ae. Dica, ae. Nomen, inis. Occasio, onis. Ratio,
onis. Res, ei. La cause, la chose. The cause or matter is such. In ea causa
res est. La chose est tell. S.

There is a cause why. Causa est cur. Ci il y a cause pourquoy.

There will be cause, why we may praise the counsel or advise of our elders.
Erit causa, qua consilium maiorum laudare possimus. Il y aura cause pourquoy.
etc.

That there be no cause, which way any person may seek thee. Ne causae quid
sit, quo te quisquam quaeritet. A fin que person n' ait cause de te chercher.

For that cause I will not have thee come in hither. Ea te causa huc introire
nolo. Pour ceste cause.

For these causes and reasons. De his causis. Pour tells raisons. S.

Thou wast cause of his condemnation or casting. In causa damnationis fuisti.
Tu as este cause. etc.

I have no cause to lie, there is no cause why I should say otherwise then the
truth is. Causa nulla est cur mentiar. IN n' ay aucune occasion de mentir. S.

For the very same cause. Ob eam ipsam causam. Pour ceste mesme cause. S.

It was a cause of liberty to the city. Libertatis causa fuit ciuitati. Cause
que la ville sest mise en liberte.

It was cause, or occasion of all his ill. Malorum causa fuit adolescenti.
Cause, ou occasion de tous ses mauls. S.

Thou art cause or occasion of this war. Constat causa belli in tua persona.
Tu es cause de ceste guerre.

Let them consider, for what cause and reason, they do every thing. Videant
qua quidque geratur cum ratione. Lucret.

Thou art cause of all this mischief. Tu horum maloru^ caussa, Tu fons, and
origo. Tu tantas malorum faces ince^disti. Tu horu^ malorum initium attulisti.
Tu haec mala peperisti, haec mala excitasti, Auctor horu^ malorum praeter te
nemo fuit. A te fluxerunt haec mala, haec incommoda, calamitates, acerbitates,
infortunia, damna, detrimenta, pernicies, exitium, reru^ euersio. Horu^ maloru^
culpa^ sustines, horu^ in te maloru^ culpa co^ferenda est omnis, haec tibi su^t
adscribe^da, assigna^da. Has calamitates vni tibi acceptas refer debemus. Tu
es cause.

Should not I come for my very friends cause, against an alien and a
stranger? An ego non ve nirem, contra alienu^ pro familiari and necessario,
and domestico meo? Ne prendroye ie pas la cause de mon ami. etc.

Tell or to show the cause. Rationem reddere. Dire la cause.

Cause of ones pains. Poenam sibi contrahere. Estre cause de la pain qu' on
endure. S. Cause of his own death. Contrahere sibi causam mortis. Estre cause
de sa mort. S. Cause of ones marriage or to cause one to mary. Efficere nuptias
alicui. Estre cause du marriage d' aueun. S. To cause ye others study no longer.
Studia aliorum restinguere. Estre cause que les autres n' estudient plus. S.

I am the cause of this. Ortum est ex me. IN en suis cause. S.

Thou art ye cause. Iniuria tua factu^. Tu en es cause.

He was the cause of going. Author fuit profectionis. il fut cause de l' allee.
S.

For what cause? Quam ob causam? Quam ad finem? Quam ob rem? Qua gratia? Quo
nomine? Pour quelle cause. S.

For this cause. Ex ea causa, hac gratia. Pour ceste cause. S.

For this only cause. Hoc vno nomine. Pour ceste seule cause. S.

For these causes. Pro hisce rebus, Ob hasce res. Pour ces causes. S.

I speak not for that cause, or to that end. Neque haec in eam sente^tiam
dixi, Non hoc eo pertinet. Ie ne l' ay pas dict pour ceste cause. S.

Angry without a cause. De nihilo irasci. Se courrourcer sans cause. S.

Not without a cause. Non sine causa, Non immerito, Non abs re, Non iniuria,
Rite, Merito, Optimo iure, Summis rationibus, Optima de causa. Non sans cause.

Cause, just and true. Sontica caussa. Causen, or to cause. Causo, as, Facio,
is. Fair. Cause one to abide or tarry. Remoror, aris. Demoror, aris. Retarger
aucun. Arrester. Cause ill luck. Oscoeno, as. Cause thyrste. Quaerere sitim. *
Causing. Causatiuus, a, um.* Cautels, or crafty ways to deceive. Offuciae,
aru^. Offucia, ae. Techna, Dolus, Astus, Astutia, Vafritia. Cautelle.
Cautelouse. Subdolus, a, um. Fraudulentus, a, um. Versipellis, le. Cauteleux.
S. Cautelously. Subdole, Fraudule^ter, Vafre, Caute, Peditentim, Astute.
Cautement, Cauteleusement. S.
C. ANTE. E.
CEase, or leave. Cesso, as. Conquiesco, scis. Defino, is. Pono, is. Quiesco,
scis. Remitto, is. Requiesco, scis. Restinguo, is. Supersedeo, es. Et vult tam
dati. quam abl. Cesser. The work goes not forward or the work cease.
Opus cessat. La besongne cesse.

Godliness is laid aside, or it cease. Pietas cessat. Ovid.

He ceased not all this day to rail at me. Nunquam cessauit hodie dicere
contumelias. Il n' a cesse auiourd' huy de dire iniure. S.

Not to leave of, or cease his business. Non cessare in opere and studio. Ne
lascher iamais la besongne, Ne finer ou cesser iamais de fair son affair. S.

He never cease to detracte and speak evil of us. Non cessat de nobis
detrahere. Ne cesse de mesdire de nous. S.

You never ceased in mine affair, till the matter was brought to pass. Nisi
perfecta re, de me non conquiesti. Tu n' as iamais cesse en mon affair, que la
chose n' ait este mise a fin.

In winter all wars cease. Hyeme omnia bella iure gentium conquiescunt.
Cessent.

Cease now the matter is past remedy. Desine, Iam conclamatum est. Deporte toy,
Cesse. The rain ceased. Imbres desierant. La pluye estoit cessee.

The earthquakes cease or stint, when the winds begin. Desinunt tremores,
quum ve^tus emersit. Plin.

The fire ceased. Flamma quieuit. Virg.

The war ceased. Arma quierunt. Sil.

Thou may cease now to do me injury. Remittas iam me onerare iniurijs.
Terent.

In peace he never ceased to gather his power and strength again. Nunquam
remisit animum a colligendis in pace viribus. Iamais ne cessa de. etc.

The showers of rain ceased. Imbres remiserunt. Ont cess^.

To cease to labor, to labor no more so much. Labores remittere. Cesser de
labourer and trauailler. S.

Thou never ceasest or take rest, thou let pass no time. Nullum
remittis tempus, neque te respicis. Tu ne cesses iamais, Tu n'has point de
cesse.

Not to cease for any man's council. Non requiescere consilio cuiusquam. Ne
cesser, and ne se deporter point pour quelque conseil qu' on nous done.
Requiescere, Is red in Vergil with an accusative case, as in this verse. Et
mutata suos requierunt flumina cursus.
And when the ryuers altered were,
they ceast their course to run.


I Ceased to write, contend and speak. etc. Supersedi scribere certare,
loqui. etc. Plin. Iun.

Cease or to leave of. Ferio, vel ferior, aris, feriari, deponens. Cesser. Vt
Cic. Feriari a studijs. Cesser d' estudier. Se reposer. Cease from work.
Vacationem facere vel habere. Cesser de besongner. S. Cease to cry. Parcere
lamentis. Cesser de braire. Cease, or to leave to talk. Sermonem de re aliqua
abstinere. Cesser de parler. Cease, or do thou leave to speak evil of me.
Co^pesse in me unjust loqui, De me mitte male loqui, Remitte iam me iniurijs
onerare. Cesse de dire mal de moy. S. Ceasing of letters or leaving of to
write. Intermissio literarum. Quand on cesse d' escrire lettres. S. Not to
cease marueling. Admirationem non intermittere. Ne cesser de s' esmerueiller. S.

We cease not to exhort. Nos cohortari non intermittimus. Nous ne cesserons de
l' enhorter. S.

To make war without ceasing. Bellum continenter gerere. Sans cesse fair la
guerre. S.

Cease fighting. Deponere pugnam. Cesser la guerre. Cease from giving.
Largitiones retractare. Cease from pain, and sorrow. Dedoleo, es. Finer sa
douleur. S. Cease the tumulte of the people. Impetum populi reprimere. Impetu^
populi comprimere, Continere, Contundere and frangere. S. Cease war.
Opprimere bellum exortu^. Ceased it is. Refrixit. Ceased. Quietus, a, um.
Remissus, a, um. Qui est en repos. S. Ceasing. Cessatio, Concessatio,

interdict vacation. S. Ceder tree. Cedrus. Un Cedre. Et Cedris, cedridis. The

CHafe one, or to make one angry. Bilem alicui mouere, vel commouere,

Chappelen. Capellanus.* Chapplet. Corona, ae. foe. g. Charge. Onus, eris.

curam, Mandata accipere, Munia capescere, Onus aliquod recipere, vel suscipere,

C. ANTE. I.
CIcero, the name of a noble man, which was Consul of Rome with Caius
Antonius, whose divine eloquence, abundant learning, sharpenes of wit,
dexterity in acts, and most ardent love toward the common weal of his
country, cannot be sufficiently expressed by no mortal man's tongue or pen.
His ancestors were named Cicerones, because yt Tullius Appius, a noble king
of Volscis, and one of that progeny, had on his nose a mark like a chyche,
which is a kind of pulse called Cicer. He so profited in the eloquence of
Greek and Latin, that not only his companions were in a marvelous
admiration of him, but also Apolonius the most excellent orator at yt time,
in hearing him, was greatly abashed, and keeping silence a long space, said at
the last: Truly, Cicero I praise thee, and marvel at thee, but I lamenc
greatly the fortune of Greece, when I considre, that not only noblenes in
deeds of arms and martial affairs, is taken from us by the valiantness and
puissaunce of the Romans, but also that the great praise and glory of
learning, which was only left unto us, is now by thee translated to Rome.
Which saying was found afterward very true. For look what subtilitie is in
Logike, what commodity and secret knowledge in Philosophy moral and
natural: He knew and declared the same in Latin in most perfect eloquence.
And (which is to be wondered at) not withstanding, that he being a very young
man, came to practyse in Rome, and had studied abundantly the civil laws, and
was marueilously occupied in great and weighty causes, and after that he was
Senator, was continually (as it seemed) most busy about ye weal public:
yet he that does read his works (although we have not the third part of them
which he wrote) shall think that he did never any other thing but read
great authors and write books. and yet did he exployte by his wisdom and
diligence, many great enterpryses, for the commodity and safegarde of his
country, as well in war as in peace. For the which the Senate and people
gave to him first before any other, the name, of Father of his country, For
when as civil wars began to invade the Roman Empire, and when ambition,
was crepte into the bosoms of the Senators, Cicero with many vehement
orations exhorted them to beware of ambition: And therein seemed to have a
certain divine forsighte of things to come, so in his orations against
Cateline, may be seen, with what love, art, diligence, study, instrie,
and singular eloquence, he unfolded, opened and displayed, the whole
interpryce of that lewd conspirator, and delivered his country from peril of
fire and sword: Likewise in his orations against M. Antonius the love of his
country and common weal, is vehemently expressed, and that with wonderful
eloquence, whereby Antonius was proclaimed enemy to his country, this caused
him to bear great ill will to Cicero, in so much yt in treaty of peace
between him and Octauius, he demanded Cicero to do with him at his pleasure,
which was granted of the unkind Octauius, whom Cicero had brought up, and
caused to be made chief governor of the Romans. Wherefore Antonius sent
one Herennius (whom Cicero had saved from death by his eloquence) to slay him,
who pursued him as he fled out of the city, which thing Cicero
perceauinge, abode his coming, lying in a horse litter for weakness, and
prepared his throat to Herennius, who struck of his head, and his right hand,
and brought them to Antonius: who caused them to be set over the place of
civil Judgment in Rome, Cicero, onis. m. g. Cycorie herb, whose flower will
open at the rising of the Sun, and close at the goinge down. Ambubeia,
Chondrilla, Condrillon, Heliotropium, Intybus, Intybum, Seris, Cichoriu^,
Chondrilla mayor, Dod. * Intybum satiuum, Cichorium satiuum, Cicorea domestica.
Cicoree domestique. H. Cycorie savage or wild Cycorie. Intubum, vel Cichorium
siluestre, nonnullis Ambubeia. Cicoree sauuage. H. Cydre a kind of wine or
drink made of apples. Sicera, Vinum e pomis factitium. Sidre. H. Ciphers or
notes of brief writing. Abbreuiatio^s Notae, Silgae. Abbreuiatures. H.
Cymball. Cymbalum, li. n. g. Cymbale. Cymball player. Cymbalista, ae. m. genesis
Qui jove des cymbales. Cyme. Vide Cement. Cynamon or cannell. Cinamomum,
Cinnamomu^. i, n. g. La vraye canelle. H. Cynquefoyle herb, otherwise called
five leaued grass. Pentaphyllon, Quinquefolium. Cinque fueille. H. Cypres of
lynnen. Carbasus. plur. Carbasa. Cypres an herb to set in pottes. Chamaepytis,
vel Chamaepitys. Cypres tree. Cupressus, Cyparissus. Cypres. S. Et Cupressinus,
a, um. Ang. Of Cypres tree. De Cypres. A place planted with Cypres trees.

C. ANTE. O.
Coasts, lymetes, borders or the fro^tiers of countries. Limits, Orae, Fines,
Confinia, Regiones. Frontieres, lisieres du pais, fins and limetes des
contrees. S. Coast or region, either of the air, earth or sea. A^ of the air,
East, West, North, and South. etc. Regio, onis. Vne region. The four coasts
and quarters of the world Regiones coeli quatuor. Cic. Les quatre quartie^s ou
parties du monde.

Cobyron, or a rack wherein the brotche lies when it is turned at the fler.

onis. Veteramentarius suitor, Suppactor, oris. Sauetier. S. Cobwebbe. Tela

The spider makes cobwebbes. Aranea telas exercet. Ovid.

The spider wenueth her web with her foot, or the spider draws out her
threede with her foot. Filum pede deducit aranea. Ovid.

bird. Coxis, igis. Vide Cuckowe. Cock. Gallus, vel Gallinaceus. m. g. Coq. S.

Cock crow, a time in the night very late, or toward the morning very early,
when cocks use to crow. Gallicinium. ij. n. g. Le temps de la nuict que les
coqs chantent. S. Et cantus galli, The cock crow. As, I came about the cock
crow, or a little before the cock crewe. Veni sub galli cantum. Deuant que
les coqs chantent. Cocks crow before day. Cantant ante lucem galli. Cic.
Cocks ouercomme, are still or sylent, but the victors, or they that overcome,
crow. Victi galli silere solent, canere victores. Cic. Cocks crawe, or the
crawe of any bird. Ingluuies, Vesicula gutturis. Le poche d'vn oyseau. H.
Cock or teate of a conduite. Papilla, ae. Un petit bout perce en form de
mamelle qu' on met au bout des tuyaux des fontaines, par lequel l' eaue sort
petit a petit. S. Cocks of conduites, by which the water runs forth
dropping or running. Salientes. Cic. Les bouts des tuyaux des fontaines par
lesquels l'eaue sort. S Look Cesterne. Cockatrice or basilisque, a serpente
with a white spotte on his head like a Diadem. He has a very sharp head, a
red mouth, black eyes and body, of a wonderful venomous nature, with
hissing he puts all serpents to flighte, his breath corrupts the air,
destroys fruit, burns herbs, and breaks stones, and with only sight he
kills man, of which Mantuan writes these two verses. Natus in ardenti
Lybiae basiliscus arena.
Vulnerat aspectu, luminibusque necat.
Borne is in burning Lybie sand. the basiliske to ill.
By sight he wounds, and with his eyes each creature can he kill.
In latin he is called Basiliscus. Regulus serpens, Catoblepas, pae. foe. g.
Basilisque. Plin. lib. 8. cap. 21. Cocatris. Pals. Coquatris. S. Cock of heye.
Meta foeni. Un mulon de foin. S. Cockeboate, or a boat to row in ryuers
withal. Alueus, Nauicula, Scapha. Vne nasselle. S. A little cockeboate to
fyshe in, a fisher boat. Oria, Lenunculus. Nasselle a pescher. S.

There is nothing can give me consolation. etc. Nihil est, quod solatium,
consolationem praebere, afferre, parere, solatio esse, consolatione esse mihi
possit. Nulla res est, quae creare, reficere, leuare, vindicare a dolor,
liberare solicitudine, eximere dolor, abducere a cura, auocare a molestia,
abstrahere, auellere a moerore animum meu^ possit, afflictum a moerore animum,
languente^, iacentem, erigere, excitare, confirmare nulla iam consolatio
potest, affectum dolor animum sanare nulla ratio valet. Laboranti animo,
aegrota^ti, pessime affecto mederi satis nulla ratio valet. Parum apta remedia
reperientur. Inutilis, infirma, inanis, superuacanea prorsus omnis medicina
est. Quis iam homo animo meo virtutem, dolor ereptam, restituere possit? Quis
ea sanare vulnera, ijs vulneribus mederi, medicinam afferre, remedium inuenire,
quae mihi fortuna intulit, imposuit, inflixit? Ita dolor obruor, vt emergere
nulla ratione possim. Ita malis opprimor, prorsus vt respirare non liceat.
Respuit iam animus meus, quasi desperata salute, omnem medicinam, remedia
cuncta, omnia consolationum genera, frustra in me consolando ponitur opera.
Inanem operam sumit, qui ad me consolandum aggreditur. Insitus, infixus in
animo dolor ita penitus est, vt euelli nulla ratione possit, vt nulla vis
rationum possit esse tanta, quae illum possit euellere, extrahere, educere,
eripere. finem facere dolori meo, finem imponere, modum statuere, terminum
statuere, dolorem medicari, neque homo est, neque res vlla, quae possit. Non
est vt possim in dolor mihi te^perare, dolor abstinere, dolorem sedare,
abijcere, Ipse me ad eam hilaritatem, eam iucunditatem, quam dolor ademit,
reuocare: refer me ad pristinam animi aequitatem, in eum statum, vnde me
dolor deiecit, deturbauit, depulit, detrusit, restituere.

est.

Illi nil obstat, dum ne sit ditior alter.
Ferue^ auaritia, miseraque cupidine pectus.
Immoritur lucris, and amore senescit habendi. Est esurientissimus opum. Est
auidissimus lucri. Aurum immodice sitit. Inexplebili auri auiditate, and
hydropisi laborat. Aurum omni voto appetit. Maciem contrahit, fraudat que
genium, vt aurum congerat. Illi nullus satis est thesaurus. Ab ipsis etiam
statuis exigeret farinas. A mortuo tributum extorqueret. Aurum auidssime
esurit. Retia vbique tendit ad nummos. Querendae vndique pecuniae sese dedit.
Sacra fames auri, and illi germana ambitio, suum animu^ inuaserunt. Adeo coepta
est excrescere sua auri habendi cupido, vt suis non contenta finibus, aliena
moliatur inuadere. Auaritia ad iniuriam vsque grassatur. Animum adiunxit ad
congerendas opes ac censum. Ea est homini auaritia, vt cum iam alterum pedem
habuerit in cymba Charontis, nondum suae cupiditati sit praescripturus modum.
Auri virtus ingenitam sui habendi rabiem, vehemensque desiderium cunctis
induxit: ei tamen praeter caeteros. Ante lucana expergiscitur diligentia, auri
cupiditate inflammatus. Nu^mis adeo inhiat, vt sibi non sit amicus. Nullae illi
diuitiae sunt satis. Non Midae, non Croesi, non omnis Persarum copia explere
tartaream habendi ingluuiem potest. Lucri adeo est cupidus, vt ipsum non
aestas, non hyems, non ignis, non mare, non denique ferrum, a lucro dimoueat.
Sibi plaudit, ipse domi simul ac nummos conspexit in arca. Congestis vndique
saccis indormit inhians, and tanquam parcere sacris cogitur, aut pictis tanqua^
gaudere tabellis. Philargyria mentem suam tenet, occupat, illigat. Suum studium
congerendis nummis deuouit. Est studiosior lucri quam par sit. Animu^ habet ad
auaritia^ nimio plus inflexu^.

Covetous byer. Emax, cis. Qui aim fort a acheter. Covetousness or couetise.
Auaritia, Cupiditas, Cupido, Philargyria, Auiditas. Conuoitise. S. Covetousness
is the cause of much mischief. etc. Parit auaritia multa mala. Existunt,
nascuntur, proficiscuntur, proueniu^t, effluunt, emana^t, exoriuntur ex
auaritia multa mala. Multoru^ maloru^ causa, origo, principium, fons. radix
auaritia est. Multorum malorum causa, referenda ad auaritiam, conferenda in
auaritiam, adscribenda, assignanda, tribuenda auaritiae est. Culpam sustinet
auaritia multorum malorum. Covetousness is now a days of great force. etc. His
te^poribus latissime patet auaritia vbique, vbique locoru^, vbiuis, vbiuis
locoru^, nusquam non: est, dominatur, regnat, viget maxim, orb terrarum est
co^plexa, omniu^ animos occupauit, ac tenet, in animos omniu^ irrepsit, infecti
sunt oes auarititiae labe. Plus operae in re quae renda, in opibus congerendis,
in diuitijs colligendis, co^parandis, contrahendis ponitur, consumitur,
locatur, quam deceat. Auaritiae vitio hodie fere nemo non laborat, prope^si
omnes fere sunt ad auaritiam. Ad summu^ peruenit auaritia. Eo processit, eo est
auaritia progressa, quo maxim potuit, quo longius non datur, quo non licet
vlterius. Thou art euel spoken of, for thy covetousness. Auaritiae nomine male
audis: auaritiae flagras infamia, laboras infamia. Auaritiae tibi crime^
obijcitur, exprobratur: in te confertur auaritiae culpa. Tibi auaritiae nota
inuritur. Suspectus in primis es auaritiae nomine. Accusaris, reprehenderis,
exagitaris: vt in auaritiam pronior, ad auaritia^ procliuior, vt homo
diuitiarum nimis appetens, immoderate sitiens, supra modum cupidus, eupidior
quam satis est, auidor quam satis est, nimius in diuitiarum cupiditate.

C. ANTE. R.
CRabbe fyshe. Cancer, Carcinus, ni. m. genesis Cancres. H. And it is also a sign

gloreux. S. Crack, bounce, farte, sound, or a thumpe. Crepitus, us. m. g.

Craft. Ars, it is. Astus, us. Astutia, Dolus, Insidiae, Techna, Vafritia,

Cramme or to fylle. Farcio, iui, re. Remplir, farcir. S. Cramme in. Inesco,
scis. Infarcire, Effarcire. Farcir. S Crammed full. Fartim. Aduerb. Cramming or
stuffing. Fartura, ae. Et Farctura, ae. foe. genesis Colum. Crampe, which is a
defecte of the sennowes and muscles, whereby sometime the whole body, and
sometime part thereof is stretched, if it be in part of the body, then it is
thus Englished, crampe: if it be in the entier body (which is rare) the name
thereof in our mouther tongue is not known. Conuulsio, onis, Spasmus. Graece
(...). Conuulsion ou retirement de nerfs, Spasme. S. Crampe of such kind that
the senowes are so stiff, they can not bow. Tetanus, ni. m. ge. Plin. That
has such crampe. Tetanicus, ca, cum. Plinius.

Crane a bird. Grus, is. Palamedaea auis. Grue. H. Cranes which be young,
called vipions. Vipiones. Minores grues, sicut pipiones minores columbi. Plin.
lib. 10. cap. 19. Crane, which is an engine to draw up weightye things.
Ergatum, ti. n. g. Cranny, or creuice in the ground. Vide chynke. Crannied and
broken or clefte. Crenatus, Fimbriatus, Serratus. Crene, and frange. S.
Crannied or chinked to be. Rimas agere. Se creuasser. S. Crashe or to make a
noise. Crepito, as. Crepo, as. Craqueter. S. Crashe with the teeth. Frendeo,
es. Premere dentes. Infrendeo, es. Strido, is. Strideo, es. Grincer les dens de
grand courroux. S. Crates, a Theban and Cynike Philosopher, the disciple of
Diogenes, which reducing all his substance into money, left it with a
banker, on this condition, that if his children should be Philosophers, he
should destribute the money to the nedy citezins, thinking a philosopher to
need nothing: but if they were Idiotes he should give it them, that wanting
virtue, riches might sustain their necessity. others say that he cast his
substance into the sea (that he might more freely adicte his mind to
philosophy) saying: hence with a mischief, you wicked inticeme^ts, I will
drown you, least hereafter you drown me: for he thought he ne could
possess, both riches and virtue together. Crates, is. mas. ge. Crave.
Emendico, as. Proco, as. Rogo, as. Crauer. Mendicus, Petitor, Procus, Rogator,
vel Trix. Homo petax. Coquin S. Craving. Mendicitas, Rogatus. Coquinerie. S.
Craving, or shameful asking. Procacitas, tatis. f. g. Crawe, or the croppe of
a bird. Ingluuies, Vesicula gutturis. Le poche d'vn oyseau. H. Cream. Flos
lactis, Cremor lactis, Pugue lactis. Creme. H. Creape upon ye belly like a

color. S It is spoken of things growyng. Vt proserpit herba. Plin. Creape

is. Se trainer verse quelque chose. Creape into (or to get by little and

l'amitie de quelqu'vn. S. Creape like a vine or Iuye, or such like. Erro, as,
are. Creaping beast or worm, and al thing that creapeth naturally. Reptile,

Credit, that which is owed. Creditum. Aes alienum, Debitum. Debte d'argent
priest. S. vne crea^ce. Aes nostrum. Which is owed to us. To be in credit. In
authoritate esse. Gratia flagrare. Estre en credit. S.

To be in great credit with one. Gratiam alicuius tenere, Apud aliquem
plurimum posse, Priores parts habere apud alique^, Valere gratia apud aliquem,
esse in gratia cum aliquo. Auoir grand credit enuers aucun. S.

To be out of credit. Authoritate egere, Non optime audire, Opinione laborare.
N'auoir pas bon credit. S.

To leese his credit. Fidem consumere, Perdere, Labefacere, Labefactare. Perdre
son credit. S.

He has lost his credit. De gradu potentiae deiectus est. Il a perdu son
credit. S.

They have lost their credit. Fides nuper deficere eos coepit. Il ont perdu
leur credit. S.

To take money upon credit. Mutuas pecunias sumere. Prendre argent a credit. S.

Culinder. Colum, li. n. g. Couloir. H. Cullayse brothe or gruel. Olus, eris.
Pulmentum, Pulmentarium. Vide Brothe. Culle, a little fyshe with a great head,

ge. Constelier qui fait les cousteaux. H. Cyrus, son to Cambysis ( as
Justinius writes) translated the Empire of the Medes unto the Persians, and
having won Asia, he subdued all the East unto his power. At last when he made
war with the Scithians, and afflicted them with great calamity: Tomyris
their queen, by polycie brought him into such a straight, that she s^ewe him
and all his army, which was of two hundredth thousand soldiers, so that not
one remained alive. Then caused she the head of Cyrus to be stricken of, and
casting it into a vessel filled with blood, she said. Suffice thy self with
blood which thou haste thristed Cyrus, ri. m. ge.
D. ANTE. A.
D, Is a letter called in Greek Delta, there signifying the number of four,
which in Latin or English letters signifies five, thus written. M. D. lxxi.
which is 1571. Also at Memphis the river Nilus has with his course made a
place after the form of this Greek letter D and to this day it is called
Delta. Dace or dase a fyshe. Aphya, Apua, ae. f. g. Arist. 6. Animal. Dadde or
daddy, as infantes call their fathers. Tata, vel Pappa, (...), id est Pater.
Pere. Likewise they call their mothers or nourises Mammy. Mamma, Which is a
Greek word, (...) Balbutientium puerorum vox, vel (...), id est Auia patris
matrisue matter. And Pappare is to call Dadde or Daddy. Appeller son pere Pappa.
S. And Mammare, To call Mammy. Appeller sa mere Mamma. Daffadyll herb.
Anthericon, Asphodelus, Hastula regia, Albucum. Affodillus. Des asphodilles. H.
Dagger. Cestrum, tri. Gladiolus. Pugio, onis. Clunabulum, vel vt Festus habet
clunaculum, quod ad clunes religetur. Poignard. H. Et sica, ae. Vne dague ou
poignart. S. Et Pugiunculus, li. Diminut. Ang. A little or short dagger. Dagge
swayne. Gausape, is. Gausapina. foe. genesis Day. Dies, ei. Lumen soles. Iour. Et
diurnus, a, um. Of a day. De iour. Sunday. Dies dominicus, vel solis.
Dimenche. H

Monday. Dies lunae. Lundy. H.

Tuesday. Dies martis. Mardy. H.

Wednesday. Dies mercurij. Mercredy. H.

Thursdaye. Dies Iouis. Ieudy. H.

Frydaye. Dies veneris. Vendredy. H.

Saturdaye. Dies saturni, vel Sabbati. Sammedy.

Day after or day followyng. Postera dies, Perendinus dies. Le iour d' apres.
S. Day after to morrow, the day following (the day before rehearsed) or the
next day after. Perindie, Postridie. Apres demain. S. Day before. Pridie. Le
iour de deuant. S. Et Pridianus, a, um. Ang. Of the day before. Du iour de
deuant. S. Day before yesterdaye, as much to say, as two days before or
past. Nudius tertius Deuant hier. Et Nudiusquartus, Nudiusquintus,
Nudiussextus. The fourth, fifthe or sixth day, that is past or before this.
Day by day. Quotidie, Diem de die, In singulos dies, Per omnes dies. De iour
en iour. S. vide daily. Before day. Ante lucem. Deuant le iour. S.

It is broad day. Multa lux est. S.

The day is far spent. Declinat in vesperu^ dies.

The day is far paste, or it is even night. Dies conficitur, Eximitur dies,
It dies, Praeterijt dies. Le iour se pass. S.

Day followyng, or the next day. Die secundo, Lumine secundo vel sequenti,
Alia luce orta. Le iour d' apres. S. Day light under the firmament. Dium, ij.
n. genesis Day next after to morrow. Perendinus dies. Le iour d' apres demain.
S. Day of birth or nativity. Dies natalis, vel genitalis. Natalis, Natale,
and Natalitium. Iour de la natiuite. H. Day of baptism. Dies lustricus quo
lustrabatur infans, nome^que illi creabatur. Le iour du baptism. Day of
death. Emortualis dies, Dies quo quis die^ obit. Iour de la mort. H. Day of
judgment to death. Capitalis dies. Day of return of a write or process. Dies
Iuridicus, vel Legitimus. Day over in law. Comperendinarius dies. Macrob.
Sat. 1. Cap. 16. Comperendinus dies. Day over for emparlaunce, or day over
after emparlaunce. Comperendinarius terminus. Day star. Lucifer, Phosphorus.
Lubar, aris. n. ge. L'estoile du iour. S. Day time or some time in the day.
Diu, Interdiu, De die. De iour, par iour. S. And so is, De nocte, By night. De
nuict. S. Day to wax, or it waxes day, or day light, or it is day.
Diescit, Lucescit. Le iour point. S. Day which makes leap year.
Exhaeresimus.* vel intercalaris dies. Insititius dies. Le iour de bissexte. H.
Day and night. Dies and noctes, vel dies noctesque. Iour and nuict. Holy day.
Festus dies, Dies solemnis, Otiosus dies. Un iour feste. S.

Day to work in, a worky day. Operarius dies, Profestus dies. Iour ouurier.
S. Days appointed. Dies dicti, Stati, Praestituti. Iours arrestez. S. Days
deed. Actus, Opera, Opus, eris. n. g. Days deed and a half of a workman.
Sesquiopera, ae. f. g. Un iournee and demie d' un ouurier. S. Days divided,
which be half holy days, and half workyng days. Intercisi dies. Days of
judgment to be given of increase to succeade. Decretorium tempus, vel Sydus
decretorium. Plin. li. 18. Days hyre. Diurnus.* Diarium, ij. n. g. Iournee. H.
Diurnae operae pretium. Days journey of an host, which was accounted an
hundred and fyfty forlonges, which is. xviii. mile and more. Mansio, onis. foe.
ge. Plin. lib. 12. cap. 14. and lib. 6. cap. 13. And Mansio, onis. The place of
abode, or time of taryeing. Days of heaviness, or of mischaunce. Dies
religiosi. Cicero. Ad At. and Gel. lib. 4. cap. 9. At^i dies, and dies
infoelix, Infamis and Infaustus. Iour malh^ureux. H. Days of prayer or
devotion. Religiosi dies. Days of venereall pastime. Aphrodisia, Veneris
festa. Days or terms ordinary called among our Lawyers. Dies datus in
banco, Or days in bancke, for ye defendau^t, or playntife. Dies legitimus,
Stati dies. Vide supra. days appointed. Days when the Physicians may know
the importance of the sickness, by the apparaunt tokens in the patient.
Decretorij dies, Dies critici. Dies criticus and crisimus apud medicos, quo
exitij aut salutis notae apparent. H. Daily. Assiduus, a, um. Quotidianus, a,
um. Qui est de iour en iour. S. Daily, or day by day, or every day.
Assidue, Indies, Aduerb. In dies singulos, Quotidie. De iour en iour. S.
Daily, of a day, or pertaining to a day. Diurnus, a, um. De iour. S. Daily
geste, or companion at ye table. Conuictor vel Trix. Quotidianus conuiua, and
qui nobiscum viuit familialiter. Ovid. 4. De ponto. Commensal. S. Dale. Vallis,
is. Vallee. H. Et Vallecula. Diminut. Ang. A little dale. Et Vallaris, re.
Pertayninge to a dale. De vallee. Dale or valley compaste round with hills or
mountains. Conuallis. Liu. Vallis vndique collibus aut montibus inclusa.

wanton language. Proco, as.*. Dallye, or to play the fool. Ineptio, is, ire.
Folastrer, Badiner, Bauer. S. Dalliaunce. Paraphronesis. * Ineptia. ae. foem.
genesis Bauerie. S. Damage or adversity. Aduersa aerumna. Damage or hurt.
Detrimentum, Incommodum, Damnum, Iniuria, Maleficentia, Maleficium, Termentum,

damno. A mon dam. S.

Damageous, or doing hurt or hurtful. Damnificus, Incommodus, Iniuriosus, a,
um. Damnosus, sa, sum. Dommageable. S. Damask roses. Trachinia. Damask sylke.
Damascena. Damas. S. Et Serica vestis, vel Scutulata vestis. Habillement
damasse. A garment of damask. Dame or maistresse. Domina, nae. foe. genesis Dame
ou maistresse. S. Great dames of high renown. Principes, foeminae. Grandes
dames de grand renom. S.

Damn or to condemn. Damnare, Damer. S. Damned. Damnatus, ta, tum. Damn. S.
Damnation. Damnatio, onis. foe. g. Damnation. S. Damsel. Puella, Iuuencula,
Adolescentula. Damoiselle. S. Damned. Addictus, a, um. Vide Condemned. Damsyn.
Prunum, ni. n. genesis Et Pruna Damascena. Prunes de Damas. S. Damsyn tree.
Prunus, ni. foe. genesis Col. Un prunier. S. Et Prunetum. The place where damsyn
trees grow. Et hortus prunosus. Is an orcharde or gardayne where many damsyn
trees grow. Daniel a Prophet of the tribe of Judah, and is interpreted a man
acknowledging and confessing God, as Judge. Who at the debellation of
Jerusalem by Nabuchadnezer, was taken captive with Ananias, Misael, and
Azarias, amongst other, and educated with other yongelynges captives in the
kings court by Aspheuas the high Steward, which had their lyuinge out of
the kings storehouse, his name was altered by the same Steward and called
Balthazar, that is to say: the most excellent and faithful keeper of
treasure. The names also of the other were there at the self same time
changed, the which I do omit, because they appear more pregnantly in the
history of Daniel. This Daniel Prophesied of the four high Monarchies,
whereof the one stood upon the Chaldees, and eftsoon upon the Babilonians,
both combined at the last in one, which began in Abraham's days, and
continued to the last years of Daniel, even unto the end of the captivity of
the Jews in Babylon, which was the first Monarchy, and stood. 1495. years,
and ended in the year from the Incarnation 3440. And then after began
incontinently the second Monarchy (which was the Empire of the Medes and
Persians) to flourish, and continued an. 191. years, whom Alexander Magnus
conquered. After which conqueste began the third Monarchy, called the Empire
of the Greeks, which stood. 260. years. The fourth Monarchy which began.
47. years before Christ's birth, is called at this time ye Romayne Empire,
which presently stands (as Daniel. capit. ij. did forsaye it) upon feable
feet made of brickle potbacked earth, whereof the legs are iron. etc. Vide
Danielem. cap. ij. At the beginning of this last and fourth Momarchie, the
Romans were puissaunte and strong, so continuing until Mahumet and
Antichriste did translate, divide, scatter, and mynishe the Empire. The which
last and fourth Monarchy has stand these. 1618. years. Julius Caesar first
being Consul, and eftsoon Emperor of Rome, who reigned four years and seven
months, whom Octauius Augustus succeeded, in whose reign. Anno. xlij. Christ
was borne. etc. Daniel, lis. mas. ge. Danger. Vide Danger. Dankyshe or moist.

Nor yet I Am so deformed much,

did stand and stable state.

or prostrate. Supplex, cis. Adiectiuum. Desiring many things, or much.
Multiuolus, a, um. Catul. ad Mallium, Multiuola est mulier. Desirous, or
desiring. Appetens, it is. Auidus, a, um. Affectuosus. Cupidus, a, um. Desireux.
S. Desirous. Studiosus, a, um. Vt laudis studiosus. Desirous of praise.
Desirous of honor, and promotion. Ambitiosus, a, um. Ambitieux. S. Desirously,
or with desire, or desiringly. Cupide, Cupienter, Optato, Studiose. Auec grand
desir. S. It is to be noted that all verbes ending in vrio, As Cacaturio,
Coenaturio, Dicturio. etc. Be verbes desyderatiue, desiring or entendinge to
perform the act of their significations, as Facturio. I desire to do.
Lecturio, I desire to read. They are formed of the latter supine, by putting
to rio, Vt Esu, Esurio. They are of the fourth conjugation, verbes neuters, and
lack their preterfecte tense and supines, only two excepted. Parturio and
Esurio, vt Li^ius. Praeteritum fugiunt, Meditatiua omnia, praeter parturio,
esurrio, quae praeteritum duo formant. And that they lack the supines.
Quicquid praeterito caruit datur absque supinis. If you couit to know more of
the nature of these verbes, read Laur. Vall. li. 1. cap. 24. But this may
suffrse.

Despectus, ta, tum. Vt Vergil. Despectus tibi sum, nec quis sim quaeris Alexi,
Quam dives niuei pecoris quam lactis abundans.
Mill meae Siculis errant in montibus agnae.
Of the Alexis I Am despysde
Thou naught inquyrst of me,
How rich of snow white sheep I am
What store of milk for thee,
A thousand wander of my lambs
In mountes of Sicilie.

D. ANTE. I.
Diadem or cappe, whereupon the king wears his crown. Diadema, it is. n.
genesis Diadem. S. And he which wears a Diadem on his head. Diadematus, ta,
tum. Qui ha un diadem en la test. Et Diadema, atis. Is also sometime taken
for the crown it self. Dial. Horologium, Sciatericum, Solarium. Un quadran
ou horologe a soleil. H. Dial set upon a chymney or wall, to know what it is a
clock by the Sun. Sciatericon. Idem. Dialogue, the speech between those
which talk or dispute. Dialogus, Sermo inter colloquentes disputantesque
personas. Dialogue enter deux ou plusieurs. H. Diamonde, a kind of precious
stone, which is said to be so hard that it can not be broken, but this is not
always found true, it is soonest dissolved in warm Goats blood. Vti Rhennius
quidam Poeta cecinit. Quem minime valeat ferrum superare nec ignis,
Frangitur hircino maceratus sanguine tantum.
Whom neither fire nor iron strong,
can burn or break with stroke,
Delayde or stepte in blood of goats
thereby is only broke.
There are of this stone four kinds. As one of India, an other of Arabia, the
third of Macedonia, and the fourth of Cyprus. But that of Inde is most
precious, of the nature of this and the like, Lege Albertu^ Magnum De
mineralibus. Et Plin. li. 37. cap. 4. Et Dioscor. li. 4. cap. 69. Et Iul.
Solin. cap. 64. Adamas, antis. mas. ge. Un Diamant. Adamantaeus, a, um. Et

would have thee use more diligence in writing. Velim te plus diligentiae,
curae, operae, industriae, studij in scribendo ponere, Locare, Collocare,
Consumere. Plus diligentiae ad scribendum co^ferri a te velim, Operam nauare
studio maiore in scribendo cuperem, Tuis in scriptis diligentiam desidero,
Requiro, Maiorem postulo, Non scribis accurate, non diligenter, non studiose,
non ea, qua opus esset, quam res postulat diligentia, minus quam. oporteat
diligenter, Impiger in scribendo non admodu^ es.

He was of al men, most dillige^t in his affairs. Erat in omni genere officij
maxim omnium dilige^tissimus, omnis officij diligentissimus, Vincebat,
superabat, anteibat, antecedebat omnes, excellebat omnes, antecellebat omnibus
diligentia, Par illi, aequalis, similis, cum illo comparandus, aequandus,
conferendus, componendus, in diligentia nemo fuit.

Discordant. Discors, dis. Adiect. Discordant. S. Discord, dissension, or
division among people. Diaphonia, Discordia, Dissidium, Diuidia, Seditio, onis.
Dissensio, onis. Dissensus, sus. Dissidentia, ae. f. g. Discord ou dissension.
S. Et Dissidiosus, a, um. ac Seditiosus, a, um. Ang. Full of discord. Tit.
Liui. recites (which is worthy to be noted) that division did offend the
public state of ye Romans, by these three points: Iuuenile consilium,
Latens odium, Singular co^modum. As to the first point, the old Senators
and the young could not agree, for there was division and parts taking, for
the old thinking their ways very laudable, the young on the other part
esteamed theirs more acceptable. And concerning the second point, pryuie
hatred and malice crept in amongst them, that the old hated the young, and
the young disdayned the old, and so remained as men without charity. As
touching the third, and last point, every man mynding chiefly his private
lucre, did little regard the publicque state, and thus by division the state
of ye public wealth did decay. Discord in speech, tune, or voice.
Dissonantia, ae. foem. genesis To discord. Discordo, as. Discrepo, as. Dissideo,
es. Disconuenio, is. Discorder. S.

grand discord enter eux. S

D. ANTE. O.
DOblet. Diplois, dis. f. ge. Thorax, is. mas. ge. Pourpoinct. Docilitie.

is a doctor of divinity. Est theologiae doctor, Est doctor theologicus. Il est

reliquis disciplinis. Cor.

shrewd turn, which after runs away. Tropeus.* Dog. Canis. Graece Cynos.
Chien. H. Et Caninus, a, um. Ang. Of a dog. De chien. S. If you desire to
read the wonderful sagacitie, love, nature and property of dogs, read the
25. of Iul. Solin. and Cic. 2. De not. de.

Dog days. Dies caniculares, vel caprificiales, Feriae canariae. Les iours
caniculiers. H. Doggefenel herb. Amariscus, Fenellum caninu^.* Stataria herba,
Pinastellum, Peucedanum, Foeniculus porcinus. Queue de porc. H. Dog fish.
Boce, ces. Boces, cis. Canis marinus. Dog fly. Cynomyia, ae. foe. g. Musca
canina, quae sanguinem ab animalibus exugit. Haec praecipue canu^ aures
infestat, vnde nomen est sortita. Call. Dog lean. Squallidus, a, um.
Strigosus, a, um. Fort maigre. S. Dog properly a bandogge. Lycisca, Or it is
a dog engendered between a bitche and a wolf. I think it a mungerel or a
shepeherdes curre, some think it is taken in the third Aeglog of Virgil, For
the proper name of a dog, let us therefore show what Menalcas says. Quid
domini facient: audent cum talia fures?
Non ego te vidi Damonis pessime caprum,
Accipere insidijs: multum latrante lycisca?
Et cum clamarem quo nunc se proripit ille,
Tityre coge pecus: tu post carecta latebas.
What more shall masters do when thieves
Presume such things to say?
Did not I see the noughtie knave
Filtche Damones goat away?
His dog much barking, and when as
where creepes he now I cryde,
O Tityrus keep thy cattle in:
In segges thou did the hyde.

vt virum bonum decet. Il a faict en homme de bien. Cor.

He has done all his duty toward me. Omni officio mihi satisfecit, Omne
officium mihi praestitit, Nullum erga me officium praetermisit. Ila faict tout
son deuoir enuers moy.

Do a thing so subtely as can be. Locum subtilitati nullum relinquere. I would
never have to do with thee. Nihil vnquam velim tecum contrahere, Nollem tecum

a fair a toy. Cor.

Do a thing royally. Regaliter vel basilice aliquid facere. Do a thing slyly,
or craftily. Manticulor, aris. It is also to pick a purse. Do away, or to
take away. Abrogo, as. Oster. S. Do away. Semoueo, es. Idem atque Abrogo, as.
To take away. Oster. S. To do as he says. Verba ad rem refer.

Do a thing three fold. Triplico, as. Tripler. S. Et Tertio, as. To do the
third time. Tiercer. S. Do a thing double or two fold. Duplico, cas. Doubler.
S. Do a thing four fold, or four times. Quadruplico, cas. Quadrupler. S.
Do a thing the third time. Tertio, as. Tiercer. S. Do before or first.
Praeuerto, is. Anteuerto, is. Adeuancer. S. Do contrary to alegiaunce. Prodere
fidem. Do dissolutely without reason or wit. Scopas dissipare. Thou do
more then thou have thanks for, or you have more labor then thanks. Plus
equo officiosus es, Tu nimis obsequeris, Officium simulas, Nimium prae tefers
obsequium. Tu fais du bon varlet.

Do folyshly, or rashely. Temero, as. Temerare negotium, Inepte facere. Do
eftsoon, or again. Reitero, as. Redintegro, as. Refaire. S. Do for one all
pleasure that may be. Profundere in aliquem, Promereo, es. Promereor, eris.
Promerere de aliquo. I will do it whether thou wylt or no, I will do it in thy
despite, or to anger thee. Odio tui faciam illud, Illud te inuito faciam,
quamlibet resistas, faciam tamen, id est quantumlibet. Qua^tumuis repugnes,
nihilominus id faciam, Velis nolis id faciam, Hoc vel te inuito faciam, Etiam
si maxim nolis, tamen faciam. Ie le feray en despit de toy. Cor.

Do ill. Aedere facinus. Do much with an other man. Valere apud alique^. Do
often. Actito, as. Acto, as. Agito, as. Factito, as. Souuent fair vne chose.
S. Do one thing before an other. Anteuerto, is. Vt supra. Do that he woteth
not what. Perplector, eris. * Do well. Benefacio, cis. Fair bien. S. Thou
ought, or it becomes thee to take in good part, that which I have done
well, or with good will. Quod been feci, boni vt consulas decet, Non debes ex
animo quod feci in malam partem accipere. Tu ne dois pas prendre en mal, ce que
i ay faict pour bien. Cor.

Doing. Agens, it is. Faciens, it is. Faisant. S. Doing good pleasure, or service.
Promerens, it is. Qui fait quelque bien a un autre. That does one a good turn.

Dote. Deliro, as. Insanio, is. Desipio, is. Radoter. S. Dotage, or folly.

Nam Gnydiae volucris dicitur esse deae.
Crashe not the tender dove
With grasping gredy toothe,
For she is said to be
The foul that Venus louthe.

thinks another. Solet aliud sentire and aliud loqui, Homo est bilinguis, Est
homo duplex, Aliud in ore promptum aliud in pectore clausum habet, Eius animo
lingua solet esse dissimilis, Solet aliud sentire and loqui. Cest un homme a
deux visaiges. Cor.

onis. Offendiculum, Scrupulus, Suspicio, Suspectio, Timiditas, tatis. foe. genesis
Doubt. Subdubitatio, onis, f. g. An. A little doubt. Doubt, or to be in
doubt. Addubito, as. Cuncto, as. Cunctor, aris. Dubito, as. Fluctuo, as.
Haereo, es. Haesito, as. Pendere, Percipere opinione, Nuto, as. Subdubito, as,
aui, are. In ambiguo, aut in dubio esse. Estre en doubt. S. I am in doubt
what to do. Ancipiti cura distrahor, iactor, versor, animi pendeo, incertus
animi sum, pendet animus, inclinat huc illuc, fluctuat, iactatur, incertus est,
quid consilij capiam. Vtram in partem me them ignoro. explicare consilium,
expedire me ex hac deliberatione, exitu^ meae cogitationis inuenire non possum,
distrahunt me diuersa consilia, in vtramque partem ita multa succurrunt, vt
difficilis admodum sit, minime expedita, minime explicata, minime explorata,
minime certa, perobscura, haud satis aperta deliberatio.

Doubtful. Anceps, it is. Creperus, Dubious, Incertus, Perplexus, Scrupulosus,
Suspensus, a, um. Ambiguus, ua, uum. Doubteux. S. It is doubtful to what end
the wars will come. Dubium est, dubitandum est, dubitari potest, in dubio
est, est cur dubitetur, dubitationem res habet, ambiguum est, in dubio
versatur, in dubio positum est, in ambiguo, in ancipiti, plane non constat, non
patet, non liquet, apertum non est, perspicuum, dilucidum, dilucide non patet,
qui sit belli exitus futurus, de belli euentu potest ambigi, certo diuinare,
conijcere, augurare, affirmare non licet, exploratum non est, certa coniectura
non est, in dubium vocari potest euentus belli, in dubium venire, in
dubitationem adduci, potest in vtranque partem iudicari de belli eue^tu, anceps
de belli exitu, ambigua, dubia, incerta, difficilis admodum, obscura, quae
obscuritatis and erroris habeat multum, non simplex, non aperta, non perspicua,
parum certa diuinatio, coniectura, opinio est. coniecturam facere de belli
exitu cui licet? quid in bello casurum sit, vtram in partem inclinatura
victoria, nemo dispicit, videt, intelligit, nouit, exitum belli certa ratio non
oste^dit, non promittit.

Dowre, or dowrye. Donatio propter nuptias. Dos, it is. foe. ge. Do, ou
douaire. H. Et Dotalis, le. Ang. which pertains to a dowrye. De douaire. et

a dowrye. Donner do.

To pay the dowrye. Exoluere dotem. Payer le do. S.

Women that have great dowres. Dotatae mulieres. Femmes qui ont grand do. S.

Woman that has no dowrye. Indotata mulier. Femme qui n' ha null do. S.


D. ANTE. R.
DRradde, dreadful, or to be feared. Terribilis, le. Vide Dreadful. Dradde,
or feared to be. Metuendus, Timendus, Verendus, a, um. Pauendus, a, um. Qui
est a craindre. S. Dragge. Tragula, ae. f. g. I think it may be taken for
such as they take a bucket with forth of the well, it is also a dragge net.
Un traineau. S. Dragge, or instrument of husbandrye with iron teethe to break
cloddes, some do call it an Harrowe. Occa, ae. foem. genesis Crates occatoria. Vne
hearse. S. Dragge net. Tragum, gi. Verriculum, li. Rete piscatorium ita dictum
quod per aquam verratur, id est, trahatur, idem et Euerriculum dicitur. Call.

g. Hersement. S. Dragon. Draco, onis. m. g. Un dragon. Of the dragon his

Soli. Dragon which is the female. Dracaena. ae. f. g. Call. Dragons herb.

or sleade, which goes without wheles. Traha, ae. vel Trahea, foe. g.

-- Trahit sua quenque voluptas.
Each one is drawn by deep desire
To love what lykes his eye.

Drink. Potus, us. m. g. La boire, la boisson. S. Drink charmed, which causes
madness for loves sake. Philtrum, tri. Cic. Amatorium poculum appellat. Et Ovid.
2. de Art. Nec data profuerint pallentia philtra puellis:
Philtra nocent animis, vimque furoris habent.
Nor yet those potions pale will help
Are given to virgins small:
Such drinckes do hurt the mind, and have
Of furies force with all.

Dronken and drunk. Idem. Dronke^ drabbes which wander about ye streates.
Ambubeiae, arum. foe. genesis Dronken knave. Madulsa, Potator, Potor, oris. m. g.
Yurongne. S. Dronken sow. Thyas, per periphra.* Dronken, or which has
droncke. Potus, a, um. Qui a bien beu. S. Dronken with wine. Plenus vini.
Temulentus, Vinarius, Vinosus, a, um. Yurongne. S. To make dronken. Inebrio,
as. Enyurer. S.

Dronken to be. Exercere bacchanal. Inebrior, aris. Poto, as. verb. neut.
Dronkennes. Crapula, Ebrietas, Perpotatio, Temulentia, Ebriositas, Bacchatio,
Vinolentia, Popinatio, onis. foe. genesis Yurongnerie. S. By dronkenesse. Vitio
vini. Par yurongnerie. S.

Senica in his.83. Epistle, affirms dronkenesse to be nothing else but
voluntary madness. Resite (says he) the example of Alexander king of
Macedonie which when he was drunk, slew his dear and faithful friend
Clitus, and after the offense known, he would have dyed for shame and
grief. Senica Epistola.83. affirmat nihil aliud esse ebrietatem, quam
voluntariam insaniam. Refer (inquit) Alexandri Macedonis exemplum qui Clitum
charissimum sibi, ac, fide liss. inter epulas transfodit, and intellecto
facinore mori voluit.

E. AMTE. A.
EAle, a fish. Anguilla, ae. foem. genesis Anguille. S. In the great river of
Ganges, are eales of thirty foot long, as Iul. Solin. Cap. 65. writes, and
Plin. lib. 9. cap. 3. nature. Hist. Ear. Auris, is. f. g. Oreille. Et
Auricularius, a, um. Of the ears, or pertaining to the ears. ac Auritus, ta,
tum. He that has great ears, or he that hears well. Ear lap, or nether
part of the ear. Auricula, Auricula infima, Ansa auriculae. Le tendron de l'
oreille. H. Ear lidde, or over part of the ear, Pinnula, ae. f. g. Ear of

ELbowe. Cubitus, ti. m. g. Cubitum, ti. neu. ge. Ancon, onis. mas. gener. Le

Elect. Eligo, is, egi. Optionem facere, Optare, Adoptare, Delectum facere, vel
habere. Eslire. S. Elect or appoint an heir, as by way of adoption. Adopto,
as. Adopter. Call. Election or chose. Co^ditio, Electio, onis. f. g. Election.
Election or choice of things. Rerum delectus, Electio, onis. foe. g. Election.
Election of good from from evil. Discretio, onis. f. g. The election of
