Electuary, which the apothecaries call otherwise Lochet. Ecligma, atis, vel
Eclegma, atis. n. g. Electuaire que les apothicaires appellent autreme^t
Lochot. Elegancy. Elegantia, ae. foe. genesis Elegance. S. Elegant. Elegans, it is.
Lautus, a, um. Elegant. S. Elegant person. Philocalus.* Elegantly. Eleganter,
Rotunde, Laute. Elegamment. To speak without eligancy. Horride dicere, sieve
inculte. Parler sans elegance. S.

To speak eligantly. Laute loqui, vel eliganter. Parler elegamment. S.

He writes eligantly. Scribit eleganti structura, Scripta sua sunt piperata,
Oratorum facundiae cohaerentissima. Scribit terse, nitide, and expolite.
Scripta sua sunt miro verborum cultu expolita. Nihil scribit, nisi ingenio
perfectum, and industria elaboratum. Scriptis suis nihil potest esse, neque
doctius, neque sapidius. Scriptorum suoru^ Genio delectantur omneis, tam lepida
sunt. Scripta sua diuite quadam sententiarum atque verborum copia, aurei
fluminis instar exuberant. Spirante Minerua hoc elucubratum est. Scripta sua
sunt eloquentiae pigmentis adeo venustata, vt in ijs eloquij lumen sple^descat.
In suis scriptis velut quoddam eloquij Latialis lumen splendeat. Scriptis suis
inest concinna facilitas, and facilis concinnitas. Nemo est, quem festiuitas
sui styli no^ protinus pelliceat. Beatissima in scriptis eius rerum and
verborum copia. Multum ei inest eruditae facilitatis. Homo est verborum delectu
religiosus, and proprietate perspicuus. Vir est verborum supellectile dives,
Compositione expeditus, Veneribus oratorijs gratissimus. In scribendo videtur
esse Gratiarum choro stipatus. Eius stylus placidus, sedatus, ineffectatus.
Stylus est sui vndique similis, apertus, simplex, modestiae plenus, doctus,
eruditus, petpolitus, nihil vsquam habens scabri, contorti, conturbati. Quem
non (obsecro) suauitas illa suorum scriptorum, tanta elegantia tam dives tot
sales, tot aculei argutiae, tanta eruditio, tanta varietas, tantaeque vbique
Veneres and gratiae delectant? Scripta sua sunt et venustate promiscua, and
perspicuitate clara, munditi^que verboru^m perornata sunt lepidis and venustis
vocum modulis vincta, sunt Demosthenio lepore exculta, miro verborum lenocinio
phalerata, multijugis sermonis oratorij phaleris redimita, elega^ti ac absoluta
verborum cultura elaborata, non sunt a Romani eloquij puritate aliena, sunt
venustissimis delectisque verbis, ac sententijs plena. Literae suae sunt non
solum eruditae, (quod illis perpetuum est) verumetiam gratijs, leporibus,
salibus, sic vndique scaren^es, vt nemo sit tam plane agelastos, quin his
legendis plane hilarescat. Illi perpetuu^ est, peculiare, and proprium quam
eruditissime scribere. Quae scribit, complere apes floribus, and nectare
videntur. Quae scribit, abunde lectorem reficiunt, tam grata sunt and
elegantia. Mirum est, quantum scriptis suis sit humanitatis and venustatis,
quam arguta, quam dulcia, quam nitida sunt, dictu mirum est. Nihil non elegans,
pensiculate and enucleate scribit. Lepide and venuste scribit sic, vt prorsus
melius fieri posse nihil censeas. Scripta sua sunt multo venustatum color
depicta and variata. Sua scripta eximiam dicendi facultatem referu^t. Scripta
sua sunt ita ad amussim perfecta, atque ad summum absoluta, vt ne ab liuore
quidem aut Momo valiant reprehendi. Suis pereruditis scriptis summam verborum
elegantiam, summum nitorem, splendorem, candorem adiu^git. Scripta sua sunt
omni elegantiarum genere ornatissima. Scriptis suis nihil est doctius,
candidius, politiusque. Illud suum scribendi genus minime triuiale est, immo,
cultum, subactumque sparsum denique optimarum lectionum fruge. Compositissima
sunt sua scripta, and quam fieri potest elaborata. Scriptis suis haud parum
lucis and splendoris inest. Musae omnes certatim ei scribenti aspirant. Nihil
non crudite and ornate, nihil non destincte, and ad amussim scribit. Sua
scripta adeo fluunt, vt secum rapiant lectores. Sua scripta multam variamque
recipient lectionem. Suis scriptis verborum mundities nunquam non accedit. In
suis scriptis nihil videas, nisi politie^ verborum, beatamque rerum and
sententiarum copiam. Scriptis suis accedit Romanae proprietatis peritia, sum
admiranda. Scripta sua sunt omni Venere chariora, longeque cultiora, sunt ad
Aristophanis lucernam elucubrata. Oleum, lucernamque, sua scripta resipiunt.
Demosthenis aut Epicteti lucernam olent. Varijs Rhetorum schematis lasciuiunt.
Innumera Latini sermonis vbertate, in star laeti graminis luxuriant. Est
festiuus in suis scriptis nitor and gratissima latinarum vocum exuberantia.

Elements or principles, whereof al things have their beginning, which be
four, Air, Earth, Fire, and Water. Elementa, orum. n. g. Elemens,
Commencemens de toutes chooses. Call. Elements, or principles of Grammar.
Grammatices elementa. Elements, whereof lettres be made sillables. Litterarum
elementa. And the self letters be called, Litterae elementariae, vel
Primitiuae. Elephant a beast (in Mauritania) of wonderful strength, the
greatest among all beasts, and comes nearest to humane sense: Of the nature
of the Elephant, read Plin. lib. 8. and Iul. Solin. cap. 38. and Munster. in
Ind. Hist. Eliphas, antis. m. g. Elephantus, ti. m. g. Barrus, ri. m. g. Un
El^phant. To braye like an Eliphant. Barrio, is. Braire comme un Eliphant. S.

The braying of an Eliphant. Barritus, tus. Le cri d' un Eliphant. S. Et
Elephantinus, a, um. Of an Elephant. D' elephant.

The long snoute of the Eliphante, hanginge down to the ground, wherewith he
fyghteth or defends him self in fighting with the Dragon, as Solinus cap. 38.
writes. Proboscis, idis. foe. genesis

Elephantes louse, or a tree called Pediculum Elephantis, Anacardus, vel dum.*
Eleven. Vndecim. Ind. Vndeni, ae a, plu. number. Onze. Eleventh. Vndecimus,
Vndenus, a, um. Onzieme. S. Eleven times. Vndecies. Aduerb. O^ze fois. S.
Elfes, or Fayres. Lamiae, arum. foem. genesis Ab antiquis mulieres esse
putaba^tur, sieve verius daemonu^ quaedam phantasmata, quae formosarum mulierum

He is eloquent. Est Romana facundia nobilitatus, Latina eloquentia
spectabilis, Eloquij Latialis nitore conspicuus. Homo ornatioris eloquij. Homo
ornatissimae facu^diae. Cultus and eloquens. Facunda ac nitida elocutione
vtitur. Loquitur omni barbary procul repulsa. Singularis eloquij suauitas ore
suo dimanat. Est velut quida^ eloquij Romani Deus. Cum summa verborum elegantia
sermonisque venustate, atque gratia declamat. Ciceronis elegantiam atque
iucunditatem in dicendo, egregie exprimit. Qui eloquentiam (quae in eo est
singularis) maiorem desideret, is mihi suauitatem in melle desiderare vide.
tur. Tantum cultus and nitoris inest suae linguae, vt ad solam audientium
delectationem genitus videatur. Suaui ioco et lepore valet. Rhetorissat, and
Musas Latias studiose colit. Hic Demosthenem, Tulliumque vincit, linguae
praecipuos, ducesque summos. Est latina facundia celebratus. Vir cultissima
facu^dia praecellens. Orator est haud hercle ignobilis. Est inter Romanae
linguae Quirites eloquentissimus. In suo ore purissima residet Latinae linguae
proprietas. Sessitat in labris Suada diserta suis.
In labris Pitho stat reuerenda suis.
Suis labris persuadendi deam (quae a Graecis Pitho, a nobis Suada and Suadela
dicitur) sessitasse nemo nescit. Orationis and eloquij suauitate clarus. Est
Latinae linguae delicium. Romano splendore suum venustat eloquium. Ter se,
nitide, ac press loquitur. Mira inest verbis suis elegantia. Loquitur summa
verborum munditie atque luce. Nihil suo eloquio politius, excultius, eruditius.
Intelligunt omnes hunc tantum facundiori eloquio caeteris praestare, quantum
eruditione singulari. Tam facundus existimatur, vt si ipse Hermes coelo
descenderet, nec elegantiore, nec beatiore facundia vsurus videatur. Latin
loquax. Homo omnium facundissimus, que^ optimo iure Suadae medullam quis
dixerit. Quae cunque eloquitur incredibili verborum suauitate dulcescu^t.
Incredibili quadam suauitate verborum vtitur. Ei eloquenti illa Homerici senis
mella profluere videntur. Nihil non erudite, and ornate, nihil no^ destincte,
and ad amussim loquitur. Oration sua pura est, aperta and facilis. Dulcis sermo,
proprius tersus, exquisitus, and grauis. Eum dicas vberrimu^ quoddam
eloquentiae horreum. Musam quandam, non hominem loqui contenderes. Illi
rhetorica subseruit, and ad vnguem nota est. Illi domestica sunt, and
familiaria rhetorices praecepta. Dum loquitur, iurares esse Demosthenem, aut si
quis Demosthene superior esse potest. Exactissima dice^di facultate valet. Suo
ex ore fluit oration melle suauior. Sua oration adeo fluit, vt secum rapiat
auditorem. Hunc praeter summam eruditionem dos eloquentiae co^mendat. Mellita
quaedam suauitas suo ori insidet. Tam expolite loquitur, vt ne Cicero quidem
politius. Nihil suo sermon suauius, mellitius, nitidius. Est quaeda^ medulla
Suadae. Flexanimam quandam Suadelam in dicendo refert. Sui sermones e ditissimo
quodam pectore in morem lepidissimi fontis scaturiunt. Pure, integreque
loquitur. Sincere, candide, nitideque eloquitur. Incorruptus est illi sermo,
nemo enim tam ferreus, quem suus ille purus, syncerusque sermo non protinus
demulceat. Est etenim praestantissimus cum omni genere eruditionis, tum vel
maxim linguae Latialis gloria. Linguae Latialis gloria insignis. Nullus est
dicendi ca^dore eo superior. Vir in narrando mirae iucunditatis, and clarissimi
candoris. Tanta est eloquentia praeditus, vt omnes alios quoscunque putes aut
ranas Seriphias, aut Acanthias cicadas. Tanta venustas illius sermonibus inest,
and polities, and Sappho (dixerim) plusquam Attica, vt nihil suo eloquio sit
venustius. Vir dicendi maiestate, and orandi praestantia clarissimus. Hoc
homine facu^dius quicquam dicere mihi religio est. Nihil suo eloquio tersius,
cultius, castigatius, emaculatiusue audiri potest. Hic vnicus omnes dicendi
Veneres amplexatur. Musarum blanditiae and illecebrae ei sane quam frequentes
sunt. Est supra quam dici queat eloquentissimus. Est typus atque simulachrum
totiusque Latialis politiei effigies. Huius viri facundia plerisque videtur ad
formandam eloque^tiam sola sufficere. Rhetoru^ flosculis venustatus veteribus,
oratorijs lenocinijs, coloribus, pigmentis, cerussis, myrothecijs, apparatu,
luxu, diuitijs, opibus, blanditijs, illecebris, venustate, luce, munditia,
mundo, lepore, concinnitate, artificio, dexteritate, polity, ornamento, iocis,
salibus, varietatte, splendore, decore, honestamento, ornatu, stylo, gratia,
elegantia, eloquio, co^dimento, aculeis, melle, candore, festiuitate, nitore,
gemmis, cultu, delectu, eminentia, facundia, amoenitate, praestantia,
iucunditate, hilaritate, modestia, modulis, modulamine, harmonia, acrimonia,
acutia, concentu, solertia, suauitate, suauiloquio, suaueolentia, vrbanitate,
comitate, gratiaque verborum excomptus, comis, placidus, argutus, gratiosus. Ex
Ciceronis ludo, tanquam ex equo Troiano innumeri Oratoriae disciplinae heroes
fortissimi prodierunt, in quoru^ albo haud absurd annumerandus est. Huic est
eloquentia, and insignis oration, acuminis and solertiae plena. Suae orationi
inest ornatus, cum summa perspicuitate. Orationi suorum verborum inest
facilitas, and facilitati inuentionum non deest ornatus. In hoc homine reginam
rerum eloquentiam inuenias: in quo sunt Catonis grauitas, Caelij lenitas,
Gracchi impetus, Caesaris calor, Hortensijque distributio, and Ciceronis
opulentia.

Call. Engine. Telum, li. neut. genesis England. Anglia, ae. Britannia, Albion ab
albis montibus, Alter orbis. Britannia mayor. Angleterre. quasi Anglia terra.
S. Et Anglicanus, a, um. vel Anglicus, a, um. Ang. Of England. D' angleterre.
Anglia, quae Britannia ab eruditis dicitur, Insula est insignis in Oceano, quae
vndique a circumfuso pelago complexa est, nusquam iuncta co^tinenti: Sed ab
omni orb penitus diuisa. Quae quondam ab albis rupibus, quas mare vndique
abluit, Albion dicebatur. Hanc primum Troes incoluerunt, qui strata Troia
fugerunt excisam patriam, Paladisque oraculo class in hanc insulam appulerunt,
atque Gigantes tunc insulam colentes multis deuictos praelijs expugnauerunt.
Hanc postmodum lo^go temporis tractu Saxones (qui sunt illustres Alemaniae
populi) subiecere. Ea debellata, Angela imperatrix agros, fundu^, opes, atque
trophaea inter legatos Saxonicos contribuit. Nec non vt tum gentis, tum linguae
memoria semper maneret, Angela cuius ductu populata est, Angliam tellurem illam
denominauit: quanquam plaerique Angliam veluti orbis nostri Angulum praedicent
dictam. Sita est (inquit Plinius. lib. 4. cap. 16.) ex aduerso Galliae,
Germaniae, atque etiam Hispaniae, licet longiore interuallo. Agrippa
longitudinem eius prodidit esse. DCCC.M. passuum, latitudinem vero. CCC. M.
Call. and circuitus omnis insulae non amplius octies decies centenis millibus
passuum, atque sic minus ducentis milliarijs, quam Caesar supputarat. Pol.
Virg. Haec vero de recentioribus authoribus bona venia traducenda putaui.
Britannia insularu^ in Europa co^tinens maxima, a meridie in septentrionem
protenditur forma triquetra. A promontorio enim quod Vecte^ Insulam ad meridiem
prospicit, vsque Cathanesiam vltimam Scotiae partem, quae ab Orchadibus insulis
pelago non admodum latebroso, aut magno dirimitur, milliaria continentur. 600.
A Douero autem extrema Cantij fine, quae a Gallia non vltra. 30. distat mill.
in vltimum Cornubiae promontorium, quod Aermoricum respicit, Milliaria
habentur. 320. A quo rursus per Hibernicum mare ad septentrionem progrediens,
ad Cathanesiam integrae illius insulae partem supremam inueniuntur. 800. mill
passus. Ambitus insulae. 1800. continet milliaria, licet Caesar computauerit.
2000. Haec in imperia duo partitur. Pars australior Anglia dicta est, and
fertilior, and vrbibus frequentior, and Moribus ciuilior. Quae aute^
septentrionalior pars est, Scotia nu^cupatur, non montibus inaspera, atque
intentiss. frigoribus sterilissima. Anglia a Scotia ad Orie^tem Tueda, ad
occidentem Solueo fluuio dirimitur, mediterranea mons Cheuiota discriminat.
Obiacent Scotiae ad Occidentem in Hibernico mare insulae Hebrides, sieve Eboniae
numero. 43. Quarum prima and episcopali sede, and antiquiss. Druidum memoria
Mona erat, nostro oeuo anglo paret. Ad Septentrionem sunt. 31. Orcades insulae,
and secundum Pomponium. 30. Insulae Oceani septentrionalis vltra Britanniam,
and Hyberniam non nimium inter sese distantes, hordeo, piscibus, cuniculisque
locupletissimae, inter quas tenet principatu^ Pamonia, tu^ magnitudine alijs
excellens, tum sede episcopali, regio quoque castro pollita. Vltima omniu^ in
Scoti ditione est Thule, polo gaudens eleuato gradibus. 63. in qua cum Phoebus
Cancrum teneat (quod fit in Iunio mense) sunt sublustres noctes, and perbreues,
aut tenebrae nullae. Idiomata, vermaculique aut vulgares, quibus vtuntur
incolae, sermones sunt quinque. Videlicet Cornubicum, quo Cornubiens.
VVallicum, quo VVallici: Anglicum, quo Angli, parsque Scotiae bona: Hybernicum,
quo Hebrides insulae, and septentrionalis Scotiae finis: Gothicum, quo solae
orcades vtuntur. Episcopatus Anglia habet. xxij. aliquot praesulatus per
He^ricum praeteritu^ Angliae recolendissimae memoriae Regem conditi e numero
hoc dimittantur. Quoru^ octodecim primati Cantuariensi metropoliti
Subijciuntut, duoque Eborac. archipraesuli parent. gemina item gymnasia ibi
sunt, Scilicet Oxoniu^, and Ca^tabrigia, Academiae celebres, atque famosae.
Satrapias, quas comitatus, conuentusue appellant. 39. habet. Scotia vero. 13.
episcopatibus gaudet, quorum. 9. archiepiscopo primati. S. Andreae, caeteri
quoque Archipraesuli Glascuensi ac caeteris subsunt. Comitatus insunt. 22.
Opulescit haec Aere, Argento, Auro, Ferro, Lana puta, Mollicina, Pecude,
Pecore, Frume^to, cum omni granoru^ genere. Cum quibus materijs haec qua^ sit
dapsilis, nemo no^ nouit. Abu^dat illa lana subhespida, pecore hirsutulo,
Bouibus pumilibus, and piscibus. Lupos non habet Altera, Altera quam plurimos.
In treis quasi regiones diuidunt Angliam Tamesis, Sabrina, Humbrus, tria
Latebrosa flumina, atque ingentia. Scotiam item tria, Nempe Clauda, Forthea,
Tau^. Metropolis Angliae est Londinum, Scotiae regia Edinburgus, quem aliqui
Alata castra dicunt. Sanctionibus and municipalibus fruuntur Angli legibus:
ciuilibus Scoti subiuguntur. Accolae licet sint: gens tame^ genti omnifariam
aliena, and repugnax, Vbi vna amoena, ciuilis, et per omnia fida: altera denuo
ingrata, perfida, atque vulpina, omni authoritate, fideque omnium gentium orba.
Cum praepositi magnates omnino tenebriones maneant: Sunt etiam vulgares, and
populates paratragoediatores, ac rixatores. At Angloru^ genti in bello
austeritas, Scotorum est impietas. Arcubus isti praeualent, cum sint arquites,
and sagittarij validissimi: illi lanceolis semper cedunt, cum lancearij
plaerique existant in praelio. Inter hos rariss. foedus, dum isti de titulo
regali manuconsertum ex iure vocare conantur: illi seorsum propagare, and
renuere subtendunt, and meditantur. Haec Huloetus.

English. Anglicanus, Anglicus, a, um. Britannicus, a, um. Vernaculus, a, um.
D' angleterre. Vernaculus, Is all thing that takes beginning in the own
native country or place, as Vernacula lingua, The country language, or
English tongue, or the speech peculier and proper to one country or house.

Virg. In faith I envy not thy luck
I rather marvel how,
It comes to pass in all our fleldes
We are so troubled now.

I do not so much esteem or think of my self. Tanti me non facio, Hoc mihi
non sumo, non assumo, non arrogo, non adscisco. Ad hunc me sapientiae grac^um
peruenisse non puto. Eam mihi sapientiam contigisse non sentio. Fateor eo me
sapientiae non peruenisse, ea me sapientia non esse, non vsque adeo me sapere,
non ita mihi placeo. Non ita mihi assentior, non eam de me opinionem suscepi,
non ita me effero, non mihi tantum tribuo, non in me tantum statuo, pono, loco,
non ipse mihi tanti sum, non ita valde me amo, non ipse me tanti facio,
aestimo, pendo, puto reputo, duco.

F. ANTE. A.
F, A letter by Priscian nombred among the mutes, of others among the half
vowelles, because it begins with a vowel and ends in it self. This letter
also by another name is called Diga^ma Aeolicum, which in figure or form
does represent g g, It has the same sound with us that PH has among the
Grecians, whereby it happens that certain Greek words received among the
Latins, are written with F, which they write with PH As Fan^a, Fanu^. etc.
The ancient writers used this letter F as an aspiration, for they said
Fordium, Trafo, Vefo, For Hordium, Trah^, Veho. There were besides amongst them
which did use B, in stead of F, As Bruges, For that which we rather name
Fruges. To this lettre gave C. Caesar the force of a consonant, which to this
day remains in certain old wrytenges and monuments: Notwithstanding his
opinion in this point was never of all men allowed. It sounds more sharper
then V consonant, and the sound thereof rises and falls according to the
quality of his place, and the letter following. In the notes of antiquity F
was written for Fecit, Fuit, Foelix, Familia, Fit, Figura, Fides, Filius,
Fuluius, Februarius, Fur: Faustum quoque declarabat diem. Fable, or a tale.
Fabula, ae. f. g. Apologus, gi. m. genesis Vne fable. Fable, or to tell fables.
Fabulor, aris. Fabloyer. S. Fabler, or a teller of fables. Fabulator, oris, m.
ge. Un conteur de contes and fables. S. Fabulous, or faulse. Fabulosus, sa,
sum. Fabularis, re. Fabuleux. S. The moralization, or interpretation of a
fable. Mythologia, ae. foe. g. Affabulatio, vel fabulae explicatio. Call.

Fabulositie, or fabling. Fabulositas, tatis. foe. ge. Et Fabulose. Fabulously,
or lyingly. Face. Facies, ei. Vultus, us. m. genesis Face. H. Aliquando pro
integro corpore sumitur, and tunc per synecdochen. A strange face, or
countenance. Peregrina facies. Un face d' estraunge sort. H.

At the first face, at the first sight. Prima front, Primo aspectu, Prima
specie, Prima inspectione. De prime face. S.

Face deadly, or fearful countenance. Facies cadauerosa. Un regard
espouentable. H. Face to face. Aduersus, Eregione. Face to face, as whereof the
foreparts ar seen. Aduersus, a, um. Viz a viz. S. And whereof the hinder part
is seen, that is. Auersus, a, um. Destourne. S. Facility, easines, or an
inclination. Procliuitas, tatis, foe. ge. Facilite, aisance, ou inclination. S.
Et facilitas, tatis. Idem. Facile, or easy. Facilis, le. Facile, aise. S.
Facily, or easyly. Procliuiter, facile, Expedite. Facilement, aiseement. S.
Fact. Actus, tus. m. g. Factum, ti. n. g. Un faict^ S. Factoure. Actor,
Factor, Negotioru^ curator, Procurator. m. g. Qui fait quelque chose. Et

Call. Procureur. Call. Faculty. Facultas, it is. foe. g. Faculte. S. Fade, or to
fall as flowers do. Defloreo, es. Defloresco, scis. Se deflourer, perdre sa

after Plinius. Sometime subject to falling, as the heads of deares, which be
yearly cast. Subject a choir. S. Fadome. Vlna, ae. foe. g. Vne brassee. S.
Faggot. Fascis, is. m. g. Un faggot. S. Faggot, or a bauin of dry wood. Fascis
cocularius. Vne bouree. S. Fail, be feable of courage, or to be sick.
Aegroto, as. Estre malade. S. To fail, err, or to do amiss. Delinquere,

Feign. Vide Feign. Faynte. Languidus, a, um. Remissus, Sublestus, a, u^. Qui
languit. S. Fainte and imperfect color. Dilutus color. Fainte hearted.

or want of courage. Remissio, vel Dissolutio animi, Abiectio animi, Animi
demissio. Defaillance de courage. S. Fair. Almus, a, um. Bellus, a, um.
Honestus, ta tu^. Decorus, a, um. Venustus, Pulcher, chra, chrum. Speciosus, a,
um. Formosus, a, um. Beau. S. Vt Virgil. Quamuis ille niger, qua^uis tu
ca^didus esses:
O formose puer, nimium ne creed colori.
Although that he be swarthy black,
though thou be passing white:
Fair boy, let not thy fading form
thee over much delighte.
Is she so fair as they say she is? Est ne vt fertur forma? Est elle si belle
qu'on dit? S.

It is a fair or very beutifull virgin. Virgo est haud deformis, Facie venusta
virgo, Virgo electae pulchritudinis. Lectae venustatis virgo nobilissima.
Dotibus formae, pueritiaeque cunctis praeclara, Formae dotibus infignita, Virgo
insignis spectabilisque formae, Mulier decora facie, Liberali, and insigni
vultu, In ea est formae pulchritudo, and corporis proceritas pulchritudine
conspicua, Eximiae formae and aetatis adultae, Forma and aetate florens,
Aetatis flore, and formae veneratione inter reliquas insignis. Est decora, and
egregia forma, Virgo facili, and non incelebri vultu, Nihil ea ipsa formosius,
venustius, pulchrius, speciosius, Virgo insignitae pulchritudinis, Mira specie,
Pulchritudine eximia, Egregia forma, atque aetate integra, Elegantia formae
praedita, Exuperanti forma.

A fair little one. Pulchellus, la, lum. Assez beau. S.

a, um. Clair and serain, sans nuees. S. Fair and easily, fair and softely.
Suspenso gradu, Tacit, Tacito, Tacito pede. Sans bruit. S. Fair weather. Aer
tranquillus, Dies serena, vel tersa, Bona tempestas, Serena tempestas,
Liquidissima coeli tempestas, Coelum serenum. Beau temps. S. Fair, or fairly.

genesis A faulse prophet. Fauls prophet. S. And every word whose beginning is

a veritate seiunctum, abest a vero, aduersatur veritati, mendacium est, falsa
est omnis oration tua, quicquid loqueris, falso loqueris.

Opinio, onis. f. g. Bruit. Call. Fame or brute which lasts ever. Pertinax
fama. Constans fama, vel rumor, Firmus rumor. If thou fynishe thy work, thy
fame shall be immortal. Si tua scripta ad exitum perduces, perficies, conficies,
absolues, si tuis scriptis finem impones, extremam manum impones: perpetua
erit, aeterna, immortalis tua fama, nunquam deficiet, consenescet, peribit,
obscurabitur, extinguetur, delebitur, nulla dies tuam famam terminabit, nullum
temporis spatium circumscribet, nulla vetustas corrumpet, vigebit in omnes
annos tua fama, omnis te posteritas cognoscet, tuas lauds excipiet ac
tuebitur, nomen tuum immortalitati commendabis, immortalitate donabis,
immortalitatis praemium consequeris, non simul cum corpore mors tuum nome^
extinguet, delebit, auferet, tuum nomen ab interitu vindicabis, in hominu^
memoria tenebis, aeterna laud illustrabis, decorabis, afficies, ornabis, de te
posteritas omnis audiet, ac loquetur.

est, obstrictus est, amicitia nostra summa^ ad familiaritate^ peruenit.

Fan to fan corn. Ventilabrum, bri. n. ge. Flabellum, li. n. g. Pala, lae.

Esuentement. Call. Fantasy. Phantasia, ae. Visio, Visum, si. n. g. Fantasy.
Phantasiae, Be certain fantasies which be thus defined. Some say they be
affections which is none other but the memory wrapped, or corruption of
understanding. Other affirm the same to be an operation of the power
fantastical, that is to say: a moving from the carnal sense. Certain other
also take them to be of the substance or power animal, keeper of the primative
figures or forms in their natural se^ce. Of this may you read more at large
in the.4. book of Vel^ur. cap. 9. Fantasy, will, or mind of any man.
Intentio, Se^tentia, Sensus, Arbitratus, tus. m. g. Fantasy and volunte d' vne
person. S. To, or according to my mind. Ad meum sensum, Ad arbitrium, Meo
arbitratu. Quomodo mihi persuadeo, Meis auspicijs. A, ou selon ma fantasy. S.
Mea sententia, Quantum ego opinione auguror.

ti. Erratum, ti. Mendum, di. Menda, dae. Noxa, ae. Noxia, ae. Offensa, sae.
Peccatum, ti. Praeuaricatio, onis. foe. g. Fault. S. I am not in fault. In me
conferenda causa non est, culpa vaco, culpam ego non sustineo, expers culpae
sum, affinis culpae non sum, purus a culpa sum, culpam ignoro, longissime absum
a culpa, long remotus a culpa sum, tam absum a culpa, quam qui maxim, culpae
mihi non sum co^scius, extra culpam sum, in culpa non sum.

To pardon a fault. Noxam remittere. Pardonner vne fault. S.

To punish a fault. Peccatum in altero vindicare. Punir vne fault. S.

It is my fault. Mea culpa est. C' est ma propre fault.

It is not my fault, or I am not in fault. Abest a me culpa, Noxia careo. Ce
n'est point ma fault.

It is thy fault. Flagitium tuum est, a te peccatum est, Penes te culpa est,
Residet eius rei in te culpa, In te haeret omnis haec culpa. C'est ta fault.

If it be our fault. Si est nostrum peccatum. Si c' est nostre fault. S.

Faulty to be, or to be in fault. Esse in noxia, Teneri culpa. Estre en
fault. S. Not to be in fault. Noxijs vacuum esse, culpa vacare, vitio carere,
Extra culpam esse. N' estre point in fault. S.

To do, or commit a fault. Commereri culpam vel noxiam, Noxiam admittere,
Offendere, Culpam in se admittere, Culpam contrahere. Fair quelque fault. S.

To lay the fault on an other. Culpam confer in alterum, Auertere culpa^ in
alterum. Causam in aliquem confer, Culpam in alteru^ traijcere, vel
transfer. Reiecter la fault sur autruy. S

vtaris, gratiam tuam apud populum non tua, sed tuorum culpa exstinxit, ex amore
populi effluxisti.

Feathers bearing. Penniger, ra, rum. Plumiger, ra, rum. Qui a plumes. Feathers
growinge right up in the top of a birds head, as of a Capon, Heron, Lark,

To harken in few words. Ascultare paucis.

Fewest of all. Paucissimus, a, um. Trespeu. S. Fewnes in nombre. Paucitas,
tatis. foe. genesis Petite nombre. S. Fever. Febris, is, f. genesis Fiebure. S. Et
Febricula, diminut. Ang. An easy or short fever. Fieburette ou petite fiebure.
S. Et Febrilis, le. Angl. Pertayninge to the fever. De fiebure. S. Fever
called a burninge fever, properlye happeninge about the Caniculer days.
Solstitialis aegritudo, vel febris. Febris ardens. Fiebure Chaulde. S. Fever
continual. Febris continua. co^tinuata, Perpetua, assidua, continens. Fiebure
continue. S. Fever quotidian which comes of fleame. Amphimerina febris.
Quotidiane. S. Fever of one day. Diaria febris. Ephemera febris. Fieure d'un
iour. H. Fever tertian. Febris tertiana. Fiebure tierce. S. Fever quartan.
Quartana febris. Fiebure quarte. S. Fever that consumes, called a consuminge
fever, or mortal fever. Hectica febris, Marasmus. Fiebure etique. H. Fever
which comes by course or fittes, being a tercian, or quartan. Periodica
febris. Call. Fever which is a burninge, or hot fever. Pyretus. Fever which is
a tertian and a half, some call it half a tertian, and it vexes in his
course. 36. hours. Semitritaeon, Hemitritaeon.*. Perot. Fever to have, or to
be feuerous, or sick of the fever. Febrio, is. Febricito, as. Pati febrim.
Auoir la fiebure. S. The fever goes away. Decedit febris, Decrescit febris,
Inclinat se febris, Remittit febris. La fiebure sen va. S.

To drive away the fever. Depellere febrem, Discutere febrem, Liberare aliquem
febre, Soluere febrem, Submouere, To^lere. Chassar ou oster la fiebure. S.

The fever comes again, at his day or time. Accedit febris, Redit febris,
Recurrit, Repetit, Reuertitur febris. La fiebure return son iour. S.

Fit, or the recourse of the fever. Paroxysmus, Accessio, Accessus sebris.
Accez de fiebure. S.

Feuerous or full of the fever. Febriculosus, a, um. Fiebureux. S. The heart
never feels the fever. Febrium morbos non sentit ceruus. Plin.

To seek remedy for the fever. Remediu^ quaerere febri. Plin.

I have the fever no more, or the fever has left me. Febris ex toto quieuit.
Ie n'ay plus de fieure.

Sweatinge drives away the fever. Febrem finiunt sudores. Celsus.

Feuerfewe herb. Parthenium, Solis oculus, Officin. Matricaria, Amaracus.
Matricaire, Matrone, Cotula foetida. H. Of the nature of this herb, read the.
79. leaf of the second volume of master Turner his Herball.
F. ANTE. I.

Fiere spark. Scintilla, quae e silice, aut ignario emicat. Estincelle. S. Vt
Virg. Ac primum silicis scintillam excudit Achates:
Suscepitque ignem folijs, atque arida circum
Nutrimenta dedit: rapuitque in fomite flamma^.
And first Achates out of flinte
the sparkles made to fly:
He took the fiere with leaves, and laid
about it sticks were dry:
And causde at length the parched wodde
to cast a flame on hye.

couuert and qui ne luist point. Fiere flaminge. Flamma, ae. foe. genesis Flamb.

S. Fig. Ficus, cus. foe. genesis Mart. Et ficus, ci. foe. genesis Horat. Figue. S.
Nam ficus, ci. m. g. Est morbi genus. Vt Martial. ad Caecilianum. Cum dixi
ficus, rides quasi barbara verba,
Et dici ficos Caeciliane iubes.
Dicemus ficus, quas scimus in arbore nasci:
Dicemus ficos Caeciliane tuos.
Caecilian when I Ficus said,
thou floutedst me therefore:
And badste me rather Ficos say,
and Ficus use no more.
We will to call them Ficus which,
we know on trees to spring,
And thy disseases Ficos name:
for likeness of the thing.

F. ANTE. O.
FOe. Hostis, is. Inimicus, Iniquus, Saeuus. Ennemi. You are to much our foe,
or ennemy. Aduersarium nimis grauem, nimis acrem, infensum, acerbum,
vehementem, crudelem te habemus, nimis acerbus, nimis aduersus, nimium grauis
atque infe^sus nobis es, oppugnas nos quam potes acerrime, and grauissime,
nullam aduersus nos iniuria^ praetermittis. Nulla nos iniuria, nulla re non
lacessis, tuis contra nos viribus vteris, tua^ in nos vim confers, omnia
conaris, nihil non agis, moves, tentas, experiris, machinaris ad perniciem
nostra^, aduersario te vtimur nimis acerbo, nimis infenso: agis contra nos,
pugnas aduersus nos, irruis in nos, quo potes impetu, impetu quam potes maximo,
eo impetu, qui potest esse maximus.

Foyne, or to give a foyne, or to prick. Pungo, is, pupugi. Compungo, is.
Lancinare. Poindre. S. A sword, which by it self can give no prick or foyne.
Gladius, qui per se pungere non potest. Cicero.

Foyne, or a prick. Punctus, tus. m. g. Et Punctiuncula, lae. diminut. A little
prick. Foyning, or a prickinge. Punctio, onis. foem. genesis Poignement. S.
Foyning, or pricking. Pungens, it is. part. Poignant. S. Foyning, or with a
foyne. Pu^ctim. En poignant. Call. Foist, called a great or light ship. Corbita,
Liburna, Liburnica, Liburnum, ni. n. g. Fuste. Pals. To be foysty, as not
sweet. Muceo, es. Estre moisi.

To wax foisty or musty. Mucesco, scis. Deuenir moisi. S.

Foistied, mustied, or vinoed. Mucidus, da, dum. Moisi. S. Fold for sheep.

Et Caula, lae. f. g. Idem. Fold, or wrappe together. Complico, as. Plico, as.
Plier. S. Et Conuoluo, is. Inuoluo, is. Obuoluo, is. Circumplico, as. Implico,

ge. Folly. S. Vide Foolish. Folk or cominune people. Plebs, bis. Vulgus, gi.

the folk or people, or perteining to them. Commun, vulgaire. S. Follow.
Assequor, eris. Imitor, aris. Produco, is. Sector, aris. Sequor, eris.
Co^sequor, eris. Suyure. Follow after. Prosequor, eris. Suyure and aller apres.
S Follow after hand, or forthwith immediately. Co^sequor, eris. Subsequor, eris.
Follow, or to pursue in diligence. Sector, aris. Co^sector, taris. Suyure ou
poursuyure en diligence. S. Follow, or to immitate Cicero. Authorem Ciceronem
habere. Ensuyure Cicero. S. Follow by course, or turn ordinately. Alterno, as.
Subalterno, as. Alterner. S. Follow counsel. Tenere consilium. Follow examples
manners or trade of other. Aemulor, aris. Imitor, aris. Et Respondeo, es. (cum
datiuo, vt Respo^det patri. He folowes his father.) Zelo, as. Zelor, aris.
Imiter. S. Et Zelotes, He that assayeth to follow the steps of other. If you
intend to follow your ancestors, it is necessary that you apply your study
to virtue. Si tuorum maiorum laudibus respondere vis, si maiores tuos refer
vis, cupis imitari, si te dignum maioribus tuis praebere studes: vt ad
virtutem, in virtutem incumbas, ad virtutem studia tua conferas, opus est,
nauari a te opera^ virtuti oportet, debes virtutem colere, tui muneris, tui
officij, tuarum partium est, non potes no^ virtuti operam dare, non licet tibi
virtutem negligere, hoc ad te pertinet, in te co^uenit, a te postulatur, atque
adeo, tanquam debita res exigitur.

Foot. Pes, dis. m. g. Le pied. S. Et Pediolus, li. m. ge. Pediculus, li. mas.
ge. Un petit pied. S. Ang. A little or short foot. Et Pedalis, le. Ang. Of a
foot. Vt Pedale spatium. Espace d'vn pied. S. Et Pedaneus, a, um. Ang. The
quantity of a foot in breadth or distaunce, D'vn pied. S. And every xii.
inches by circumlocution is called Pes, because a foot contains so much.
Also among the old writers, the foot contained syxtene fyngers breadth. Foot
and a half. Sesquipes, dis. m. g. Pied and demi. Et Sesquipedalis, le, Adiect.
D'vn pied and demi S. Half a foot. Semipes, dis. m. g. Demi pied. S. Et
Semipedalis, le. Adiect. Of half a foot. De demi pied. S.

d'aucun pour le supplier. S.

foe. g. La plant des pieds. S. Et Plantaris, re. Ang. Any thing pertaining to

and large feet. Pansus, sa, sum. Qui ont les pieds larges. S. Footed round
like a Sparrowe. Struthopes, dis. * Footed flat, or which has flat or
plain feet. Palmipes, vel Planipes, edis. Qui ha les pieds plats. For.
Etenim, Nam, Na^que, Nempe, Ob, Per, vt per aetatem, Prae, Pro, Propter, Quia,
Secundum. Vt secundum rempub. Super, Vt super laudem. Pour ou car. S. Namque
est coniunct. Casual. and semper ponitur in principio sententiae. For he is
chief of the city. Etenim est primus ciuitatis. Cicer. What means this
naughty knave? for if there be any mischief he is the author, setter on, or
ring leader. Quidnam hic vult veterator sibi? nam si hic mali est quicquam,
hem illic est huic rei caput. Terent.

For that which you can not, no man shall be able to do. Namque quod tu non
poteris, nemo poterit. Cicero. For the nonce. Ob industriam, De industria,
Dedita opera. Tout de gre. S. For fear. Prae formidine. Plaut. De grand paour.
S. This trouble is for your love. Turba haec propter te est facta. Pour l'
amor de toy. etc.

I gave twenty pound for them both. Viginti minas pro ambobus dedi. Terent.

For an other cause, or matter then that. Praeter propter.* Ob aliam causam vel
rem. For my part. Pro mea part. Pour ma part. S. For a suertie. Pro comperto,
Pro explorato. Pour certainte. S. For as much as. Cum, Eo, Inquantum, Proin,
Quandoquidem, Quatenus, Quatinus, Quia, Quippe, Quoniam, Quia enim, Quod,
Propterea quod, Quippe quia, Quoniam quidem, Vtpote. Pourtant que. S. For a
truth. Reuera, Pro certo. Pour certain. S. For because. Nempe quia, Siquidem.
Car. S. For ever. Perpetuo, Perpetuum, In aeuum, Ad infinitum, In aeternum, In
perpetuum, Aeternum, Omne ad tempus, In modum perpetuum. A iamais, a tousiours.
S. For how much, or for what price or value. Qua^ti. De quelle valeur. S. For
my self. Pro me ipso. For so much, or for that price or value. Tanti. Autant.
S. For that price, or value. Tanti, Tantidem. Idem. For that time. I am tum.
Even then. For that matter, or purpose. Ob eam rem. For this, therefore, or for
this cause. Idcirco, Ideo, Ob id, Ex hoc, Propter hanc causam. Propterea.
Pource S. For what cause, consideration, occasion, or purpose? Qamobrem?

I cannot warrant or defend you from all force, violence, or invasion. Ego tibi
a vi nihil praestare possum, vim tibi nullam factum iri, illatum iri, allatum
iri, oblatum iri, pro certo non polliceor, plane non affirmo, tutum a vi te
futurum, ne pro certo existimes. nullam fore vim, explorate, asseueranter,
certo promittere non audeo. ea te cura prorsus non libero, non eximo, eam tibi
curam plane non eximo, non adimo, non aufero: ne quando tibi vis inferatur
vlla, ne quam aliqua^do vim feras, sustineas, patiare, sentias, experiaris, ne
quid aliquando per vim patiaris.

nisu. A toute force. With all force, and power.

casus obliuiscereris, ex animo tuo, me^te, memoria deleres, euelleres: si

tua pristina mala, tuos casus, tuorum temporum varietatem obliuione voluntaria

Fortress. Arx, cis. Propugnaculum, Vallus, Vallu^, li. n. g. Fortress. S.
Fortunate. Beatus, Candidus, Foelix, Fortunatus, Prosper, ra, rum. Prosperus,
a, um. Secundus, a, um. Bien fortune. S. There is no man more fortunate then
you, or you are fortunate. Tuas fortunas nemo superat. aequas omnium fortunas.
prospere tecum agitur, sic, vt inuidere nemini possis. foelicitate conferri
tecum fortasse multi, praeferri tibi, anteferri, praeponi, anteponi, certe nemo
potest. ea fortuna vteris, quae potest esse maxima, tam beatus es, quam qui
maxim. ita beatus es, vt nemo magis. ijs vel ornamentis, vel praesidijs
redundas, quibus maiora esse nulla possunt. nihil non optabile consecutus es.
nihil ad foelicitatem tibi deest. ea possides, ac tenes, quae beatam vitam
efficiant, quae sunt in vita expetenda, quae qui possidet, fortunam accusare
nullo pacto possit, nullius fortunam sibi exoptare debeat. nemo est paratior ab
ijs rebus, in quibus sita foelicitas est. rebus omnibus affluis. non est, quod
quidquam desideres. optimus est rerum tuarum status. tibi satis est vel
ingenij, vel fortunae ad been beateque viuendum. animi, and fortunae bona sic
in te sunt, vt in nullo magis.

Fortuneement. S. Fortune. Conditio, onis. Euentus, us. Fortuna, ae. Sors, it is.
Fors, it is. Nemesis. Fortune. S. I exhort, persuade, or council you, to give
as little credit as you can to fortune. Te hortor, tibi suadeo, author tibi sum,
ne fortunae fidem habeas, confidas, credas. ne te fortunae committas, credas,
tribuas. ne fortunae potestati te committas, ne multum in fortuna ponas. ne
fidam, stabilem, firmam, constantem, certam fortunam ducas. vt a fortuna
caueas, caute agas cum fortuna. minimum tibi de fortuna pollicearis, spem in
fortuna nullam reponas, constituas. vt fortunae instabilitatem, leuitatem,
inconstantiam, varietatem, mutationem, varios casus, vicissitudinem extimescas.

fauebit, facilis erit, facilem se tibi, ac benignam praebebit, si tibi optime
cum fortuna conueniet, si fortuna vteris prospera, secunda, facili, benigna, si

status, res tibi ad voluntatem fluent, commodis abundabis: amicorum copia
florebis, amicorum multitudinem non desiderabis: sin ages infoeliciter, fortuna
vteris aduersa, tuis commodis, atque optatis aduersabitur fortuna, inimicam
fortunam experieris, tuis optatis fortuna non respondebit, male tibi cum
fortuna conueniet, male tecum agetur, incommode tibi erit, casus aliquis rerum
tuarum tranquillitatem perturbabit, perculsus fortunae vi iacebis, languebis,
iacebit fortuna tua, iacebunt res tuae, commodorum inopia laborabis, aliqua te
premet, vrgebit difficultas, infesta fortuna vteris, infensa, iniqua, aduersa,
difficili, dura, acerba, parum prospera, parum secunda, parum facili, parum
benigna: tum amicos requires, amicorum inopia laborabis, omnes te destituent,
deserent, a te desciscent, discedent, recedent.

as many words begin with full, as full of corners, full of malice, full of
words and such like, other then be here specified, therefore ye shall seek
for them in the principal word, as for Malicius, seek Malice, and so of the
rest.

Furor, Rabies, ei. f. g. Fureur. S. Furies, according to the opinon of Cicero,
they be three passions of the mind, which carye men headlong to all
wickedness, he calls the first Ire, which desires reuengement: The next
covetousness, a continual serching for riches: and the third lust, which
always coueteth delectaton and pleasure. Euripides in Oreste, says that in
heaven they are called Dirae, In earth Furiae: And in hell Eumenides. The
poets feign them the daughters of Nox and Acheron, and name them Alecto,
Megaera, Tisiphone. Furious to wax, or to become furious. Furere, Furore
ingrauescere, Furorem co^cipere ex maleficio. Deuenir furieux. S. Furious, or
full of fury. Furibundus, a, um. Plein de rage. Furious, or mad. Furiosus,
Vesanus, a, um. Rabidus, da, du^. Saeuus, a, um. Furialis, le. Captus furore.
Furieux. S. He became so furious and mad, that he never recovered his right
wits again. Vi doloris ita insaniuit, vt mente^, rectu^ animi sensum,
rationem nunqua^ receperit, in perpetuum amiserit, ad sanitate^ nunquam
redierit. insaniae morbo ita est affectus, in morbu^ insaniae ita incidit, vt
nunquam postea conualuerit, vt furore^ nunquam deposuerit, vt bonam mente^
nunquam reuocauerit, vt a furo^e, a dementia nunquam se ad sanitatem retulerit.
ita discessit a mente, ita mentem perdidit, vt illum nemo postea ratione
praeditum viderit.

G. ANTE. A.
G, A letter in the number of the mutes, which often in the preterfect te^ce of
verbes is changed into ct, as Legor, lectus, Agor, actus: Sometime into S, as
Spargo, sparsi, Mergo, mersi: Not seldom into X, vt Rego, rexi. Pingo, pinxi:
And certain Greek words written in that tongue with (...), when they are
changed into latin are written with G, vt (...), latin Cygnus, In the notes
of antiquity G signified Gaudium, Gens, Genius, Gellius, Gaius, and Gratia.
Also Ga, Grauis. etc. Gable of a ship, or anchor. Funis anchorarius,
Prymnesium, ^^etinaculum, Anchorale, Funis nauticus. Le chable de l' ancre. H.
Gabriell th'archaungell, signifying the might and puissaunce of God. Gabriel,
elis. m. g. Gadde* goade, or rod, with a prick at the end to drive oxen.
Stirnulus, li. m. g. Esguillon. S. Gadde, or rod to measure ground. Gruma,
Chorobates* ae. Vitr. Gadde or whippe. Flagellu^, li. n. g. Fouet, ou escourgee
Gadde, or go a gadding. Peregrinor, aris. Vago, as. Vagor, aris. Ito, as.
Tracasser, ou alle^ ca and la. S. Gadder about. Vagabundus, a, um. Vagus, a,
um. Vagabond. S. Gadding. Peregrinatio, onis. foe. g. Gaddingly, as they that
went on pilgrimage. Peregre, Vage. Ca et la, par ci par la. S. Gage, pledge, or
to lay to gage, or to wage. Ponere pignori, Pignora dare, Pignerare, Dare
pignori, Opponere pignori, Oppignerare, Dare in pignus. Bailler engage,
Engager. S. To redeame a gage. Repignero, as. Desgager un gage. S.

gage son manteau.

S.

To take a gage. Pignus capere. Prendre gage. S.

Gaged. Vide Gauged. Gaggle like a goose. Glacito, as. Author Philom. Strepo,
is, ui. vt Virgil. Nam neque Vario videor nec dicere Cinna
Digna: sed argutos inter strepere anser olores.
For neither yet with Varius verse
Nor Cinna-s mine compare:
I seem a gagglyng goose mong ^u annes
Of heavenly tunes that are.

Ang. A little or young gander. Et Anserinus, a, um. Of a gander. D' un iar ou
iars. Ganges, a River in Italy, which deuideth all India, and draws with it
golden sands. The Grecians call it Physon, and the scriptures countteh it
among those which flow forth of Paradise. Some say the heads or springes
thereof be uncertain, and that it flows as the river Nilus: other say, it
takes beginning in the mountains of Scythia, and that thyrtye ryuers flow or
come to it. The narrowyst place thereof is eight miles broad, and the broadest
twenty: where it is shallowest it is an hundred foot deep. it was first named
Ganges of Ganges an Ethiopian king. Of this read the. 65. chapter of Julius
Solinus, where he (besides other things) reports that in this river are
Eales of thyrty foot long. Ganges, is, vel itis. masc. genesis Gape. Dehisco,
scis. Hio, as. Hiasco, scis. Oscito, as. Oscitor, aris. Pandiculor, ris.

aris. Rimas agere. Se fendre. S. Gape for a pray. Cornicor, aris. Gape, or
yawne for lack of sleep, or after sleep, or for sluggyshenes. Hisco, scis,

scis. S' ouurir. Call. Gaper. Hiator, toris. m. g.* Gaping. Hiatus, us.

Bordure ou brodure d' habillement. Segmentu^ aliqua^do pro vest ponitur. Vt
Ovid. Quid de vest loquar? non iam segme^ta requiro,
Nec quae de Tyri^ murice lana rubet.
What shall I speak of garments here?
No guarded robes I crave,
Nor yet what woolle of Tyrie land
With purple shines brave.
Guard, purle, or trayle of any garment, or it may be said any bourders or
trayles fynely wrought with small pieces fastened thereto be it metal or
timber. Or it may be esteamed that sort of guard or welte which besides the
guard is edged with a small lace, flat or round upon the guard. Segmentum,
And that which is so guarded, purfled, trayled, dressed, edged, or trimmed, is
said, Segmentatus, a, um. * One of the Guard. Satelles, Stipator, Praetorianus
miles. Archer de la guard. H.

cuiquam, donis quenquam afficere, donare quenquam munere, dona in quenquam
confer, munera confer, liberalis in quenquam esse, liberalitate vti,
liberalitatem exercere, vel muneribus afficere.

Godhead. Deitas, Diuinitas, Nume^, inis. n. g. Deite. Godly joy. Eudoxia.
Godly, or holy. Diuus, a, um. Dius, a, um. Pius, a, u^. Divine. Call. Godly, or
of God. Diuinitus. Diuinement, de dieu. Godly, or pertaining to God. Diuinus,
a, um. De dieu, Apartenant a dieu. Call. Gods power or will. Numen, inis. n. g.
La volonte and puissance de dieu. Call. Gods wrath, anger, or malison. Sacra
fulmina, Theomenia. Here shall thou have (gentle reader) a table, or (as mine
author terms it) a Pantheon of Gods and Goddesses: because their names are
found often in profane authoures, I thought not unmeet for the purpose to
leave the^ in place, with some additio^s, that young gra^marians reading such
authors, may the sooner find for their purpose.

Jupiter, the father or king of Gods, or God of hospitality. Jupiter,
Opitulus, Papaeus, Pheretrius, Vedius, Diespater, Aegiochus, Chaonius pater,
Dictaeus rex, Tonans panomphaeus, Agenoreus iuuencus, Ammon. Jupiter. S. Whom
the Greeks honored as a God, calling him father and king of Gods, albeit they
knew him a very mortal man, he was witty, valeaunt, and very desierous of women
and maidens, and was had in such estimation among the Gentiles, that they
attributed to him souerainetie, and did ascribe to him the rule of
hospitality, as the peculiar God thereof. Unto whom according to the
diversity of their peticio^s, they gave diverse and sundry names: As for
breach of amity among the^ of the house, they called for vengeance to Jupiter
philius: For league or truce broken, they called him Jupiter Enhorcius: for any
domestical offenses done by the good man of the house, or his geste, they
called him Jupiter Xenius, for consanguinitie or kyndred, they called on
Jupiter Homoginus: And finally, for the traiterous bewraying of secret
counsel had between ^aythfull companions they called him Jupiter Heterius.

God of Battle. Mars, Mauors, Bellator deus, Pater Quirinus, Gradiuus,
Marspiter, Sithonius dux. Mars. S. Bying and sellinge, or that has the
governance of men's minds. Vertu^nus, ni. m. g. Bowndes and buttinges of
land. Terminus deus. Eloquence, or messenger of Gods. Mercurius, Trismegistus,

Interpres deoru^. Mercure. S. Excess, prodigality, or superfluity. Comos,

Myagrus, Myodes. Gardaynes. Mutunus, Priapus, Lampsacides, Lampsacenus,
Hellespo^tiacus deus. Hell. Pluto, Quietalis, Orcus, Summanus, Vragus, Dis,
Runsor, Lethaeus tyra^nus, Saturnius dux, Rex vmbrarum, Erebi, Noctis.
Hylrigges. Iugantinus deus. Mischief. Veiouis. Panyms, or father to Jupiter.

herba, Scelerata, Officin. Pes corui. Bacinet. H. Goldney fish. Aurata, Orata,
tae. f. g. Brame de mer. H Golias, or Goliath a Philistian of an exceadinge
stature, which was as the story rehearses, six cubits and a hand breadth
high, and had an helmet of brass on his head, and a coat of mayle about him,
ye weight of his coat of mayle was 5000. sicles of brass, and he ware boots
of brass, and a shield of brass upon his shoulders. The shafte of his spear
was like a weauers beam, and his spear head weyed six hundred sicles of
iron. Whom David a child did vanquishe in battle, as you shall read more
largely in the Bible. 1. Reg. cap. 17. Gomme. Vide Gum. Gone about or over.
Peragratus, Lustratus, a, um. vt Propter disce^di cupiditatem videmus vltimas
terras esse peragratas, Cic. We see yt for love of learning the farthest
parts of the earth are gone and trauayled over. Gone away. Refugus, a, u^.
vt Refugi capilli. Here gone away, or flying back. Gonge, draft, or siege,
privy, or Jacques. Forica, Oletum, ti. n. g. Latrina, ae. f. g. Retraict, prive.
H. Good. Bellus, a, um. (vt Bellus homo,) Bonus, a, u^. Praeclarus, a, um.
Probus, a, um. Rectus, a, um. Bon. S. Good and fair. Pulcher. Vide Fair.
Good, or very good. Perbonus, na, number. Perbellus, la, lum. Fort bon. S. Good
beauty, or co^plexio^. Egregia forma. Teren. Good beginning, and a good and
merry ending. Tragicum principium, Comicus finis. Goodd chance. Fors fortuna.
Terent. Bonne adventure. S. Good chance, fortune, luck, prosperity, or
success. Res secundae. Prosperity. S. Good cheap. Vilitas, tatis. foem. genesis
Bon march vilete. S. Good cheap being, or not dear, or of a small price.
vilis, le. De peau valeure, vile, de vile price. S. Good cheap to be. Vileo,
es. Estre vile. S. Good citezin. Bonus ciuis. Bon citoyen. See that thou play
the good citezin, or endeavor to behave thy self like a good citezin. Da
operam, enitere, vt bonum te ciuem praebeas, praestes, vt boni ciuis parts
tucare, sustineas, agas, exequare* vt boni ciuis officio satisfacias. vt ea
praestes, quae bonum ciuem decent, quae expectantur ab eo, qui boni ciuis nomen
aucupatur. noli co^mittere, cave ne boni ciuis in officio reprehendaris. ne
boni ciuis officium praetermittas. ne quid a te fiat, ne quid committatur bono
ciue minus dignum, indecorum bono ciui, ne ciuis eius, qui ciuitate dignus
haberi velit, parts in te requirantur, officium in te desideretur. obcunda
tibi sunt, praestanda sunt, non indiligenter, aut languide munera boni ciuis.

G. ANTE. R.
GRace and delectablenes that one has in gesture and speech. Lepor, oris.
Lepos, ris. Venustas, tatis. Vrbanitas, tatis. foe. ge. La bonne grace and
bienscance qu' ha aucun en parler. S. Grace that a body has when that which
he says or does, becomes him well. Decor, coris. m. g. La grace qu' ha vne
person, quand ce qu' elle dit ou fait luy sied bien. S. To give grace.
Decoro, as. Bailler grace. S.

With grace. Decore. Auec grace. S. Cum gratia.

Grace, or favor. Gratia, ae. foe. g. Grace. S. Graceles, or with out
delectation. Illepidus, a, um. Infacundus, Inconcinnus, na, number. Qui ha
mauuaise grace. S. Graces. Gratiae, arum. f. g. These are feigned three, Aglaia,
Thalia, Euphrosine, The daughters (as Hesiodus writes) either of Jupiter and
Eurymone, or else of Bacchus and Venus: Whom antiquity did painte naked,
because friendship and good will among friends ought to be naked, simple and
void of couine and deceit: They were three in number, for that the one gives
the other receives, and the third requiteth: they seemed young, because the
memory of a benefit, ought never to cease or wax old: cherefull and smyling,
for that a benefit should be bestowed cherefully: Two of them looked toward
the beholders, and the third turned her back, whereby is signified that a
benefit ought to be requited, with greater good will: They were knitte
together, showing thereby the knott of friendship, should be indissoluble.
Gracious. Vrbanus, a, um, Gratiosus, sa, sum. Gratieux. Call. Graciously, or
with good grace. Benign, Blande, Vrbanatim, Vrbane, Facunde, Eleganter. De
bonne grace. S. Gradation. Climax, Gradatio, onis. foe. g. Degree. Graffe.
Insero, ris, seui. Pango, is. Planto, as. Sero, is, seui, satum. Emplastro,
tras. Admitto, it is. Enter les arbres. S. Graffe between the rind and the
wood. Inoculo, as. Enter en escusson. S. Graffe, or a plant. Insitium,
*Pla^tarium, Calamus, mi. Clabula, lae. Clauola, lae. Insitum, ti. neut. ge.
Greffe de quoy on ente, vne ente. S. Graffed. Insitus, ta, tum. Ente. S. Which
is graffed and not natural. Insitiuus, ua, uum. vel Insititius, a, um. Qui est
ente, and non point naturel. S.

Cigalle. S. vt Virg. At mecum raucis tua dum vestigia lustro:
Sole sub ardenti resonant arbusta cicadis.
But while that I thy footesteps seek
The grassehoppes hoarce with me,
In parching son, make shrubs resounde
These mourning tunes for thee.

Come out of Greece. It is called diversely by aucthours, for yt there were in
Greece 18. Regions, and every of them had his several dominatour, until they
were brought into subjection of the infidels, where as they now remain, and
be thus named. Acarnania, Achaia, Aetolia, Argos, Attica, Boeotia, Doris,
Phthiotis, Epirus, Laconia, Locris, Macedonia, Magnesia, Megaris, Messenia,
Phocis, Thessalia, Thracia. All which be now barbarous, and as vile
handmaydes in the servitude of the most cruel ennemy to Christian religion,
the great Turk, which before were the mother or well of eloquence, and of all
learning, the more is to be lamented. Greecian, or Greek. Graecus, a, um.

the long gutte. Intestinum rectum, Longanon, Ileos. Le long boyau. S. Gutte

walls. Andron, onos. m. ge. Gutter of a house. Compluuium, uij. n. g. Columel.
Gutters. Colliquiae, arum, Colliciae, arum. foe. genesis Gouttieres. S. G. Ante Y.
Look G. Ante. I.
H. ANTE. A.
H, An asperation, or note of asperation, composed of the two Greek
aspirations, which are figured in this sort ' ' we call it in our tongue
ach, others call it Ha, some Asche, and so diverse diversely, according to the
variety of their tongues. It was used of late that H in these two words
Nihil and Mihi, was pronounced ch, as Nichil Michi, but it is now (and that
worthily) rejected. The like fault had they in pronouncing the vowels with
asperations, and this is used by some yet: but they are justly reprehended in
these verses of Catul. against Arrius. Chommoda dicebat, si qua^do co^moda
vellet
dicere, and hinsidias Arrius insidias.
Arri' often spak cho^moda, when say co^moda would he,
Also for Insidias uttered Hinsidias.
Or thus.
Arrius said Chommoda, when
Commoda sound he would,
Eke Hinsidias used when
Insidias he should.
H, is never written in the end of a word, saving in these interiections,
ah, vah, oh, from the which some think A to be cut of, either by the figure
Syncope, or else by the imperfectnes of the sound. You shall beside find him
joined with all the vowels, and with these consona^tes, C, as Chremes, P, as
Philip, R, as Pyrrhus, T, as Thraso: And this adding of h, to the consonantes
was not used before Cicero his time, as he in his book De Oratore declares,
by these words. Quin ego ipse (inquit) cum scirem ita maiores loquutos esse,
vt nusquam nisi in vocali, asperatione vterentur, loquebar sic, vt pulcros and
cetegos, Triumpos and Cartaginem dicerem: aliquando, idque sero, conuitio
aurium cum mihi extorta veritas esset, vsum loque^di populo concessi, scientiam
mihi reseruaui. Also A. Gellius reports that in time past, they used not to
put their aspirations among their letters, as we do now, but to set them over
the letters as in the Greek tongue, which form of writing by chance he
found in a piece of work (as he thought) of Virgils own hand writing. In
the notes of Antiquity H, signifies Honestas, Hic, Hoc, Haeres, Haeredes,
Haec, Homo, Honestus, Habet, Huius, Hora, Honor, Honori, H, b, Haeres bonorum.
etc. Haberdasher, or he that sells all manner of wares. Minutarius.*
Tabernarius, rij. m. g. Mercier, ou autre qui vend en petites leges.
Haubergion, or coat of male. Lorica, ae, foe. ge. Un Haubergeon, ou cotte de
maille. S. To put on a haubergeon, or coat of maile. Lorico, as, aui. Vestir
un halecret. S.

Armed with an haubergeon. Loricatus, a, um. Vestu d'un harnois. S.

Half verse. Hemistichium, chij. n. g. Demi verse. Call. Half wete. Semimadidus,
a, um. A demi moiste. Call. Half wild, half tame. Semifer, a, um. A demi
sauuage. S. For as much, as there be many mo words which begin with
half, then be here expressed, therefore note that the word whereunto you
add Semi, signifies but the moytie or half of that, which the word it
self signifies: As Semihora, Half an hour. Demie heure. S.

And also note, that this word Sesqui, joined to an other word, signifies
the extente or quantity of the word, and half as much more, as Sesquihora,
An hour and an half. Sesquiopera, A days journey in tillage and an half,
Sesquilustrum. etc.

Happen. Accidit, bat. Cado, is. Euenio, is. Obuenio, is. Obtingo, is.
Praeuenio, is. Incesso, is. Aduenio, Co^tingo, is. Aduenir. S. As it happened.
Ita vt fit. I know not what will happen. Quid casurum sit, euenturum sit, quid
cadere, quid co^sequi possit, ignoro, non dispicio. quid tempus laturum sit,
exploratum non habeo. latent me quae nasci possunt. futura me fugiunt. non
assequor ea, non assequor coniectura, diuinare non possum, aut me^te
praecipere, quae far, parere, patefacere dies ipsa potest. futuri casus
aperti mihi no^ sunt, mihi non patent, me fugiunt, praetereunt, latent.

What is happened, or chanced? Quid est factum? Quid accidit? Qu' est il
aduenu? S.

Happen contrary. Contrauenire. Aduenir au contraire. S. Happen in, or fall in.
Incido, is. Vide Fall. Happen often. Vsuuenire. Aduenir souuent. S. Happen, or
succeed well. Commode cadere. Happened by chance. Fortuitus, a, um. Aduenu d'
adventure. S. Happened, gotten, or had by chance. Sortitus, a, u^. It
happens not as I wyshed it, or contrary to my desire. Non cecidit, vt
optabam. praeter meam voluntatem, contra voluntatem, contra quam volebam, secus
ac volebam, euenit. exitum res habuit alienum a voluntate, minime cum voluntate
congruentem, aduersum voluntati. exitus rei, euentus rei voluntati non
respondit. optatum exitum consecuta res non est, ad exitum non peruenit. res
pro voluntate non successit. cupiditatem fortuna frustrata est, fefellit,
delusit, irritam fecit. summa cupiditas, res plane nulla fuit. speratum euentum
sortita res non est, nacta non est, adepta non est.

and rude. S. It is an hard matter to bring to pass. Difficilis res est,
laboriosa, non facillima, minime facilis, difficultatis haber, negotij, laboris
plurimu^. non ea res est, quae facile, paruo negotio, leui labor, non magno
studio possit effici. magnae difficultatis, multi laboris, non parui negotij,
non operis exigui, laboriosa, operosa, grauissima^ res est. in qua sudandum
sit, sustinendi labores, multum operae ponendum, vigilandum, excubandu^ animo
sit, non leuiter laborandum, studij multu^, industriae plurimum sit adhibendum.

Vocare aliquem in luctum. Moestitiam infer, vel offerre moerorem alicui.
Donner trestesse, ou mettre en trestesse, and doleur. S.

Heuines. or weight. Grauitas, tatis. Ponderositas, tatis. foe. genesis Pesanteur.
S. Heuines of the head. Capitis grauitas, aut grauedo. Pesanteur de test. S.
Which causes and engenders heuinesse of the head, or which is subject to
the heaviness of the head. Grauidinosus, sa, sum. Qui cause and engendre
pesanteur de test, ou qui est soubiect d'auoir pesanteur de test. S.

He is not far from home. Non long est ab aedibus. Il n' est pas fort loing

I said I would be at home. Dixeram me domi praesto fore. I'auoye dict que ie

maison. S.

Home supper. Domicoenium, nij. n. g. Mart. Homely, rusticall, or rude.
Agrestis, e. Inconditus, a, um. Rudis, e. Rusticus. Triuialis, le. om. ge.
Rustique, Rude. S. Homely after the vulgar sort. Popularis, re. Vulgaris, re.
Vulgaire. S. Homely, after the manner of the common people. Populariter,
Vulgariter. Vulgairement. S. Homely, unlearnedly, or rudely. Inculte,
Incondite, Pingi minerua, Triuialiter, Indocte. Indoctement. S. Homely style,
in speaking, or writing. Stylus gracilis, vel tenuis. Tenue filum orationis.
Homere, an excellent Greek poet, borne nere to the river Meles, of which he
was first named Melesigenes, and afterward because of his blindnenes he was
called Homerus, which in Greek signifies blind. He flourished before the
buyldinge of Rome, about an hundred and three score years, and wrote two
worthy works one of the Trojan wars, which is called Ilias: and an other of
the wanderinges of Ulysses, named Odyssea, whom Virgil prince of the latin
poets has so imitated, that in some part (by the judgment of Macrob. Sat.
5. cap. 11.) he seems to pass his patren. But of Homere Cicero in the fifth
of his Tusculans questions, has these words. It is said that Homer was
blind, but that may they say that see his picture and not his poetry. For
what Regio^, what coaste, what place of Greece, what shape of beauty, what
battle, what army, what motions of me^ or beasts, is not expressed by him in
such wise? That those things which he him self saw not, yet he has made us
to see who never beheld the same. Homerus, ri. m. g. Et Homericus, ca, cum. Of
Homere. Homecide. Homicidium, ij. n. g. Homicide. S. Homily, or ghostly

likelyhode of their exceading love, appearing to aswage, which time the vulgar

Afferre spem, Dare, Facere, Subijcere, Infer, Obijcere, Praebere, Offerre,
Pro ponere spem. Donner esperance. S.

To put in hope. Erigere ad spem, vel in Spem vertere, Ostendere vel Ostentare
spem alicuius rei, Expectationem dare. Mettre en esperance.

I see not why thou should hope. Non video, cur speres, quare, quamobrem,
qua causa, qua de causa, quam ob causam, qua ratione adductus, qua commotus
causa, quo impulsus argumento: quae te ratio, quid rationis in hanc spem
adduxit, impulit? cum in hanc spem venisti, quam rationem secutus es, quae te
duxit, aut hortata spes est? quid effecit, vt sperares? tuae spei causam
ignorare me confiteor. spei tuae causa me latet, praeterit, fugit, mihi quidem
aperta, perspicua, manifesta, satis clara non est. perobscura apud me est,
explorata mihi non est, obscuritatis apud me habet plurimum.

To hope. Habere fidem, Ponere spem, Spem alere, Spero, as. Teneri spe, In spe
esse. Auoir esperance.

Hope no longer. Relinquere spem, Deserere spem. Delaisser son espera^ce. S. To
put out of all hope. Eripere spem, Adimere spem, Spem auferre, Praecidere vel
incidere spe^ alicui. Oster toute esperance. S.

Out of hope. Spe deiectus. Frustre de son espoir. horse d' esperance.

Hope well. Reponere in optima spe, Bono animo esse, Animo confidere, Spem
optimam habere. Auoir bonne esperance. S. Hopeles, or without hope. Expes, pis.

Fourboully.*H. How. Eho. interiect. Heus. aduerb. Voc. Oh. How come hither.
Ehodum. Heus, Ad. vocant. He, venez ca. S. How syrra. Eho bone vir, Eho tu.
How. Qualiter, Quam, Qui, Quomodo, Vt, Come, Combien. S. Comment. How is it
possible. Qui pote, Qui id fieri potest. How late since. Quamdudum. How
lately since? Quampridem? Plaut. How long is it since thou did eat? Quam
pridem non edisti? Combien de temps ya il que tu n' as mange? How little?
Quantillum? Quantulum? aduerb. Combien peu? S. How little, or small?
Quantillus, a, um. Quantulus, a, um? Combien petit? S. How little so ever.
Quantulumcunque. How little so ever it be. Quantuluscunque, lacunque,
lumcunque. Quelque petit qu' il soit. S. How long. Quamdiu, Quantisper,
Quousque, Vsquequo. Combien longiement. S. How long yet, or till what time.
Quousque tandem. Iusques a quand. S. How many. Quotenus, a, um. Quotquot,
Quot, Quam plures, Quotus, a, um. Quotusquisque. Combien. S. How many sorts.
Quotuplex, cis. Quotuplus, a, um. De combien de sorts. Call. How great so ever.
Quantuscunque, Quantuslibet, Quantusquantus. Tant grand qu' il soit. S. How
many times. Quoties. Combie^ de fois. S. How much. Quantu^, Qua^to. O how much
more beawtifull semeste thou unto me now then of late? Quanto nunc formosior
videre mihi quam dudum? O de co^bien tu me semble plus beau que. etc. How
much, or how great. Quantus, a, um. Combien grand. S. For how much will thou
play? Quanti vis ludere? Quanti vis contendere? Quanti vis certare? Combien
veuls tu iouer. S.

For how much shall we play? Quanti ludemus, vel certabimus? Pour combien
iourons nous?

How much more. Quantuplus, a, um. How much more did the field give or
restore again. Quantuplum reddit ager. Call. How often. Quoties. Vt supra. Ho,
how often must I speak? Hem, quoties dicendum est, Repetendum, Iterandum,
Inculcandum? Cord.

I. ANTE. A.
I, A letter which is as well a co^sonant as a vowell. And being a word, is
in English a pronowne. As I, Ego. Ie. And in Latin a verb. As, I. Ito, Go
thou. And albeit that both in the Greek, and Latin tongues, there be
diversities between the figure I, which the Greeks call Iota, And Y, yet
nevertheless the one often represents the other. And in English nothing
material whether of them be taken, except that I, being the first person, you
can not say Y, And this word You the second person, may not be written Iou.
Finally, I placed in the middle of a word between two vowels obtains the
force, and valewe of a double co^sonant. Vt. Maius, Peius, Pompeius. I. Ego,
mei. Ie ou moy. S. I am. Sum, es, fui. Ie suis. S. I my self. Ego ipse,
Egome^. Moymesme. S. Iacint stone. Hyacinthus, thy. m. g. Hyacinthe. S. Jack,
or coat of fence. Cento, onis. m. g. Jack sauce. Proteruus, Os impudens.
Iacket. Tunica, ae. Sagum, gi. n. g. Vne say, ou sayon. Et Tunico, cas. To put
on a iacket. Vestir, and couurir d' un say. S. Iacket with sleeves. Manicata
tunica. Iacket without sleeves. Colobium, bij. neut. genesis Hocqueton. Pals.
Iacketed, or which has on a Iacket. Tunicatus, a, um. Sagatus, a, um. Qui ha
un say vestu. S. Iagge of a garment. Lacinia, ae, f. ge. Chicqueture. Iagged.
Laciniosus, a, um. Chicquetteux. Pal. Iaye bird. Gracus, Graculus, li. m. g.
Vne gay. S. Iakes, or commune draught. Forica, Oletum, ti. n. g. Un retraict
public. S. Iambes of a door, or gate. Parastates, Antae, aru^. foe. ge. Les
iambes d' vne huis. S. James. Iacobus, by. m. g. Jacques. S. Iangler, or prater.
Locutor, Rabula, lae. Locuruleius, leij. m. g. Caqueteur. S. January month.
Ianuarius, rij. m. g. Ianuier. Pals. Iape, or ieste. Vide Jest. Iapes, and
trifles. Deliramenta, orum. Lirae, aru^. foe. ge. Nugae, arum. f. g. Baueries.
S. Jar, or to discord. Discrepo, as. Dissono, as. Desaccorder. S. Iarring, or
discording. Discrepans, it is. Dissonus, a, um. Desaccordant. Call. Jasper stone.

I. ANTE. D.
IDes which are in every month just eighte, and not increasing, or
wantinge, as the Calendes, and Nones, whereof thou may read more in their
places. The Romans in respect of our account reduce them backewarde: as in
saying the twelfthe, the eleventh, the tenthe, the ninthe, etc. Of January,
they begin in this sort. Idibus ( Which is always read in the oblatiue
case for their first day) Ianuarij, Pridie, Tertio, Quarto, Quinto, etc. Iduum
Ian. Idus, uum plur. tantum. foe. ge. Idiot or fool. Fatuus, Idiota, Idiotes,
ae. com. genesis Idiot. S. Idle. Desidiosus, a, um. Inanis, Iners, it is. Languidus,
a, um. Lentus, Secors, dis. Socors, dis. Supinus, a, um. Otiosus, a, um.
Feriatus, a, um. Laboris expers, Reses, sidis, om. ge. Oiseux, Oisif. S. To
beidle. Desideo, es. Cessare, Compressis manibus sedere, Languere, Otiari,
Otiosum esse, Otia agere. Estre Oiseux. S.

To be very idle. Abundare otio. Estre fort oisif. S.

An idle household. Feriata familia. Famille oisiue.

Idle knave. Mirgizo, onis. Idle to wax, or to wax slothful. Languesco,
scis. Deuenir paresseux. S. Idleness. Desidia, Inertia, Secordia, Socordia,
Torpor, ris. Otium, tij. n. g. Oisiuete. S. Given to great idleness. Ad otium
summum accommodati. Addonnez a oisiuete. S.

Idolatry. Idolatria, ae. f. g. Idolatry. S. Idol. Idolum, li. n. ge. Vne
Idol. Et Idolium, lij. * Ang. A little Idol. Et Idolatra. Ang. A worshipper of
Idols. Idolatre. S. Et Idolothysia, ae. f. ge. Oblation or offering to Idols.
Et Idolothytu^. The thing offered, and given to Idols. Ce qui est immole, and
dedie aux idols. S. Idol set up in the place of espiall. Beelsephon.

ludimagistrum. Si n' estoit que ie crains le maistre. S. If you may justly

Leave of to sing put up your pypes,
Now have we heard our fill.
Which rather seems thus.
O children now shut ryuers up,
The meades have drunk at will.

IOcunde. Glaphirus, a, u^. Iucundus, a, um. Gay. S. Vt Iucunda accidunt. Cic.

masc. genesis Iean. Which is an Hebrewe word, and is as much to say (if ye
will interpret it) the grace of God. Of the which name there were two, the
one was John Baptiste, son to Zacharias, and Elizabeth, whom the Euangeliste
calls Praecursor domini. Of his food, attyere, conversation, and trade of
life, you shall read in Math. cap. 3. Luke. 3. Marc. 1. The other was John the
Euangeliste, an Apostle to Christ, which was the son of Zebedeus a fysher
man, and brother to James. Math. 4.10.20, Marc. 1. Luke. 5. He treats most
of the Deuinitie in his Gospel, who also did write the Revelations. There were
many mo of this name, both Princes and worthy writers, as the histories tell.

I. ANTE. V.
IVdge. Iudex, cis. com. genesis Un judge. S. There is Iudex ordinarius, and, Iudex
delegatus. The one is he that has authority of a peculiar jurisdiction, to
sit in judgment without commission, as the chief Justice of England, a Maire
or head officer of a Borogh, city, or town corporate, a coroner. etc. The
other is a commissioner, or justice which sits by virtue of commission
only. etc. Judge named on the one party. Edititius iudex. Qui est nomme par vne
des parties seulement. S. Judge, which being the inferior judge, goes on
foot. Pedaneus iudex. A judge, or magistrate condemned for bribery, or money
taking to judge. Damnatus sordium iudex, aut magistratus. Judge, ou magistrate
condamne pour auoir prins argent pour iuger? S

A judge which regards to please the parties, and to favor them, or a
partial judge. Obnoxious gratiae iudex. Judge qui regard a complaire aux
parties, and porteur faueur. S.

When the judge turns the profit of the cause to him self. Litem in rem
suam vertere. Quand le judge turn le prouffit de la cause a soy. S.

judge. S.

duniuge. S.

dicere, Pronu^tio, as. Promulgare decretum, Repenso, as. Sentio, it is. Statuo,

Judged to be for treason. Iudicium habere maiestatis imminutae, vel de crimine
laesae maiestatis. Yet consulte the difference, for the one is more heynouse
then the other. Salua semper optima opinione. I take that Damnari de maiestate
imminuta, Is to be condemned for petit treason. Judgment. Authoritas,
Cognitio, Dica, Iudicatus, us. Iudicium, Opinio, Sententia, Sors, Trutina,
Arbi^rium, rij. n. g. Judgment. S. I am not fully dissolved whether judgment
may come by the gift of nature or benefit of learning. Nondum plane
constitui, nondum satis habeo co^stitutum, deliberatum, exploratum, explicatum,
certum* naturae n^ munere, an disciplinae beneficio iudicium contingat. iudicij
praestantia, excellentia, vis, subtilitas vtrum a natura, an ab art, ac
disciplina proficiscatur, contingat, man^^. naturae ne priuilegio concedatur,
an sit ab art, ac disciplina petendum. vtrum is, qui recte iudicat, qui optime
iudicio vtitur, qui iudicio valet, praestat, excellit, facultatem habet optime
iudicandi, iudicio abundat, naturae debeat, an arti, bonum illud acceperit a
natura, an hauserit a studio, a barte, a disciplina. natural ne bonum sit
iudicium, an potius in studio, art, disciplina, doctrina, ratione situm,
eiusmodi, quod doctrina tradatur, a praeceptis ducatur, discatur a magistris.

K. ANTE. A.
K, A Greek letter, called of them Cappa, never used among the Latins, but in
words borrowed of the Greek, and for necessities sake converted into a Latin
form. Wherefore Priscianus thought K among the Latin letters to be
superfluous: from whom Quintil. not much dissenting, affirms that the lettre
C added to a vowell, does fully set forth the whole force, and value thereof.
Also Hugo, and Papias, think those that begin with K, mere Greek, and no
Latin words at all. In the notes of antiquity, K signified Calendae, Caput,
Charissimus, Cardo, Castra, Charissima, Celius: Kar, Carthago: K Ap, Calendis
Aprilis: Kal. Ianua. Calendis Ianuarij: K Aug. Calendis Augusti: K T. Capite
tonsus, cum multis alijs. Calendar, by the which one may know both the holy
days and workyng days. Fasti, orum. Calendarium, rij. Hemerologium, gij. n.
ge. Calendrier, par le quel on pouoit congnoistre les iours festez, and non
festez. S. To put out of the calendar. Eximere dies de fastis. Cic. Oster du
^alendrier. S.

Kalendes, the first day of every month. Calendae, arum. f. g. It is derived
of the Greek word (...) which signifies Voco, for that upon this day did
the Ethnicke priests assemble ye people together, to the end they might declare
how many days were to ye Nones of the same month, and then the people
repaired again to the city, to understand what was (both in spiritual and
temporal affairs) necessary to be done that month. But now that those
which desire and can not account the nombre of the days of each month by
the Kalendes, Nones, and Ides, may with more facility attain to the same. I
have thought it nothing unfit to put down these verses following. Triginta
Aprilis, Iuni, Septemque, Nouemque:
Vno plus alij: viginti Februus octo,
At si bissextus fuerit, superadditur vnus,
Et tunc bissexto Marti conscribe Calendas.
Which is.
Thirty days has November
April June and September,
All the rest have one and thirty:
Save eight and twenty February,
And nine and twenty have he shall
If that a leap year chance to fall,
Eke then the over leap years day
To Marches kalendes ad you may.
Sex Maius Nonas, October, Julius and Mars.
Quatuor at reliqui, dabit Idus quilibet octo.
Six Nones in March, October, May, and July has no mo.
The rest have four, In every monthe eight Ides there are also.
Now sith every month is divided into Kalendes Nones and Ides, and that the
verses above tell certainly how many days are in every month, you may
work in this sort. If a letter be dated in any of the Kalendes, Nones or
Ides, of a month, do no more but count how many days are in that month
which is easily known by the verses above, then by the next verses you may
know how many Nones are also in that month, for the Ides of every month are
just eyghte. The Nones and Ides known, the nombre that remains is of the
Kalendes. As for example, January has 31. days, whereof.4. are Nones.8.
Ides, and 19. Kalendes, but you must count the^ always backwardes in respect
of our count, for all the Kalendes of one month, saving the first are in the
other month that went before it. As a lettre dated Calendis Ianuarij, is
writtten the first of January, but if it be written Pridie Calendas, vel Pridie
calendarum Ianuarij (because the kalendes of one month are counted backward
into the next month going before) then was it dated the last of December, for
the last of that month is Pridie calendas Ianuarij, and tertio calendarum
Ianuarij, Is the.xxx. day of Dece^ber, but if you will write the second day of
January, you must say. Quarto nonaru^, vel quarto nonas. Ianuarij, For January
has but.4. Nones, as by the verses above it appears. If you will write the
fifth of January, you must date it thus, Nonis Ianuarij. And so if you write
the thirtenth day of January, you must write Idibus Ianuarij, for so is ye
first of the Nones, Ides, or Kalendes, always used ^n the ablative case. Thus
much have I in this place said the more, because young scholars may hereby
(as I deem) sooner attain to ye understanding the date of those Epistles which
they read. Karue, Sculpo, is. Scalpo, is. Coelo, as. Entailler. S. Karuer, a
crafts man. Coelator, ris. Sculptor, ris, Anagliptes, ae. m. g. Menuisier.
Pals. Karuer at a table. Structor, ris. m. g. Karuer, or yetter of Images.
Statuarius, rij. m. ge. Tailleur d' images. S. Karuing. Caesura, ae. Sculptura,
ae. f. g. Seek these words and the like in C. ante A. Where we judge their
propre places to be.

such whereof you double, and find the^ not here, seek C.


K. ANTE. L.

K. ANTE. N.

L. ANTE. A.
L, A letter counted among the half vowelles, and also a liquid, the Greeks
call it Lamda, In latin following a mute in ye same word, it makes the sylable
going before, if it be short, commune: in our tongue it is used so dyuersly
that it needs a longer discourse, then is here necessary. For in diverse
words we write the double and pronounce ye single, as in All, Wall. etc. But
time will take these away, as she daily reatcheth at the rests. L. in nombre is
written for. 50. Quinquaginta. Cinquante. Call. Labor. Cura, Industria, Labor,
Labos, Opera. Opus, eris. n. g. Labeut, trauail and besongne. S. Et Opusculum,
li. diminut. Ang. A little, short, or small labor. Besongnette. S. Et
Operarius, a, u^. Ang. Of labor, or pertaining to labor. Servant a l' ouure,
S. Labor lost. Abusio operae, Caducus labor. Labor or to work. Ago, is.
Laboro, as. Opus facere, Moliri, Operari. Labourer. S. To take great labor,
and travail to do some thing. Elaboro, as. Summo labor, and diligentia
eniti, Conari. Prendre grand labeur and trauail a fair quelque chose. S.

Labor for an office. Prenso, as. Praehenso, as. * Petere magistratum.
Labor in vain, or to lease labor. Frustrare, vel irritare operam, Sumere
operam frustra. Laterem lauare, Laborem serere, Aquam in mortario tundere,
Aquam pestillo tundere, Frustra currere, Mortuo mederi, Senis mutare linguam,
Senem admonere, Penelopes telam texere, Oleu^ et operam perdere, Arare littus.
Nihil agere, Cribro aqua^ haurire, Isthmu^ perfodere, In aqua scribere, Nebulas
diuerberare, Littori loqui, Ae^hiopem lauare, vel dealbare, Sumere opera^,
Operam perdere vel ludere. Trauailler en vain. S. Labor of child. Nitor,
eris, nixus s^m. Trauailler d'enfant. Pals. She is in travail, or labor with
child. Laborat e dolor. Elle est en trauail d'enfant. S.

Labor, or travail of a woman with child. Nixus, us. m. g. Le trauail d' vne
femme pour enfanter. S. Labor, or endeavor to do a thing. Nitor, eris. Vt
supra. Labor, or solicitie for the voice of ye contrary. Praehenso, as.
Prenso, as.* Labor, or toil for aduau^tage or living. Tudito, as. Fest.
Laborare, Opus facere. Trauailler. S. Labor painful, or heaviness of mind.

resoluere, vel vincere. Terram moliri, Colere. Labourer la terre. S. Labor
hard, or till he sweat. Sudo, as. Conuexo, as. Trauailler grandement.

it is. Laborious, or full of labor. Laboriosus, Operosus, sa, sum. Qui trauaille
fort and prend grande peine. S Lace. Fibula, Laqueus. * Lace of a cappe, or
