Ladder of the top castle of a ship. Epibatra. * vel Epibathra. Scalae
nauticae, quibus in nauim conscenditur. Call. Ship ladders. Lade. Suffarcino,
as. Sarcino, nas.* Onero, as. Grauo, as. Charger. S. Lade a ship. Implere
nauim. Laded. Suffarcinatus, a, um. * Grauatus, ta, tum. Oneratus, ta, tum.
Onustus, ta, tum. Charge. S. Laded or stuffed. Suffarcinatus, ta, tum. Laden to
be. Grauesco, scis. Lady. Domina, nae. f. g. Dame. S. Lady, or president of
eloquence. Pytho, vel Pitho, Dea qua^ E^nius Suadam: Quintilianus persuadendi
deam dicit. Neb. Ladies of Destenie, or Life, called by the Poets Fatal
ladies, of which there are three, Clotho, Lachesis, and Atropos, the daughters
of Erebus and Nox. They are called Parcaeper contrarium a Parco, because they
spare no man. The first is imagined to hold a dish^staffe: The second
draws forth the threede, and the third cuttes it of. That which is on the
dishstaffe, signifies the time to come: The threede now in hand, betokens
time present, and that which is wound on the spyndle, figureth the time
paste. So that by a similitude their spinning is compared to the beginning,
continuance, and end of a man's life. Parcae, carum. foem. gener. Parques, les
trois Parques. S. Et Deae fatalia nentes stamina, Deae fatales, Lanificae
sorores, Lanificae puellae. vt Martial. lib. 1. Epigram. Lanificas nulli tres
exorare puellas
contigit, obseruant quem statuere diem.
Was never man such favor could
of fatal ladies find,
To cause them length or short the day
which they to him asynde.

grand renom. Ladle. Tudicula, ae. Ferula, ae. Grand cullier. Lagge. Vide Last.

Lettres stolen out by suggestion. Surreptitiae literae. Lettred, or learned.
Literatus, Literosus, a, u^. Lettre, docte. S. Lettuce, an herb. Lactuca, ae.
f. g. Vne laictue. S. Of ye which Martial* speaks thus. Claudere cum coenas
lactuca solebat auorum,
Dic mihi, cur nostras inchoat illa dapes?
Sith that in elder time they used
their lettuce after meat,
Tell me why now we ever use
it first of all to eat?

Leave cul, a French phraes, as much to say in English, remove your bomme,
and may be thus latined. Leua culum. It is a kind of gaminge at the tables
coursly at many hands, that where as one has lost a game, an other
enterpriseth by turn, and so every man in his turn. Leuel to make, or to make
eue^. Aequo, as, aui. Vnir. To level, or shoot with the bow. Tela dirigere

It is not my propriety to lie. Non est mentiri meum. Ce n' est pas mon
naturel de mentir. S.

They do nothing but lie. Nullus mentiendi modus est. On ne fait, que mentir.

Without lyinge. Non dicam dolo, Bona fide. Sans mentir. S.

Like figure. Concors figura. Semblable figure. S. A thing like, and near to

One like unto me. Alter ego. Un semblable a moy.

A beast like unto those of the sea. Aemula marinis bestia. Best semblable a
celles de la mer. S.

I seek a man like unto this. Ad istam faciem hominem quaero. Ie cerche un
homme semblable a cestuy. S.

Other like. Alia eiusdem generis. Autres semblables. S.

It is more like the truth. Similius very, aut vero est. Il est plus vray
semblable. S.

It is like to this. Ad hoc exemplum est. Il est semblable a cestuy. S.

Of like kind. Eius, vel eiusdem generis. De semblable genre. S.

Noe one man like an other. Nemo est alteri similis. Null n' est semblable a
l'autre. S.

vehement then our lime. Strab. Plin. With this Semiramis caused the walls of

Full of love. Love being sone hot, sone cold. Repudiosa cupido. Love. Amo,
as. Colo, is. Confer amorem. Diligo, is. Prosequi amore, Respecto, as.
Respicio, cis. Vti amore, Adamo, as. Opera^ dare amori, Charum aliquem habere.
Aimer. S. I love the chiefly, only, or with all my heart. Sum, vehementer,
valde, magnopere, maximopere, maxim, etiam atque etiam, mire, mirifice,
incredibiliter, vnice, singulariter, egregie, insigniter, ex animo, ex intimo
sensu, cumprimis, in primis, apprime, praecipue, admodum, oppido, maiorem in
modum, mirum in modu^, minime vulgariter, non mediocriter te diligo, in te
amando nemini concedo. qui te vehementius diligat, co^cedo nemini. beneuolentia
in te mea ad summu^ peruenit. amor in te meus is est, ita accumulatus est, vt
addi nihil possit. amorem in te meum verbis exprimere qui possum, quem
cogitatione vix amplector? cuius magnitudinem vix mente co^prehendo? amorem in
te meum cogitatione fortasse consequi, complectique possum, verbis quidem
exprimere, explicare, expromere profecto non possum. aeque, similiter, pariter
ac meipsum, non aliter ac meipsum, non secus ac meipsum, itidem vt me ipsum, te
diligo, sic te diligo, vt neminem magis, ne meipsum quidem. cum te multi
diligant, omnes tamen in amore vinco. principatum appeto, primas parts mihi
vendico, praecipuu^ locum obtineo. fero te in oculis. mihi es in amoribus.
nihil mihi est te charius. secundum Deum, post Deum, excepto Deo. cum a Deo
discessi, nemo mihi este charior. ego te vt oculos meos, aut si quid oculis est
charius diligo. singulari erga te animo sum. vt pater in filium, ita ego in te
sum animatus. habeo te filij loco. amor in te meus tantus est, quantus potest
esse maximus. haeres mihi in animo, in medullis, in intimis sensibus. singulari
sum in te beneuolentia. primum amore Deum, te habeo proximum.

Ly, Vide Li.
M. ANTE. A.
M, Written by him self, signifies with us a thousand, and where as in our
language M, is fully pronounced, yet in the Latin tongue, if it be placed in
the end of a word with a vowell following in the beginning of the next, the
Poets use by their figure Ecthlipsis to cut him of, for that (as some
affirm) his sound is so bellowing, and intolerable. Beside M, in
Compositione and Deriuatione, coming before, D, T, C, or, Q, Is often changed
into N, as in these words, Tantum, Tantundem, Eorum, eorundem. Idem,
Identidem. Number, nuncubi: Number, nunquis, Quicunque, Nunquam Circunquaque, Nanque,
Tanquam. Likewise, Am, the preposition set before, F, C, or Q, Is turned into
N, as Anfractus, etc. In the notes of antiquity M, signified Marcus, Martius,
Mutius, Monumentum, Mulier, Miles, Meum, Meam, Mihi, Molestus, Modo, Mors,
Munus, Ma, Macuuius, Mag, Magistratus. M, D, O, Mihi dare oportet. etc. Mace,
or kings scepter. Sceptrum, tri. neut. ge. Un Scepter royal. S. It was
Neptunus Mace. Mace bearer. Sceptrifer, a, um. Qui port scepter. Maces a
spice. Macer, Macis. Macis. H. Mache. Vide Match. Mackerell, a fish.
Scombrus, bri. m. g. Maquereau. Made. Conditus, a, um. Creatus, a, um. Factus,
a, um. Faict. S. Made again, or a fresh, or eftesones. Redintegratus, a, um.
Rediuiuus, a, um. Refectus, a, um. Refait. Call. Made all one. Adunatus, a, um.
Made by rule. Emussitatus, a, um. Ad amussim factus. Fest. Made or of form
like the Moon. Lunatus, a, um. Qui ha la form de la Lune. S. Made moist.
Madefactus, a, um. Vide Moiste. Made of many pieces, as a house is made of
clay, stone, timber. etc. Structilis, le. om. g. Qui est faict, and basti de
plusiers pieces. S. Made out of use. Desuefactus, a, um. Desaccoustume. Made
ready, or fit. Procinctus, a, um. Made without labor. Illaboratus, a, um.
Qui ne est point elaboure. Call. Mad. Amens, it is. Captus mente. Deme^s, it is.
Fanaticus, a, u^. Furibundus, Furiosus, Insanus, Lymphaticus, Maniacus,
Percitus insania, Phanaticus, Proceritus, a, u^. Rabidus, a, um. Vecors, dis.
Vesanus, Alienatus me^te. Forcene ou enrage. S. Et Rabiosulus, a, u^. diminut.
Ang. A little, or somewhat mad. Quelque peu enrage. Call. Mad angry.
Rabiosus, a, um. Saeuus, a, u^. Enrage. Mad at certain Moons, lunatike.
Lunaticus, a, um. Lunatique. S. Mad fool. Euapelus.* Mad person Vacerra,
ae. mas. genesis Fest. Ceritus, ti. m. ge. Plaut. Mad priests. Corybantes,
Cybeles sacerdotes. They were certain priests of Idols, who using fury and
madness, incited the blind people to follow the same. Mad to be. Demento,
as. Furio, ris, insaniui, Gallo, as. Insanio, is. Rabio, is. Dementio, is.
Bacchor, aris. Estre insense. S. Mad to make. Externo, as. Furio, as. Fair
deuenit furieux. S. To wax mad. Furere, Furore ingrauescere, Furorem
concipere ex maleficio. Deuenir furieux.

Madder, herb. Aparine, Rubia tinctorum, Rubia, Erythrodanum, ni. n. g.
Garance. S. Madly. Dementer, Furiose. Furieusement. S. Madness. Furor, ris.
Insania, ae. Insanitas, Mania, ae. Melancholia, ae. Oestrum, tri. Rabies, ei.
Vecordia, Vesania, ae. Splendida bilis. Forcenerie. S. Furibundus. Full of
madness. Plein de rage. S. Madness of a dog. Rabies, ei. f. g. Fureur de chien.
Maffle in the mouth, or to stammer. Balbutio, is. Balbucinor, aris. Begueyer.
S. Magike. Magia, ae. Magice, magices. f ge. Magie. S. This art the
Philosophers divide into natural mag^^e, which consists only in the
perfect knowledge of natural things: And Theurgie, which teaches by
inuocations of spirits, and wicked inchauntementes. It contains these
kinds, or forms. Axiomantie, which is wrought by hachettes, pike axes, and
other like tools: Hydromatie, by water: Lecanoma^tie, by b^sins filled with
water: Catoptromantie, by a glass: Pyromantie, by fire: Geomantie, by the
earth: Chiromantie, by the lintame^ts of the hands: Nicromantie, by calling
up of spirits, and talk had with deuilles: Capnomantie, by the smoke of the
altar, or sacrifice: Coscinomantie, by a sie^e, which is (as some report) at
this day much used of the French women, for the finding out of things taken
away by stealth, or such like means. Magistrate, or ruler. Magistratus, tus.
masc. gener. Magistrate. S. Magistrate, which brings the law to the people.
Rogator comitiorum. Magistrate, qui apportoit la loy au peuple. S. A kind of
magistrates, which have like power, and authority for the time, as the
consulles. Tribuni militares. Vne espece de magistrate, qui eut pour v^ temps
semblable puissance, and authorite que les consulz. S.

A magistrate, which did enquire of causes criminals. Quaesitor, ris. m. g. Un
magistrate, qui ha la cognoisance des causes criminelles. S.

An ancient magistrate in the province, which leaves his place to new
successors. Decessor, oris. m. g. Le vieil magistrate estant en la province qui
fait place aux nouueaulx successeurs. S.

The office of magistrate. Magistratus, tus. m. ge. L' office d'vn magistrate. S.

ae. f. g. Magnificence. S. Magnificke. Superbus, a, um. Magnificus, a, um.
Magnifique. S. Magnify. Extollo, is. Magnifico, as. Magnifier. S. Magot.
Terms, is. m. g. Ver de chair. Pals. May, or can. Polleo, es. Possum, potes,
verb. sub. Queo, is. Valeo, es. Pouoir. S. Antiqui habent potestur, pro potest.
May not, or can not. Nequeo, is. Ne pouoir. S. Antiqui vsurpant nequinunt, pro

Ma virginite est au commandment de Phoebus. S.

party d' aucun. S.

aliquem. Soustenir quelque parti, and quarelle contre aucun. S.

as inuente punishment for others, and feel the same them selves, risen of one
Perillus, which made a brazen Bulle, ordained for torment, and gave it to
Phalaris, wherein Perillus him self was first tormented, to try the
experience. Make assault. Adeo, is, iui, vel ij. Assailir. Vide Assault. Make

Render feroce and cruel comme vne best. Call. You shall find many words
which begin with make in the places of the principal words, as thus:
Angry to make, seek there fore make angry, Apt to make, look there to make
apt: Manifest, there shall you find, make manifest. and ce.

homme. H. Et homulucus, ac homunculus. diminut. inde, and Homuncio, onis. Ang.
A little or low man. Petit homme. H. It is also the general latin to man,
woman, or child. Of Vir comes Semiuir, Whose English is half a man, or an
imperfect man: Duumuir, a man having joint office with an other: Triumuir,
joint officer with two me^, where as three be in office: Quinqueuir, where as
five be in joint office: Septemuir, where as seven be in like office: Decemuir,
where ten be in like office, but more properly a man having the office or
dignity of Decemuiratus, in whose authority was Dece^uirale Ius: Centumuir,
one of the Judges, called Centumuiri, when the people of Rome were divided
into.xxxv. trybes, as Budaeus writes: Leuir a man who is brother to the wives
husband, or brother in law to the wife. Masculinus, a, um. Virilis, le. Ang.
Of a man. D' homme. Call. Man come up of naught, whose kynred is unknown.
Terrae filius. Cic. Man desirous of the peoples favor. Aurae popularis homo,

pugnare. Curt. Homme a homme. S. Man having members of both kinds, being both
man and woman. Androginos. Qui vtrunque habet sexum, and maris, and foeminae.
Call. Of this kind is in Asia. Man kyller, or queller. Angerspartarius, *
Homicida, ae. m. g. Homicide, tueur de gens. Call. Man lately commen to honor,
or worship. Nouus homo. Cic. Man never laughing. Agelastes, Agelastus. Qui ne
rit iamais. Call. Man not perfect, lacking members, or being gelded. Semimas,
ris. Semiuir, ri. m. ge. Chastre, demi homme. Call. Man of a little stature.

Minor, aris. Tollere minas. Eminor, aris. Minas iactare, Minas proponere,
Minitor, aris. Menacer. S. To manace, or threaten upon a pain. Poenas
interponere. Menacer sur peine. S.

He manaced that he would go from her. Ab hac minatur sese abire. Il la menace
de la delaisser. S.

To manace, or threaten stoutly. Comminari. Interminari. Fort menacer. S.

To manace, or threaten one to beat him. Vim denunciare licui. Menacer quelqu'
un de battre. S.

To manace, or threaten one, if he do not that that we demand. Opponere
nomen alicuius ad rem aliquam faciendam. Menacer d'aucun si on ne fait ce que
nous demandons. S.

To manace, or threaten to kill one. Minari alicui mortem, Interminari vitam,
Minitari ferru^ and flammam, Intentare mortem. Menacer de tuer aucun. S.

To manace, to send one to prison. Comprehensionem corporis inhibere. Menacer
d'enuoyer en prison. S.

To manace one in crying after him. Clamore, ac minis aliquem insequi. Menacer
aucun en criant apres aucun. S.

mesure. S.

Measure to meat ground. Chorobates. In some places called a gadde containing
eighte feet by standarde, which laid every way makes a roode, and that is
the fourth part of an acre, as some hold opinion, albeit I will not verify
it. Calipine says it is a rule of.xx. foot long. Measure, or to meat.

aris. Modificor, aris. Permetior, tiris. Modulor, aris. Admetior, iris, vel
ire. Mesurer. S. Measure or meat, diligently, or truly. Demetior, iris, vel

More. Magis, Plus, Vltra, Amplius. Plus. S. Much more. Multo magis. Beaucoup

Superflu. Call. More then enough. Satis superque. Aduerb. Assez and plus qu'
assez. S. More, is the sign of the comparatiue degree, which fourmed
according to the rules of comparison, may be more easily tried out then written
here, as thus, Black, whose comparatiue is Blacker, or More black White,
whyter, or More white. etc. Niger, Nigrior, Albus, Albior.

chyne, and if it byte any thing, then the thing bitten will swell and dye.

N. ANTE. A.
N, A lettre, and one of the half vowels in elder time counted among the the
liquids, which if it take the first place in a word, some time takes G
before it, as Natus, Gnatus, Narus, Gnarus. etc. And sometime in composition,
where the letter C, follows N, C is turned into G, as Quadringenti pro
quadrincenti, and Quingenti pro quincenti. But in those words where N is not,
C is reserved, as Ducenti. etc. In the notes of antiquity, N was written for
Non, vel Nec, Number, Nomen, Nepos, Nonius, Noster, Numisma, Numorum, Nascitur,
Nisi, Numerator, Nostri, Nostrum, and Nau. Nauicula, vel Naues, vel Nauibus. Et
No. Nobis, Nbl. Nobilis, Nc. Nunc, N. C. Non certe, vel N. C. Nero Claudius.
N.C.S.N. Co. S.D.E. Notis ciuibus Senatus consulti suffragium datu^ est.
N.C.N.P. Non clam nec praecario. Et N.C.C. Non Calumniae causa. etc.
Nabuchodonosor, the fourth king of Babylon, and the third king of the
Chaldees, whom Berosus also names Nabugodrosus, and of the Hebrews
Nabuchadnazar. It is written that Nabuchodonosor, king of Babylon, caused a
golden Image to be made, which was forty cubits high, and six cubits
thick, and caused all the people to fall down and worship it, which
Idolatry, because Sidrach, Misach, and Abednago, would not do, he commanded
them to be cast bound into an hot burning oven, but they were preserved by
the almighty power of God, and they which cast them in, consumed with the
flambe. Read the.3. chap. of Daniel. Nagge. Equulus, Mannus, Equus pumulus.
Cheualet. H. Nay. Vide No. Nay sayer. Negatiuus. Negans, it is. om. genesis Niant
Qui nie. Nay saying. Negatio, onis. foe. g. Niement. Nay to say. Nego, as.
Vide Deny. Nail. Clauus, ui. n. g. Un clou. S. Et Clauulus, Clauiculus, li.
Ang. A little or small nail. Clouet. S. Nail of a balke, or beam. Trabalis
clauus. Nail of brass. Clauus aeneus. To nail a thing. Clauo aliquid figere.
Clouer quelque chose.

g. A little or soft nail. Onglet. S. Vngulatus, a, um. Having foul great
nails. Qui magnos vngues habet. Call. Nailed. Clauatus, a, um. Cloue. S. But
rather trimmed with nails. Garni de clous. S. Nailed up. Suffixus, a, um.
Particip. Naked. Nudus, a, um. Nud. S. Half naked. Seminudus, da, dum. A demi
nud. S.

sibi adoptare, Nomen commutare, Transnominare. Changer son nom. S.

nom. S.

Surnommer. S. Name, which we call the sir name. Cognomen, inis. n. g.
Cognomentum, ti. n. g. Surnom. S. Name called the Christian name, or the first
or propre name. Praenomen, inis. n. g. Le nom propre. Named. Adpellatus,
Nominatus, Nuncupatus, ta, tum. Nomme. S. Named again. Repetitus, a, um.*
Named to be again. Repetor, eris.* Namely, or by name. Seorsum. Nommeement. S.

Nuncupo, as. Allego, as. Nommer. S. Namen again. Repeto, is.* Names which be

When it is need, or needful. Vbi opus poscit. In loco. Quand il en est
besoing. S.

I will send thee the rest when need requires. Caetera apposite tibi
mandabo, vel suo tempore. Ie te manderay le rest quand il en sera besoing. S.

What need I speak of the multitude of fishes? Quid multitudinem piscium
dicam? Qu'est il besoing de parler de l'abondance des poissons. S.

What need I declare how great the love of brute beasts is, in bringinge up
those which they have engendered. Quid dicam qua^tus amor sit bestiarum in
educandis quae procreauerunt? Que est il besoing que ie parle de la grand amor
que les bestes ont a nourrir ce qu'elles ont engendre. S.

vt Virgil. Antiquas domos auium diruit. He destroyed, or cast down the old
birds nestes. Nestle, or build nestes. Nidifico, as. Nidulor, aris. Fair un
nid, nicher. Call. Nestor, the name of a Grecian, which lived three men's
ages. Nestor, toris. m. ge. Pylius senex, senex ter aeuo functus, Neleius,
Nelides, a patre Neleo, and rex Pylius. vt Iuuenal. Rex Pylius (magno si
quicquam credis Homero)
Exemplum vitae fuit a cornice secundae.
Foelix heu nimium, qui tot per saecula mortem
Distulit, atque suos iam dextra computat annos.
King Nestor (if thou credit ought
To Homer great do give,)
Example was of blissed life
Nighe long as crow to live.
O to to bliste that drove of death
So many ages oulde,
And yet at last of all his years
Observe account that could.

si afflige, que iamais person ne le fut plus. S.

pais. Cord.

nuncias voluptatem. Tu me dis bonnes nouuelles. Cord.

Noise of the hands, or feet. Strepitus, tus. mas. g. Bruit qu'on fait des
pieds, ou des maiens. S. Noise made with the mouth, the lips fastened

neut. ge. dimin. A little noise. Petit Bruit. S. Noise to make, or to sound.

To make a soft noise. Susurrare. Fair un bruit bas

S.

wailing, and weeping. Eiulo, as. Braire. S. Nombe to be, or a sleep, as hand

benommed. Manus obtorpuit. Cic. Number. Numerus, ri. m. g. No^bre. S. Et
numeralis, le. Pertaining to number. Appartenant a nombre. To fill the nombre.

O. ANTE. B.
O, Is the name of a vowel, which has diverse significations, and is found
either an aduerbe of calling, as, O Syrus, where is Aeschinus? o Sire,
Aeschinus vbi est? Terent: or an Interiection of sorrow, as, O wretch that I
am. O me perditum. O me afflictum. O moy homme perdu. S: Of disdayning, as, O
what boldness. O audaciam. O la hardiesse. S: Of mirthe, as, O happy chance. O
factum been. O que c' est bien faict. S. etc. H joined unto him, makes him of
more vehemency: as, Oh, I am an honest man. Oh, Probus homo sum. Plaut. Also
in the notes of antiquity, O A Q signified Omnes aliquos. O good child. Euan.

O. ANTE. Y.
OYer and terminer, a phrase in the common law, signifying to hear and
determine. Audire, and determinare, vel decidere. Ouir and terminer. S. Oyes,
is a French phrase, and is as much to say, hark ye, or hear you: Which
is used in common proclamation, to cause the people to harker diligently what
shall be done or said. It seems to come of the second person of the verb
Audio, Which is, Audis? Hears thou? Oy^^tu? Pil.
P. ANTE. A.
P, A letter compted among the mutes, and never written with any aspiration
after him, except it be in Greek words, as Phaeton, Epiphania, and such like.
Also in translating Greek words into a Latin form, P is often changed
into B, as (...) in Latin is written Buxus. In the notes of antiquity, P
signified Pupillus, Posuit, vel Pes, vel Passus, vel Publius. Pace, which
contains three foot, whereof a thousand make an English mile. Passus, us.
masc. genesis Un pas. Call. Patience. Clementia, ae. Patientia, ae. Tolerantia,
tiae. foe. ge. Patience. Patience herb. Bulapathu^, Hippolapathon,
Hippolapathum. Lapathum, Rumex satiuus, Lapatium, Rhabarbarum monachorum.
Patience. H. Patient. Clemens, it is. Patiens, it is. Placidus, a, um. Patient. S.
Pacient, or sick body. Aeger, a, um. Aegrotus, a, um. Pacient. Pals. Patient
to be. Deferueo, es. Deferuesco, scis. Estre patient. S. Patient to wax.
Deferuesco, scis. Deuenir patient. S. Patiently. Clementer, Patienter, Placide,
Toleranter. Patiemment. S. To bear, or suffer patiently. Recte far, Humane,
and placate far, Patienter far, Fortiter pati, Lent far, Leuiter far,
Pati, and non moleste far, Pati aequo animo, Molliter far, Aequo animo
far, Far moderate, Placide far, Sustentare. Porter patiemment. S.

Pauing. Pauimentatio, onis. foe. ge. Pauement. S. Pauing betle, to trim
pauement. Pauicula, ae. f. ge. Un bato^r, vne bate. S. Pauing tyle with
pictures eneyled. Asarotum, ti. neut. genesis Stat. Paul one of the Apostles,
elected by revelation from a persecutour to be a chosen vessel of God, and
named before Saulus, is now called Paulus, which is (if you will interpret it)
Champion against Gods enemies, conuentour, marvelous, mouth, or voice of a
trompet. He was of the trybe of Benjamin, borne in Iudaea, in a town called
Giscalis, who lived after the passion of Christ twenty years or more, in the
time of Nero, under whom he suffered. Of this name Paulus, there were diverse,
some noble and gracious, as were Aemilius, Lucius Paulus, some were ignoble,
ungracious, and also Heretics, as Paulus Samosatenus. etc. Paulus, li. mas.
genesis Paul. S. Paunche. Rumen, inis. Venture, tris. Aqualiculus, li. m. g.

P. ANTE. E.
PEace. Quies, it is. Quietudo, inis. Toga, ae. foe. ge. Pax, cis. f. g. Paix. S.
vt Ovid. Fast. 1. Sub iuga bos veniat, sub terras semen aratas,
Pax Cererem nutrit, pacis alu^na Ceres.
Let ox receive the painful yoke,
And tylled ground the seed,
For peace does Ceres sweet maintain,
On peace does Ceres feed.
Peace certain, and sure. Explorata pax, Pax constituta, and firmata. Paix
certain, and asseuree. S. Peace accorded. Pax conuenta, vel sequestra. Virg.
To confirm, or establishe peace. Pacem confirmare. Confirmer la paix. S.

Which loves peace. Amator pacis. Qui aim paix. S.

accordee. S. Peache a fruit. Persicu^ pomum, Malum persicu^, vel Duracinum,
Nux mollusca, and Nucipersica. Un pesche. vt Mart. Vilia fueramus maternis
praecoqua ramis,
Nunc in adoptiuis persica cara sumus.
Upon our native boughs to ripe,
And out of price we were,
Now peaches on adoptiue plants,
We are accounted dear.

P. ANTE. H.
PHarysey. Phariseus, sei. m. g. The Phariseis were a sect of Jews, living
(as they feyned) more Godly and straightly, then ye common sort did. Read of
ye Phariseis in Math. 5.23.15.16. Luke ye. 7.16.18. In Mark. 12.3. In John
the. 1.6.11.12.15.18.23. cha* Where you shall see what is spoken of them* and
what they were. Philadelphus, a king of Egipte surnamed Ptolomaeus whose
daughter Bernix was given in marriage to one Antiochus Theos, the king of
Siria, albeit Mala fide, for Antiochus had a wife called Laodice (mother to
Seleucus Gallinicus, and Antiochus Hierax) whom he put away, but what was the
end of this adulterer, any other but mischief and murder, as is imminent to
all aduoutry and whoredom? For Seleucus Gallinicus did slay Bernix his fathers
concubyne and her bastard, and Laodice did poison Antiochus her husband. After
that Ptolomaeus Euergetes brother to Bernix, chased Gallinicus out of his
realm. This Philadelphus was the first that erected a library in Alexandria,
in the which were fifty thousand books, wherein were also the five books of
Moses, which he caused to be translated out of Hebrew into Greek, by.lxxii.
interpretours, excellent clerks, hired for that purpose. Philasarie or keeper
of records in ye high courts at Westminster. Monophilax.* Philippe a propre
name. Philippus, pi. m. ge. Eras. or some other pleasauntly disposed, made
these verses of this name. Phy nota foetoris, lippus malus omnibus horis:
Phy malus, and lippus, totus malus ergo Philippus.
Of this name were diverse, both kings and nobles, whereof one was father to
Alexander Magnus of Macedonia. This story is notable, as well for the wit,
prowes, and gravity of the prince, as also for his wisdom and severity in
judgment. Philosopher. Philosophus, i. m. g. Philosophe. S. Et Philosophaster,
tri. m. g. Ang. He that does cou^terfay^e a philosopher, or would be taken for
one. Qui fait du Philosophe. Et Philosophicus, a, u^. Of a philosopher, or
pertaining to a philosopher. Appart^nant a philosophe. S. Philosophor, aris. To
study phylosophie. Philosopher. S. Philosophy. Philosophia, ae. f. g.
Philosophy. S. Philosophical. Philosophicus, a, um. Cic. Physician. Medicus,
ci. m. g. Medicin. H. Asa. A healer of diseases.* He is a physician. Medicinam
profitetur, Est medicus. Il est medicin. Cord.

A good physician ought to know not only the disease of his pacient, but also
the complexion. Medico diligenti non solum morbus aegroti, sed etiam natura,
valetudo, vel constitutio corporis cognoscenda est. Un bon medicine doit
congnoistre non seulement la malady du patient, mais aussi la complexion. Cord.

What physician has he? what physician cures him: Quis medicus illum curat, A
quo curatur medico. Quel medicine le pense. Cord.

Physic. Ars medicinae, Medicina, nae. foem. genesis Medicine. S. Doctor of
physic. Medicinae doctor, vel doctor medicus. Docteur. etc.

Physiognomie, an art whereby the nature, or disposition of man is known,
both by body and countenance. Phisiognomia, ae. foe. ge. Ars qua natura
hominum ex corpore, vultuque cognoscitur. Physiognomer. Phisiognomon, onis. m.
g. Physiognomus, mi. m. g. Qui a totius corporis filo atque habitu, de ingenio
cuiusque pronunciat. H. Physnomie. Effigies, ei. Imago, nis. Vultus, us. m. ge.
Phisonomie. Pals. Phrase. Phrasis, is. f. g. Est eloquentiae corpus and dicendi
modus. Call. Phrase, or plain exposition of a sense, or text written.
Paraphrasis, sis. foe. ge.* Phy Vide Phi.

Piuoine, peuoene. S. Pype. Calamus, mi. Tibia, ae. Fistula, lae. foe. ge. Vne
fleute. S. Fistula, Is the general latin for any thing that is hollow, and
of the shape of a pipe, or whereof a pype may be made, as an Oote straw or
other straw, or reed. etc. vt Virgil. Est mihi disparibus septem compacta
cicutis,
Fistula: Damoetas dono mihi qua^ dedit olim.
Et dixit morien^: te nunc habet ista secu^dum.
With seven unequal spaces I
a pype that's joined have,
Which whilom for a gift to me
my friend Dametas gave,
And dieng said: thou art second now
this pype could ever have.

Plead. Actito, as. Agere, vel dicere, vel orare caussam, Inforo, as. Oro, as.

and le defendre. S.

l'accusateur. S.

To teach to plead. Viam litigandi tradere. Enseigner a plaider. S.

They plead one against an other. Certa^t inter se, aut litigant. Ils plaident
les vns contre les autres. S.

To plead no more. Desistere litibus. ne plaider plus.

To plead well. Causas agere industry, and altercari. Bien plaider. S.

To begin to plead. Inire certamen forense, Causaru^ age^daru^ facere
tyrociniu^, Actio^es causaru^ and altercatio^es co^mittere. Co^mencer a plaider.

To be ready to plead. In procinctu stare, Certaminique imminere. Estre pressed
a plaider. S.

To plead in the court. De superiore loco dicere. Plaider en la court. S.

He durst not plead. Ne certamen quidem altercandi tentauit. Il n' a ose
plaider. S.S.

such pleading is, Litis contestatio, Before the which it is said that no
costs shall be adwarded.*

P. ANTE. R.
PRactyse. Practica, ae. foe. ge. * Practice of a craft, or occupation.
Artificiu^, Vide Occupation. Practice. Ago, is. Adduco, is. Practiquer.
Practice craft, or deceipte. Tragulam inijcere. Practice friendship. Amicitiam
gerere. Cic. Practice hostility, or enemitie. Inimicor, aris. Vide Enemy.
Practice in matters of the law. Actito, as. Plaider. Practiser of law.
Formularius, Pragmaticus, ci. m. g. Un practicien qui scait son formulaire
comme il fault fair demandes and defenses. S. Practiser of physic.

Prevail. Praeualeo, es. Preualoir. S. Preuarication. Praeuaricatio, onis. f.
g. Preuaricatio^. It is a collusion done in law, albeit against the equity
of the law, whereby the one party suffers the other to obtain his suite, to
the intent to hurt or endomage some other, or else it is a swaruing from the
true and right way leaving ye vnspoke^ which should be said, or it is a brief
and light touching of a matter, which ought to be deliberatly, summarily, and
plainly spoken of. Prevent. Antecapio, is. Anteuenio, is. Anteuerto, is.

in his book, De libero Arbit. thus defines. Prudentia, est appetendarum, and
vitandarum rerum scientia, Macrob. Prudentiae est, ad rationis normam, quae
agit vniuersa dirigere, and nihil praeter rectu^, and laudabile facere.
Prudentiae insunt Ratio, Intellectus, Circu^spectio, Prouidentia, Docilitas,
Cautio. Et apud Socratem in sola prude^tia omnes virtutes colloce^tur. Aristot.
inquit, Impossible est, quempiam esse prude^tem, nisi sit bonus. Plat. in leg.
prudentia virtutu^ dux. Virtutis merita sunt haec, humilitas eam exornat,
prudentia exornatam decorat, fortitudo decoratam roborat, Iusticia roboratam
laetificat, temperantia laetificatam conducit, fides conductam erigit, spes
erectam dirigit, charitas directa^ coronat. Prudent. Prudens, it is. Callidus, a,

P. ANTE. T.
PTolomais, idis. Otherwise called Ache, A city in Phoenicia. Ptolemaide.
Plin. li. 5. ca. 19. Ptolomaeus, The name of diverse men, as well nobles as
others as. 1. Ptolomaeus Lagi gregarij militis filius, a quo Egyptij reges
deinceps Ptolemaei appellati sunt. 2. Ptolom. Philadelphus qui Bibliam in
peregrinas linguas traduci primum instituit. 3. Ptolom. Euergetes. Beronices
frater. 4. Ptolom. Philopater qui vicerit Antiochu^ magnum totus luxuria ob
amorem dissolutu^ in pellicem quandam translatum reginae mortis causam
crudeliter afferre voluit. 5. Ptolom. Epiphanes, cui post pacem conuentam
Antiochi magni filia in vxorem tradita est. 6. Ptolom. Philometor, quem
obsidebat Auunculus Epiphanes. 7. Ptolom. Euergetes, hic reduxit Demetriu^
profugum.* 8. Ptolom. Physco, vel Euergetes, Insignis tyrannus, qui spurca
libidine diffluxus sororem suam duxit vxorem, cui quaesitos liberos tyrannice
locauit obedendos. 9. Ptolomaeus Alexander.* 10. Ptolom. Latyrus. 11. Ptolom.
Auletes. 12. Ptolom. Dionysius, qui Pompeium necauit. 13. Ptolom. Astrologus
insignis, natione Aegyptus, qui floruit. Anno Christi. 163. Cuius Mathematicis
disciplinis, tota Aegyptus polita est.

Q. ANTE. A.
Q, A mute almost vnneadfull as is K, because ye C, may supply both their
places, and seems to serve none other purpose, than to join the vowell V,
that always follows him, with an other vowel in the same syllable (which
otherwise in one syllable can not be joined) and makes a more oblique and
grosser sound. Q, is changed into C, as Loquor, locutus, etc. In the notes of
ancient writers, Q, was written for Quintus, vel Quintius, Qu. Quartus, Qm.
Quomodo, QVAES, Quaestores. Q. L. Quinti Liberti. Q. V.AE.S. Quaestor. Q.
N.A.N.N. Quandoqu^ neque ais, neque negas. Q. F. Quinti Filius. Q. L. F. Quinti
Lucij filius. Q. vel Quint. Quintilianus. Quir. Quirites. Q. L. Quinti
Libertus. Q. M. Quintus Mutius. etc.
Qu. ANTE. A.
QVadrangle, or four square. Quadrangulus, a, u^. Qui ha quatres angles. S.
Quadrate. Quadratus, a, u^. Adiect. Quarre. Quadrate, or a square. Quadru^,
dri. n. g. Un quarre. Call. Quadrate aspecte of the planettes, or fourth part
of the Zodiac circle, wherein be the.xii. signs celestial. Tetartimorion,
Spatium trium signorum, Quarta Zodiaci pars. Quadripartite, of four parts, or

R. ANTE. A.
R, A semivowell and a liquid, which being put after a mute in the same
syllable, makes the syllable going before it (if it be short by nature)
common, as Ovid. makes Pa in this verse. Iam patrem, famulosque patris,
lucemque timebam. In the beginning of Greek words, it receaues an
aspiration: as, Rhadamanthus, Rhea, and the like. sometimes it is changed into
L, as, Intelligo, for Interlego, Pelluceo, for Perluceo, and in words not
compounde, as Niger, Nigellus, Vmbra, Vmbella: Into ss, as, Arbos, for Arbor:
and sometime into ss, as Vro, vssi. Gero, gessi: Into V, consonante, as Sero,
seui. Tero, triui. Persius calls it the dogs lettre, because it is uttered
with a quauering of ye tongue, and seems to imitate the Arring that a dog
makes, being angry. In the end of words it is short, except they be of
one syllable, as Cur, Fur, Lar, Ver, Par, with their compoundes which be long.
etc. In the notes of aunciente monumentes R, C, was Romana ciuitas, and R, D,
Regis domus. R. Is also written for Roma, Respublica, Rex, Regina, Richardus,
Robertus, Reginaldus, Rodulphus, Rogerus, and for diverse other propre names of
men. Rabat, or furrowe made in metals, timber, or stone, with an instrument
called a plough. Runctura, ae. Stria, ae. Vitruu. And yet Philander on the
third book of Vitruu. and.2. chap. And in the fourth book and fourth chap.
says, that Strix, gis. foe. ge. Is the rabat, and Stria, the imbossing out
between the rabates. Un canab. etc. Chaufrain creux. Et Strio, as. To rabate or
make such chaumfreyes in any thing. Fair tells chaufrains. S. Rabat, a plain
that carpenters use. Runcina, ae. f. genesis Rabot. S. Rabet, or young conye.
Cuniculus, li. m. g. Connin. S. Rack, critche, or maunger of a stable.
Praesepe, Praesepium, pij. n. ge. La creiche, ou auge d' un estable. H.
Ratillier. Pals. Rack to lay the brotche in at the fler. Crateuterium, rij.
n. g. H. Rack, or a torture to rack one on, to make him confess the truth.
Tormentum, ti. Fidiculae, arum, Torture, ou gehenne, ou question. Equuleus, ei.
m. g. A kind of rack to rack men on. To rack one, thereby to know the
truth of him. Tormentis quaerere, Quaerere crimen tormentis. Bailler la
gehenne, pour scauoir la verite de quelque cas. S.

To rack his fathers servants, or to examine them by torments, to know who
kylde his father. Mortis paternae habere quaestionem de seruis paternis.
Bailler la question and torture pour scauoir d'vn faict. S.

Confessions made on the rack. Confessiones tormentis expressae. Confessions
faicts en la gihenne.

memoriam redigere. Fair souuenir. S.

The one makes me to remember the other. Occurrit mihi aliud ex alio. L'vn me
fait souuenir de l'autre. S.

I remember that. Illud mihi occurrit. Il me souuient de cela. S.

I remember very well. Probe memini. Il me souuient fort bien. S.

Which remembers. Recordans, it is. Memor, ris. om. ge. A qui il souuient. S.

Paternam specie^ gerere, Exhibere faciem parentis. Resembler a son pere. S. To
resemble his father very much. Exscribere patrem similitudine. Resembler fort
a son pere. S.

Resemble, or to be like his father in manners. Mores patris refer. Resembler
a son pere de meurs. S. To resemble the image, or similitude of God. Dei
effigiem in se ostendere. Resembler a dieu. S.

It resembles the leaf of the Laurel. Effigiem folij lauri habet. Il
resemble a vne fu^ille de laurier.

reponere. Reseruer quelque chose pour le temps aduenir. S. This is expressly
reserved, and excepted. Hoc nominatim cautum and exceptum. Cela est
expressement reseru^. S.

Rich. Abundans, it is. om. ge. Dives, it is. Lautus, a, u^. Locuples, it is.

Rich of money. Nummatus, a, um. Pecuniosus, a, u^. Praemiosus, a, u^.
Nummosus, a, u^. Rich d'argent. Rich with brybing and polling. Auctus praeda,
vel spolio. Qui c'est faict rich par pillerie. S. Rich to be. Diuito, as.
Valere opibus, Abundare, Multa habere. Estre rich. S. He is so rich, he
knows not what he has. Adeo rebus omnibus abundat, vt sua ipse nesciat bona,
Est Craeso ditior, Crasso est opulentior, Circunfluit omnibus copijs, vel
omnium rerum copia. Il est s^riche, qu' il ne scait qu' il ha. Cord.

O why am not I so rich as thou? Me miseru^, cur non est mihi ista tua
fortuna? Cur non sum perinde ac tu dives, vel fortunatus? Cur te non aequo
diuitijs? Cur aeque, ac tu, dives non sum? O que ie ne suis aussi rich que
toy. S.

If I be once rich I will live at my pleasure. Siquando abundare coepero, Meo
more viuam, Si vnquam dives ero, meo modo, meo more vel arbitrio vitam agam. Si
ie suis vne fois rich, ie viuray a mon plaisir. S.

Thou will never be rich, thou wylt never thrive, or thou will never be
worth a groate. Nunqua^ re^ facies. Terent. Iamais tu ne seras rich.

tout mes secrets

Sembl^r. S. Me seemith I hard his voice even now at the door. Audire voce^
visa sum ante aedes modo. Il me semble que ie ay ouy sa voix maintena^t deua^t
la maiso^.

Sure me seemith, or me thinks it is not like to be true, it is unlike, or
me seemith it smelles like a lie. Mihi quidem hercle non fit verisimile.
Certes il ne me semble point vray semblable. S.

It seems so to thee. Tibi ita videtur. Il te semble ainsi. S.

It seems that this fellow serves some poor man. Apparet seruum hu^c esse
domini pauperis. Ter. Il semble a veoir que cestuy soit seruiteur d' un pour
homme. S.

ne conuenant. S.

est, ie. etc. Seeing that I care not for yours, care you as little for mine.
Quando ego non curo tuum, ne cura meum. Terent. Seeing I have taken it in hand,
I will not leave it. Quoniam quidem suscepi, non deero. Cic. Selandine, herb.

Seleucus, One of the kings of Siria ye north next Alexander, called
Antiochus, son to Antiochus Theos, and Laodice his wife which was repudiated.
This Seleucus Antiochus, was one of the four wings and four horns of
Alexander, after the prophecy of Daniel, of which names were diverse, as
Seleucus Nicanor, S. Gallinicus, Seleucus Ceraunus, Seleucus Philopater. Vide
Iosephum. Self heal an herb. Prunella, lae. vel potius Brunella, lae. f. g.
Turner. Sell. Vendo, is, didi. Venundo, as. Vendito, tas. Distraho, is. Aere
commutare. Vendre. S. Sell a thing before witness, or by delivering possession
maintenantly to the byer, or with promise of warantie. Mancipio dare, Mancupio
dare, Mancipo, as. Vendre auec promise de garentir. S. Mancipium, Is the thing
it self which is so bought and sold, as a bondema^, chattels, goods, lands.
etc. Mancipatio, Is th'assuraunce of the thing so sold, whether it be by
livery and seysing, possession, or otherwise. Mancipi, Is the interest, or
right of the thing. Mancipes, Been the sale makers of ware. Ma^cupi emptio, Is
ye form and manner of making such sale. And Mancipio accipere, Is to take
possession, or lyuerie and seizing of the thing sold, or to take it before
sufficient witness, or with warrantie of the gyuer or seller. etc. Sell a
thing to him, of whom it was first bought. Remancipo, as. Boeth. Remettre vne
chose vendue enter les mains de celuy qui la vendue, la luy reuendre. Sell at a
high pryse. Luculente vendere. Plaut. Vendre bien cher. S. Sell by port sale.
Auctionor, aris. Vide Sell publicly. Sell often. Vendito, as. Vendre souuent.

S. ANTE. K.
It is to be remembered, that if such words as you shall seek for, be not
here in S. ante K. seek for them in S. ante C.

S. ANTE. L.

ita est. Il n' est pas ainsi. S.

Be it so. Verum esto, Fac ita esse. Soit ainsi. S.

Is it even so? Is it so in deed? Ita ne est? Ter.

and respondant de quelqu' un. S.

S Ante Y, vide S Ante I.
T. ANTE. A.
T, A lettre somewhat hard to pronounce, as the rest of the mutes are, whereof
Lucian in his judgment of vowelles pleasauntly makes mention, brynginge in. S
obiectinge against T. that he as it were with certain bands wrappeth in ye
voice of man, and also with violence endeavors to tear, and rent it. Among
the Athenians, and Dorians, T. oftentimes displaced S. Again among the
Romans many words were wont to be written with T. which now in later time
are written with S. as Mertare, Pultare, which we write Mersare, Pulsare.
Besides T. has a certain affinity with D. as Quintil. in his first book,
and fourth chapter shows* for our elders used Alexanter, Cassantra, where as
we now use Alexander, and Cassandra. Tabaro, or chimere. Exomis, dis. f. g.

I know. Quod equidem scia^. Que ie scache. S I pray thee, that thou neither
forsake, nor leave her. Te obtestor, ne abs te hanc segreges, neu deseras. Ie
te pry que tu ne la delaisses point. S.

T. Ante. Y.
Vide T. Ante I.

V. ANTE. A.
V, The fifte vowell, which is oftentimes changed either into a s^ngle
consonante, as, Quum tales animos iuuenu^. etc: Or into a double consonante as,
Cupiui, Cupiueram, where I, coming before V. is made long. But V. consonante
sometime is contrarywyse changed into a vowell, by the figure Diaerisis: as,
Debuerant fusos euoluisse suos, for Euoluisse. Also after the opinion of some,
V. followinge these letters, G. Q. S. As Gu, Qu. Sua, is no consonante, and
loses the virtue of a letter. Finallye, V. in nombringe, signifies ^^ue: As
for example in these nombers followinge.v.vi.vii.viii.5.6.7.8. Vacant, or which
has naught to do. Vacans, it is. om. genesis Qui n'ha que fair. S. Vacant time,
or leisure. Otium, tij. n. genesis Loisir. S. To be vacant, or to be at leisure.
Vaco, as. Frui otio. Estre de loisir. S.

Vacation. Vacatio, onis, Vacation. S. Vacation, and cessinge from pleadinge.

V. ANTE. M.

V. ANTE. N.
First in this kind of phrase it is to be noted, that every word (for the
most part) beginning with this syllable Un, except verbes, be certain
adjectives, and negatiues to the words of which they be compounded, as for
example. Taught, Untaught, Doctus, Indoctus. Spotted Unspotted. Maculatus,
Immaculatus. Like, Unlike. Similis, Dissimilis. etc. So that untaught,
Indoctus, Is compounded of In, and doctus, Unlike, Dissimilis, Is compounded of
dis and Similis, which makes the contrariety, and so of other, Unable,
inepte, or not sufficient. Inhabilis, le. Inhabile, inepte and non suffisant.
S. Unaccustomed. Dissuetus, a, um. Insolitus, ta, tum. Inusitatus, ta, tum.
Insuetus, ta, tum. Inaccoustume. S. Unadvised. Incogitans, it is. Incogitatus,
ta, tum. Inconsidere. S. Unadvisedly. In praeceps, Praecipitanter, Imprudenter.
Inconsiderement. S. Unarm, or to take away ones armoure. Dearmare, Exarmare,
Armis aliquem exuere, Arma detrahere alicui. Desarmer aucun. S. To unarm him
self. Arma deponere. Se desarmer. S.

Unarmed. Dearmatus, ta, tum. Desarme. S. Unbelieving, or infidelity.
Infidelitas, tatis. foe. genesis Infidelite. S. Vnbende. Remitto, is. Retendo,
dis. Desbender. To vnbende a bow. Arcum detendere, vel Retendere. Desbender un
arc. S.

remissus. Arc desbende. S.

um. Effrene. Call. Unbuckle. Diffibulare, Refibulare. Desboucler. S. Unburden.

onus. Discharger aucun. S.

Deuenir aigre. S. Wax to a tree. Arboresco, scis. Deuenir arbre. S. Wax white
as milk. Elactesco, scis. Se blanchir comme laict. S. Waxing hard. Concretio,
onis. foe. ge. Cic. Waxing kernel. Glans, dis. foe. ge. Vne glande. Pals.
Seek all other verbes beginning with wax, (properly called verbes inceptiues,
or inchoatiues) in the principal words, from whence they are derived, as in
White, for to wax whit, In black, for to wax black. etc.


VV. ANTE. E.
Weak. Debilis, e. Delumbis, e. Flaccidus, a, um. Imbecillis, e. Imbellis, e.
Infirmus, a, um. Inualidus, a, um. Laxus, a, um. Vietus, a, um. Imbecillus, a,
um. Foible, debile. S. Very weak. Perimbecillus, a, um. Fort foible. S.

Weak or slender. Tenuis, e. om. g. Gresle and menu. S. Which has a sick,
or weak stomach. Stomachichus, a, um. Plin. Qui a mal a l'estomach. Call.

Weaken, or to make weak. Attenuo, as. Debilito, as, Infirmo, as. Tenuo, as.
Delumbo, as. Eneruo, as. Frango, is. Affoiblir, debiliter. S. To weaken greatly
the defense of any. Premere fauces defensionis alicuius. Grandement debiliter
la defense d'aucun. S.

Weaker title. Caussa inferior. Weakly. Imbecilliter, Infirm. Foiblement. S.
Weakened. Attenuatus, a, um. Debilitatus, Detrimento fractus, Infirmatus, a,
um. Affoibli. S. Weakness. Debilitas, it is. Imbecillitas, Infirmitas,
Inualetudo, inis. Foiblesse, debilite. S. Weakness of strength. Virium
infirmitas. Debilite de force. S. Weakness of health. Valetudinis infirmitas.
Debilite de sante. S. Weakness of heart, or stomach. Debilitatio atque abiectio
animi. Foiblesse de cueur. S. Weakening. Infirmatio, onis. Debilitatio, onis.
Affloiblissement. S. Wealpublike. Respublica. Republique. S. A sick
wealpublike. A^grota respublica. Republique qui va tresmal. S.

Weane. Ablacto, as. Subducere lac, A mamma disiungere, Depellere a matre,
Detrahere alumnum mamma, Auferre vberibus foetum Seurer. S. They weane the
little lambs. Lac subducitur agnis. On seure les petis agneaulx. S.

Weaned. Ablactatus, a, um. Delicus, a, um. Lacte depulsus. Qui est seure. S.
Weaning. Ablactatio, onis. foe. ge. Weapons. Arma, orum* n. g. Arms. S. To
lay hand on, or to take weapons. Capessere arma. Empoigner les arms. S.

Weaponed. Armatus, a, um. Arm. S. Which is not weaponed. Inermis, me. om.
genesis Qui n'est point arm. S.

Wear. Tero, is. Extero, is. Attero, is. Detero, is. Absumo, is. Consumo, is.
Vser. S. To wear the soole of his feet. Obterere vestigia, Calces deterere.
Vser la plant de ses pieds. S.

Wear a hoode. Humerale gestamen gestare. Porter le chaperon. S. Wear, or use
often. Gestito, as. Plaut. Weary. Defessus, a, um. Fatigatus, a, um. Fessus, a,
u^. Lassus, a, um. Less ou las. S. That is very weary of a thing. Pertaesus,
a, um.

Weary of wars. Fractus bello. Virg. Weary to be. Defetiscor, eris.
Elassesco, cis. Lasseo, es. Lassesco, cis. Se lasser, estre less. S. I am
weary to hear. etc. Taedet iam audire eadem millies. Ie m'ennuye d'ouir. etc.
S.

I am weary of my life. Vitae taedet. Ie m' ennuye de viure. S.

Weary to make. Defatigo, as. Delasso, as. Lasso, as. Obtundo, is. Rumpo, is.
Fatigo, as. Lasser, fatiguer. S. I am weary with running. Me rupi currendo. Ie
me suis less de cou^ir. S.

This walking has made me very weary. Me haec deambulatio ad languorem dedit.
Ce pourmenement m'a fort less. S.

Weary to make with words. Conterere alique^ oratione. Plaut. Weary to wax.
Lassesco, cis. Deuenir las. S. Wearied. Defatigatus, a, um. Fatigatus, a, um.
Lassatus, a, um. Fessus, a, um. Less, fatigue. S. Wearines. Defatigatio,
Lassitudo, inis. Taedium, ij. Fatigatio, onis. Languor, oris. masc. genesis
Lassete fatigation. S. Wearines, or fulness. Satietas, atis. foe. ge. Ennuy, ou
saoulement S. Weaue. Detexo, is. Texo, is, xui. Adtexo, is, xui. Tistre. S. To
weaue with an other thing, or to weaue to. Adtexo, is. Tistre auec autre chose.

Weaue perfectly, or to an end. Pertexo is. Acheuer de tistre, parfaire. Call.
Weaue together. Contexo, is. Tistre ensemble. S. To begin to weaue. Ordiri
telam. Commencer a tistre. S.

Weaued. Textus, a, um. Tissu. S. et Textilis, e. Ang. Which is weaued. Qui
est tissu. S. Weaued together. Contextus, a, um, Tissu ensemble. Weauer.
Textor, ris. m. genesis Tissier, ou tisserand. S. and Textrix, icis. foe. genesis A
woman weauer. Vne tisserande. S. Weauer of sylke. Seracarius textor. Tisserand
de soy. Weauers beam, whereon they turn their web at hand. Iugum, gi.
Panus, ni. Rouet. S. Weauers craft. Textrina. L'art de tistre. S. Weauers of
cloth of bawdkin. Barbaricarij, orum. Phrigiones, number. Call. ex Alciat. Weauers
shittle. Liciatorium, ij. Radius, ij. mas. g. La nauette. H. Weauers shop.
Textrina, Textrinum, ni. neu. ge. L'ouuroir d'vn tisserand. S. Weauing.
Textura, ae. Textus, tus, m. ge. Tissure. Web of cloth. Tela, ae. foe. ge.
Toil. S. To unweave, or pluckte the threedes from the web. Detexo, is.
Detistre, ou deffiler la toil. S.

To wedde a husband. Nubere, Innubere. Espouser mari, prendre mari. S.

To wedde a daughter rychely without giving any thing. Dare in nuptias filiam
sine dote. Marier richement vne fille sans rien luy bailler. S.

To wedde him self. Connubere, Coniungere sibi foeminam matrimonio, Vxorem
sibi adiungere, Vxorem ducere, Denubere. Se marier. S.

Web or pearl in the eye. Leucoma, it is. Albugo, inis. foe. ge. Vne taye, and
tache blanch en l' oeil. S. Wechhasel a tree. Opulus, li. f. ge. Wedde, or to
marie. Maritare, Innuptias conijcere, Filiam in matrimonium collocare, Dare
nuptu^. Marier. S. Wedded. Nuptus, a, um. Marie. S. New wedded. Nouus nuptus,
Recens nuptus. Nouueau marie. S.

To desire to be wedded. Cupere nuptias, Nupturire. Auoir faim d' estre marie.
S.

To be wedded. Permisceri matrimonio, Esse maritum. Estre marie. S.

Which is not married. Caelebs, bis. com. gener. Qui n'est point marie. S.

Wedded man. Maritus, ti. m. ge. Mari. S. Wedded man's harlot, or concubine.
Pellex, cis. f. ge. Concubine d'vn homme marie, S. Wedded woman. Marita, ae.
Nupta, ae. f. g. Mariee. S Wedding. Nuptiae, arum. Nopces. S. and Nuptialis, e.
Of a wedding. De nopces. Call. Wedding, or marying. Nuptus, tus. m. g.
Marrieme^t. Wedding chamber. Thalamus, mi. m. g. Ovid. Wedding garment. Vestis
nuptialis. Wedlock. Coniugium, ij. Connubium, Matrimonium, nij. n. g. Marriage.
S. To hate the state of wedlock. Ab re vxoria abhorrere. Hair l'estate de
marriage. S.

To break the faith of wedlock. Fidem coniugij violare. Rompre la foy de
marriage. S.

Wedge. Cuneus, ei. foe. ge. Un coing, S. and Cuneolus, li. m. g. Petit coing.
S. Wedge of gold. Massa auri, Palacra. ae. f. ge. Plin. To drive in as a
wedge. Adigo, is. Cuneo, as. Tundo, is. Coigner. S.

Driven in as a wedge. Adactus, a, um. Coigne. S. To be wedged, or driven in
with force. Per vim cuneari. Es^re coigne a force. S.

Made in form of a wedge. Cuneatus, a, um. Fait en form de coing. S.

We. Nos. Nous. S. We dispute two against two. Bini disputamus. Nous
disputons deux contre deux. S. We go to the fields. Rus abimus, Nous en
allons aux champs. S. We our selves. Nosmet ipsi. Nousmesmes. S. Weed. Herba
erratica. Herb sauuage, S. To weed, Sarculo, as. Sarcler. S.

To weed corn. Sarrio, is. Consarrio, is. Sarcler les bleds.

To weed out the weeds. Exherbo, as. Runco, as* Sarcler, and oster les herbs
meschantes. Call.

Weeder. Sarritor, oris, Sartor, oris. Runcator, oris. mas. genesis Sarcleur. S.

Opinor, ris. Penser, ou cuider. As I ween. Vt puto, Vt opinor, Vt mea fert
opinio. Comme ie cuide, ou ie pense. S.

Weening. Opinio, onis. foe. ge. Opinion and judgment. Weep. Fleo, es.
Lachrymo, as. Ploro, as. Affleo, es. Delachrymo, as. Lachrymor, aris.
Illachrymor, aris. Larmoyer and plourer. S. Weep and to wayle. Eiulo, as.
Plango, is, nxi. Braire. S Weep no more. Mitte lachrymas. Ne pleure plus. S.
To make, or cause to weep. Adducere in fletu^, Lachyrmas elicere, Fletum
mouere. Fair pleurer.

To forbear, or keep him from weeping. Lachrymas tenere vel continere,
Lachrymis imperare, A lachrymis temperare. Se garder de pleurer. S.

Weep together, or with other. Collachrymo, as. Plourer ensemble. S. Weeper.

om. gener. Pleurant. S. Weeping. Flerus, us. Ploratus, us. Lachrymatio, nis.
foe. ge. Larmoyement. S. and Plorabundus, a, um. Which weepeth much. Qui
pleure fort. S. Weeping, and waylinge. Eiulatio, Planctus, us. m. g. Braiement.

Praegrauare. Plus peser d'vn cost que d'autre. S.

It weyeth ten drammes. Pendetper se drachmas december. Il poise dix drachmes. S.

Weye much, or more. Praepondero, ras. Plus peser. S Weye up ancre. Anchoram
subducere. Weighed. Libratus, Ponderatus, Trutinatus, a, um. Pese. S. Weyer.

pound. Trilibris, e. om. genesis Pesant trois livers. S. Weying four pound.
Quadrilibris, e. om. genesis Pesant quatre livers. S. Weight to weye some thing.
Pondus, eris. Le poix a peser quelque chose. S. Pondusculum, li. dimin. Ang. A

eris. neut. g. La pesanteur de quelque chose. S.

Hebdomada, ae. Septimana, ae. f. ge. Sepmaine. S. Well. Belle, Been, Probe,
Recte, Valde. Bien. S. Not so well. Non aeque been. Non pas si bien. S.

That is well done of you. Been facis, Been agis, C'est bien faict a vous. S.

That is well said, or spoken of thee. Lepide memoras, Been dicis. C'est bien
dict a toy. S.

Well aduysed. Consultus, a, um. Ovid. Well at ease to be. Saluere, Recte
valere. Se porter bien. S. Well beloved. Charus, a, um. Bien aim. S. To
welcome, any. Foelicem aduentum alicui precari, Comiter excipere aliquem.
Byenuienner, ou bienueigner aucun. S.

Welcome, even with all my heart. Optato aduenisti. Terent. Well done. Euge.
Plaut. Well favored. Formosus. Pulcher. Beau. S. Well go to. Age vt lubet.
Terent. Well a gods name let him speak, I am well content. Age dicat, Sin.
Bien de par dieu qu'il die in en suis content. S. Well nyghe. Vsque, Pene,
Prope, Propemodum, Fere, Modo, Ferme, Tantum non, Modo non. Presque. S. He has
well nighe killed me with stripes. Me pugnis vsque occidit. Il m'a presque tue
de coups. S

Well nighe all. Plerique, Fere plerique. Presque tous. Well spoken. Disertus,
a, um. Disert. S. Well, well. Age, age. Terent. Bien, bien. S. Well wrought.
Adfabrum. Cic. Well, or a spring. Fons, it is. m. g. Font ou fontaine. S.
Fonticulus, li. dimin. Ang. A little well. Fontenelle, ou petite fontaine. S.
Well being cold in summer. Derce.* Well mouth. Crepido, inis. f. ge. Colum.

Puteanus, a, um. De puis. Well water. Aqua puteana, vel putealis. Eaue de
puis. H. A well never dry. Iugis puteus. Puis qui ne tarist point. S.

To draw water out of a well. E puteo aquam sumere, Haurire aquam. Puiser de
l'eaue d'vn puis.

VV. ANTE. H.
WHaye. Serum, ri. Serum lactis. Ser du laict, megue. H. Whale a fyshe. Cete,
is. Cetus, ti. Balaena, ae. foe. genesis Vne balene. S. When, or when. Cum, adu.
Quando, Quando gentium, Quum, Vbi, Vbi loci. Quand. S. Vide when. Wharle to put
on a spyndle to spinne with. Verticulus, li. Verticulum, li. n. g. Peson,
vertoyl, pirouette. What. Quid, Quidnam, Quis, qui, quae, quod. Que, quel. S. I
know what age thou art. Ego scio quid sis aetatis. Ie scay quel aage tu has.
S.

What is this? what is that? Quid hoc rei est? Qu'est cela? What do thou?
Quam rem agis? Quid agis? Que fais tu? What makes Chaeria here? Quidnam Chaeria
hic rerum gerit. Qu'est ce que fait ici Cherea? What else should he have done?
Quid fecisset aliud? Qu'y eust il fait autre chose? S. What else would I have
said? Quid, Quid aliud volui dicere? Que demandoye ie autre chose? S. What art
thou? Quid tu hominis es? Quel homme es tu? S. I know not what man thou art.
Nescio quid tu viri sis, Nescio te ego. Ie ne scay quel ho^me tu es.

What? what is that? Hem, quid est? Quoy qu' est cela? S. What to do? Qua
gratia? Qua de re? Quam ad rem? A quoy fair? S. What a mischief. Quae malum.
What country man, or of what country. Cuias it is. adiect. De quel pays. S.
What fashion, or of what sort. Cuiusmodi. De quelque sort. S. What man? Quis?
Quisnam? Qui vir? Quel ho^me? What man in the world. Quisnam gentium. What
manner. Cuiusmodi. De quelle maniere. S. What manner of man. Qualis, Quis. Quel.
S. What manner of thing. Quale, Quid. Quelle chose. S. What number, or order, or
of what number or order. Quotus, a, um. Quantieme. S. Vt quota hora, Quotus est
a primo. What, or of what quality. Qualis, le. Quel. S. Whatsoever. Quicquid,
Quodcunque. Tout ce que, Quelconque. S. Whatsoever man he be. Qualis qualis,
Qualiscunque. Quel qu'il est. S. Whatsoever thou wylt. Quiduis, Cuiusuis. Tout
ce que tu vouldras. S. What to do, or wherefore. Quamobrem? Vnde? Pourquoy. S.
Whaule eyed. Glauciolus, a, um.* Wheale, or a whelke, or blister. Pustula, lae.
foe. genesis Vne ampoule. S. Wheat. Arista, Frumentum, ti. Triticum, ci. neu. g.
Froument. S. and Triticeus, a, um. Frumentaceus, a, um. Of wheat, or wheaten.
De froument. Call. and Frumentarius, a, u^. Pertaining to wheat. Triticum, Is
properly wheat which is out of the ear, or threshed. Pure wheat. Far
vernaculu^, Ador. nom. Indec. Adoreum far. Pur froument. S.

Wheat being foul, not dressed, or vnwynewed. Acerosum frumentum. Wheat
flower, or flower of meal. Pollen, nis. Fleur de farine. S. Wheat eaten with
wiuels, or mytes. Triticum a curculionibus erosum. Ble calendre. S. Wheat
having but one read, or stalk growing out of the root. Vnicalamum frumentum.
Plin. A kind of small wheat being white. Olyra, ae. Siligo, inis. foem. genesis
Vne sort de froument menu, blanc. S.

Wheat straw Calamus, mi. m. ge. Tuyau de ble. S. Wheaten, or of wheat.
Frumentaceus, a, um. Tri ticeus, a, um. De froument. S. Wheaten plummes, white
or yellowe plummes. Cerea pruna. Virg. De poetrons, ou prunes iaulnes. S
Wheel. Rota, ae. f. g. Vne roue. S. Et Rotula. dimin. Ang. A little or small
wheale. Vne petite roue. S. Wheel barrowe. Arcirma,* Vehiculum trusatile, vel
secundum Agricol. Cisium, sij. neut. genesis Vne brouette. S. and Sarracum non
male dici poterit secundum Had. Bruette. Wheel of a crane wherein men stand
that turn up burdens. Tympanum, ni. Rota, tae. Versatile tympanum. La roue d'
vne grue, de quoy on haulsse les fard^aux. H. Wheel of a wyndles in the which
the rope runs, called the pullaye. Trochlea, ae. foem. genesis Vne poulie. S.
Wheel to turn anythi^g with, a turners wheel. Tornus, ni. m. ge. Tournoir.
H. Wheel tracke or rutte. Orbita, tae. foe. g. Vne orniere. Whelke, or blayne.
Papula, ae. foe. ge. Pustula, lae. foe. genesis Bubo. S. Whelpe. Caniculus, li.
Catulus, li. m. g. Un petit chie^. Whelpe of a Lion. Scymnus, ni. Catulus

Quand. S. When shall this be? Quando istuc erit? Quand fera ec? Let him come
when he will. Veniat qua^do volet. Qu'il vienne quand il vouldra. S.

vis accede. Approach quand il te plai^^. S.

Whence, or from whence. Vnde. D'ou. S. Whence comes she? Vnde haec gentium?
D' ou vient elle. S. Where. Vbi. Ou. S. Where be the other? Cedo alios? Ou sont
les autres? S Where be we? Vbinam gentium sumus? Ou sommes nos? S* Where waste
thou? Vbi terrarum eras? Ou tu estois? Every where. Vbique. aduerb. Par tout. S.

Whereby. Quo, Vnde. Don't. S. Whereby it comes to pass. Ex quo fit, vt. etc.
Don't aduient que. etc. Whereby it is plain that. etc. Ex quo manefestum est.
etc. Don't il appert que. etc. Whereby it is come to pass. Per quod effectum
est. Don't est aduenu. S. Wherefore? why? or for what cause? Cur? Quare?
Quamobrem? Qui? Quid ita? Pourquoy? S. But wherefore I pray you? Quamobrem
ta^dem? Mais pourquoy ie vous pry? S.

But wherefore are you angrye with me? Sed quid negotij quamobrem succenses
mihi? Pour quoy est ce que tu te courrouces a moy. S.

Wherefore, or why not? Quidni, Quid ita non? Pourquoy non? therefore, or why

cela toymesme? Wherefore, therefore, or for that cause. Qua de re, Quamobrem,

VV. ANTE. O.
WOE. Dolor, ris. Vide Sorrow, and Grief. Woe be to you, or wo-worth you. Vae,

scauoir. S.

I would. Non nollem, Vellem. Ie vouldroye bien.

X.
X, Is a semiuowell, and has the force of a double consonant, for the which
in old wrytinges cs, and gs, was used, As Apecs, Gregs, For Apex, Grex, In
composition of words S, is not written after an X, As the rule is, Post X non
scribitur S, vt Exugo, is. Exupero, as. Of which words the one is compounded
of Ex and Sugo, the other of Ex and Supero, And should be written thus, Exsugo,
Exsupero, Were not the rule and custom of writing otherwise. X, also is
written for the figure of ten, and may be augmented in this manner.x.xx.xxx.
which is, 10.20.30. Ten, twenty, thirty. Or
thus.xi.xij.xiij.xiiij.xv.xvi.xvij.xviij.xix. which is 11.12.13.14.15. etc.
Eleven, twelve, thirtene, fourtene, fiftene, sixtene, seuentene, eightene,
nyntene, and so forth, (of which nombers though not of their forms) have I
spoken before in their places. X ounce, or ten ounces. Dextans, it is. Diz
onces. H. Xantippa, The name of Socrates wife, a woman of wonderful
impatience, and shrewyshe demeanoure, whose curstenes Socrates suffered with
marvelous patience, and being asked of Aleibiades, why he suffered such a
shrewe in his house, therefore (quod he) bide I this at home, that when I come
abroad I may the better bear with the wantonness and injuries of others.
Xantippe, es. foe. genesis Xi ounces. Deunx, cis. Onze onces. H. Or a measure
containing as much as a reasonable man may drink at.xi. times. Xx. Viginti.
Vide Twenty. Xxx. Triginti. Vide Thirty.
Y. ANTE. A.
Y, Is a Greek vowel, and used with us and the French men, even as I, the
vowell is, it has also with use oftentimes the force almost of a consonant,
as in these words you, yard, yarne, which words can not be written with an I,
Also Y, may both begin, and end a word, as the letter I, and other vowels
do. I have declared somewhat hereof in the letter I. Yard, a measure to
measure with. Virga, ae. foe. ge. Vne verge. S. Yard of a man. Coals, is.
Virga virilis. Vide privy. Yard, or a court of a house. Area, ae. foem. genesis
Vne court de maison. S. Yarke of a whippe. Tax. n. g. Le son d'vn coup de
fouet. Yarne, or threde of cloth. Filum, li. n. g. Fill, filet. H. Yarrowe,
milfoile, or nosebleede, an herb. Millefolium, Stratiotes, Millefolium maius.
Millefueille. Yate. Ianua, Porta. Vide Gate. Yaune, or to gape. Hio, as.
Dehisco, scis. Baailler. S. Yaune, or to gape wide. Inhio, as. Oscito, tas.
Fort. baailler. S. To yaune for sleep. Hiscere, Oscitare, Oscitari Baailler de
sommiel. S.

Which yauneth, or is open. Hians, it is. Dehiscens, it is. Qui baaille ou est
ouuert. S.

Yauning for sleep. Oscitans, it is. Baaillant de sommeil. Yauning, or gaping.
Hiatus, tus. Oscitatio, onis. f. g. Baaillement. S.

Ocior, aris. Otior, aris. Otiosum esse. Estre oiseux. S. Ydlenes. Cessatio,
Ocium, Otium, tij. n. g. Oisiuete. S. Ydely. Ociose, Otiose. Oisiuement. Call.

qui adore vne idol. S. Ydolatrie. Idololatria, ae. foe. g. Idolatry. S.

Y. ANTE. E.
YEa. Etiam, Immo, Ita, Sane, Sic. Ouy. S. Yea but. Immo, Sed autem. Mais. S.
Yea certainly. Immo certe. Ouy certaynement. Yea, I say so. Ita loquor. Ouy ie
le die. S. Yea, I tell thee. Ita inquam. Ouy te die ie. S. Yea mary. Quid ni.
Vide What. Yea rather. Immo. Mais plustost. S. Yea truly. Quippe. Ouy certes.
S. Yea verily. Ita vero, Ita enimuero. Ouy vrayement. S Year. Vide year. Ye,
or you. Vos Vous. S. Have ye knives? Habetisne cultros? Aues vous des
cousteaux? S.

Your doings are such yt ye seem of a set purpose to do them against your
selves. Quae facitis eiusmodi sint, vt ea dedita opera a vobis contra
vosmetipsos facere videamini. Cic.

Yield. Dedo, is. Trado, is. Se render. S. I yield to thee. Dedo me tibi. Ie me
rens a toy. S.

To yield to the enemy. Tradere se. Se render a son ennemi. S.

They did yield to the consuls mercy. Abiectis armis, in fidem consulis
venerunt. Ils se redirent a la merci du consul. S. Vide Render.

Yield account. Calculum ponere, Dictare ratione^, Rations dare, Reddere, vel
refer rationem. Render un compte. S. Yield, or to render. Reddere,
Retribuere, Restituere. Render. S. Yield forth licour, or moistnes. Exudo, as.
Veluti per sudorem emitto. Render sueur. Call. Yield, or render him self to the
enemies part. Transfugio, is. Se render du parti des enemis. S. Yield to an
other in battle. Dedo, is, Diditionem facere. Vide Render. Yield up. Resigno,
as. Vide Resign. Yield up a castle, or fortress to the ennemies. Prodere
arcem obsidentibus, Arcem prodere hostibus. Render la fortress aux ennemis. S.
Yield up ghost. Edere spiritum. Vide Die. Yielded up. Deditus, a, um. Rendu. S.
Yelding to enemies. Tra^sfugiu^, Defectio ad hosts. Yelding up our selves to
one. Deditio, onis. foe. ge. Quand on se rend a aucun. S. and Dedititius, a,
um. Which has yielded him self to the mercy of an other. Qui se rend a la
mercy d'autruy. S. Yelke of an egg. Luteu^ oui, Vitellus, li. vide Egg. Yell
and rore. Vide Cry, Rore. Yellowe. Flauus, a, um. Luteus, a, um. Rufus, a, um.
Iaulne. S. Yellowe ambre, called Lambre. Sualternicum.* Yellowe earth found in

feray. S.

Z.
Z, A double c^^sonant, it is not used in Latin, but in Greek, and in very
few English words. Zacharias a Prophet, the father of John Baptiste, which
is interpreted just or justified, or the memory of the Lord. Zacharias, ae.
m. ge. Zele. Zelus, li. m. ge. Zele. S. Zele to have, or tender. Zelo, as.
Zeler. S. Zodiac or celestial circle, wherein be the.xii. signs. Zodiacus,
ci. m. g. Zodiaque. S. Zone. Zona, nae. foe. ge. Zone. S.
Soli Deo, Honor, Laus and Gloria.

Faults escaped.
Abound. Circumfluo. Abonder. Acuse. Arcessere. Aucun. Alecost. Saluia Romana.
Alms. Eleemosyna. Apease. Tranquillum. etc. Apple of winter fruit. Pomum
serotinum. Apple ripe. Pomum maturum. Apple monger. Pomilius. Augustinus a
famous doctor in Christ's church. etc. Beware. Prouideo. Bewitche. Effascino,
fascinat. Buffe. Vulgus. Cuckowe. Coccyx. Day. Lumen solis. Dead, pertaining to
the dead. Drawght. Epotauit. Elephant. Elephas. Elephant. Emeraude.
Scrutantibus. Increase. Accrescere. Idolatrer. Idololatra. Idololatrie.
